Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: Hon. David Hawker) took the chair at 9.00 am and read prayers. TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX REDUCTION) BILL 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Costello, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: Unknown
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The measures contained in this bill will cut personal income tax for all Australian taxpayers. The tax reductions amount to $21.7 billion over the next four years. This is in addition to the $14.7 billion in tax cuts provided in last year's budget. From 1 July 2005, the 17 per cent marginal tax rate will be cut to 15 per cent. The 42 per cent threshold will increase to $63,000 and from 1 July 2006 will increase again to $70,000. From 1 July 2005, the 47 per cent threshold will increase to $95,000 and from 1 July 2006 will increase again to $125,000. The reduction in the 17 per cent rate to 15 per cent means that taxpayers who are eligible for the full low income tax offset will pay tax until their income exceeds $7,567, up from $7,382 currently. Senior Australians will also benefit. From 1 July 2005, senior Australians who receive the senior Australians tax offset can earn more without paying tax. Single senior Australians will now pay no tax on their annual income up to $21,968 and no tax on equal incomes up to a joint $36,494 for a couple. The Medicare levy threshold for senior Australians will be increased to ensure that they do not pay the Medicare levy until they begin to incur an income tax liability. The personal income tax cuts will assist low-income earners, boost disposable incomes and improve incentives for all Australian taxpayers to participate in the work force, to invest and to save. This will ensure that over 80 per cent of taxpayers will face a top marginal tax rate of 30 per cent or less. These personal income tax cuts will further improve the structure of Australia's tax system and increase our international competitiveness. Our strong economy, lifestyle advantages and changes to the top two thresholds will provide incentives to work in Australia. Taxpayers will not reach the highest marginal tax rate until they earn around three times average weekly earnings, with the top marginal rate applying to only three per cent of taxpayers from 2006-07. If the threshold for the top marginal rate had been indexed to inflation since 1996, on 1 July 2006 it would have stood below $64,000. Under the measures contained in this bill it will stand at $125,000. This income tax cut is due to take effect on 1 July of this year. In order to ensure that the tax cuts take effect on 1 July this year, this parliament needs to pass legislation. The legislation is the basis for the Commissioner of Taxation to publish the scales which inform employers how much tax they should not withhold. Until such time as those new scales are published showing the lesser amounts to be withheld, employees will still have today's tax taken out rather than the reduced tax which would apply after 1 July 2005. For that reason this legislation needs to go through this parliament in good time before 1 July 2005. Any blocking measures by the Australian Labor Party could only be designed to keep from people the tax cut which they deserve on 1 July 2005. Let me make it clear: the Australian Labor Party will not block this tax cut. This tax cut will go through in the new Senate if it does not go through in the current Senate. The only thing that the Australian Labor Party could be expecting to achieve with their current tactics is to delay a tax cut for all Australian income tax payers. Their opposition will be futile. It will not work. The new Senate will be able to pass this legislation, but the new Senate does not sit until 9 August. The tax cut is due on 1 July. I call on the Australian Labor Party not to stand in the way of tax cuts for every Australian. We know that Labor stand for higher taxes. They are demonstrating that they stand for higher taxes by trying to delay this bill. This morning the Australian Labor Party is in absolute chaos because of the brilliant Black Adder like tactics of the member for Lilley and the Leader of the Opposition. They have a cunning plan to deny Australians the tax cuts which they deserve. There are members of the Australian Labor Party backbench who know that this is a ridiculous tactic. I call on those members, if they are in the Senate, to at least abstain in relation to this vote and to allow this legislation through before 30 June. Let us be clear about this-Labor can only delay this tax cut if it has every single its senators voting against it in the Senate and combining with other minor parties. If those senators are prepared to join with the government, or at least to abstain from the vote, Australians can have their tax cuts. This government stands for lower income taxes. This government announced a plan for lower income taxes on Tuesday night. This government has fully funded it. This government calls on the opposition to join with it. This government says to the Labor Party, ‘Do not stand in the way of tax cuts.' Labor may stand for higher taxes, but this time the stand will be futile. This will go through the new Senate; it ought to go through immediately. I can also indicate, on behalf of the government, that if the Australian Labor Party wants to bring the vote on today, we would be prepared to facilitate that-with no divisions and no delaying tactics. If it wants to bring this bill on today, have a vote and go down on the record as voting against it in the House of Representatives, I make the offer that we would facilitate that if it were done by leave and by agreement. Why? Because Australians want income tax cuts. I commend this bill to the House. The full measures are contained in the exploratory memorandum which I present to the House. Debate (on motion by Ms Gillard) adjourned. TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (2005 MEASURES No. 3) BILL 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Brough, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: Unknown
text: Longman-Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (9.09 am)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill amends various taxation laws to implement a range of changes and improveone of ments to Australia's taxation system. Firstly, the bill will implement a number of proposals to increase flexibility for charitable funds, ancillary funds and prescribed private funds, and hence further encourage charitable giving in Australia. The bill expands the concessions relating to the capital gains tax provisions, distributions by charitable funds, the income tax exemption for charities and the refund of franking credits provisions. The measure gives effect to the government's announcement in the 2004-05 budget. The amendment in Schedule 2 to this bill is technical in nature and deals with the recently expanded foreign branch profits exemption. The expanded exemption, in conjunction with Australia's treaties, could have resulted in foreign branch income and gains derived from the operation of ships or aircraft in international traffic not being taxed in Australia or the country in which the company operates. Schedule 2 to this bill reinstates the way Australian companies with foreign branch income and gains from the operation of ships or aircraft in international traffic were taxed prior to the implementation of the expanded foreign branch income exemption. This will ensure that such amounts continue to be taxed in Australia. The Commissioner of Taxation can release taxpayer information to certain law enforcement agencies, such as police forces and various crime commissions, if the commissioner is satisfied that the information is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been committed or to the making of a proceeds of crime order. The third measure will add the Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia to the list of law enforcement agencies to which taxpayer information can be provided. The fourth measure will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 to make a technical correction. This will clarify that certain government institutions that are charitable institutions at law are not eligible fund. for fringe benefits tax rebatable employer status from 1 July 2005. This amendment will ensure that the status quo is not changed. Finally, this bill introduces a standard definition of a dependant: a child less than 21 years or a full-time student less than 25 years. This means there will be a single set age criteria for the housekeeper, keeper, medical expenses and zone tax offsets, as well as the Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge. It will provide consistency for taxpayers and will allow more taxpayers to access the dependant-related offsets, the concessional Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge thresholds offsets, and the Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge family thresholds. Full details of the measures in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum. I commend this bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Fitzgibbon) adjourned. SUPERANNUATION BILL 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Dr Stone, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: Unknown
text: Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration (9.13 am)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Superannuation Bill 2005, together with the Superannuation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2005, will provide for the separation of the Public Sector Superannuation Accumulation Plan, the PSSAP, from the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme, the PSS. The bill will also provide a framework for Australian government employers to offer employees and office holders with choice of The PSSAP will be established as a fully funded accumulation scheme for new Australian government employees and office holders and certain other persons from 1 July 2005. It was established as a subplan of the PSS by the 20th Amending Deed, which of amended the trust deed and rules under the child house- Superannuation Act 1990. The bill will provide for the PSSAP to commence as a scheme separate from the PSS. This will allow it to operate on the same basis as similar superannuation schemes. While it exists as part of the PSS, the PSSAP must operate within the framework of a largely unfunded defined benefit scheme, rather than a framework appropriate for a fully funded accumulation scheme. This requires it to include features that are not usual for accumulation schemes. Although the PSSAP will be separate from the PSS, the PSS board will continue to be responsible for the PSSAP and the Commissioner for Superannuation will continue to provide administrative services to the board in respect of the new scheme. The PSS board will also be responsible for the new PSSAP fund established by the bill. Like the PSS, the rules for the PSSAP will be provided for by trust deed. Following the passage of the bill a new trust deed and will be made for the PSSAP in essentially the same form as the existing rules for the PSSAP as a subplan of the PSS. It is intended that Australian government employees and office holders will be treated in the separate superannuation scheme in the same way as they would have been treated in the subplan of the PSS and employer contributions will be payable in the same circumstances. However, the bill, together with the consequential bill, will require new Australian government employees and office holders to be given choice of fund arrangements from 1 July 2006. Their employer may also offer them choice of fund from as early as 1 July 2005. This framework will provide them with unprecedented flexibility for investing their superannuation savings and will address the rigid arrangements currently in place where membership of one scheme is mandated for most employees. From 1 July 2006, Australian government employers will be required to comply with the choice requirements of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 (SG Act), like most private sector employers. The legislation also provides that the PSSAP will be the employer-or defaultfund for Australian Public Service employees and certain other prescribed persons who do not choose a fund. Other employers will have the flexibility to nominate the PSSAP or another appropriate complying superannuation fund or retirement savings account in these circumstances. The proposed changes do not affect existing Australian government employees at 30 June 2005, including those employees who are members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme or the PSS. Also the arrangements will not generally rules affect those new employees who have an existing relevant interest in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS) or the PSS, for example where a person has a PSS preserved benefit. Those employees will continue to be eligible to join those schemes as appropriate. I commend this bill to the House and I table the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Fitzgibbon) adjourned. NA (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Dr Stone, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: SUPERANNUATION
text: Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration (9.18 am)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Superannuation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2005 will amend eight acts and the trust deed under the Superannuation Act 1990 as a consequence of the establishment of the Public Sector Superannuation Accumulation Plan, the PSSAP, as a separate superannuation scheme and will allow Australian government employees and office holders to have choice of fund. The Superannuation Bill 2005 will establish the PSSAP as a separate scheme from the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme, the PSS. The Superannuation Act 1990, which provides for the PSS, will confirm that the PSS will close to new employees from 1 July 2005 with the commencement of the PSSAP. The Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 is being amended to allow Australian government employers to comply with the choice of fund requirements until 1 July 2006 in respect of employees who are PSSAP members. From that date, employers will be required to meet the choice of fund requirements in respect of new employees in the same manner as most private sector employers. The Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988 provides for superannuation guarantee type contributions for Australian government employees and office holders who are not Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme or PSS members. The bill will amend that act so that it does not apply to new employees and office holders from 1 July 2006. Superannuation will be provided for these persons as agreed with their employer subject to employers providing contributions at least in accordance with the perannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992. Also, these employees and office holders may join the PSSAP if eligible to do so. The bill will also amend the productivity benefit act to ensure that the act does not apply in respect of PSSAP members who have chosen to cease PSSAP membership in accordance with the choice of fund arrangements. The Governor General Act 1974 and the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 are being amended as a consequence of the closure of the productivity benefit act to new employees. The amendments provide safety net superannuation guarantee minimum support to the Governor General and judges in rare circumstances where the benefit otherwise payable would be less than the superannuation guarantee minimum employer superannuation. The bill makes minor amendments to the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 and to the trust deed PSS. These amendments concern the establishment of the PSSAP as a separate scheme. The Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990 also includes minor amendments to allow Australian government employers to provide employees with choice of funds. I commend the bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Snowdon) adjourned. NA Corporations and Financial Services Committee Report

Speaker: Ms BURKE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee Suon Corporations and Financial Services, I present the committee's report entitled Statutory oversight of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, together with the evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper

Speaker: Ms BURKE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-I rise to welcome the report and wish to start by thanking most sincerely the staff of our committee, who go to great lengths to make these events worthwhile-particularly Dr Anthony Marcinac, Mr Alex Olah, Ms Loes Slatery and Ms Laurie Cassidy. I want to thank also the chairman of ASIC, Mr Jeffrey Lucy, in his first statutory oversight appearance since his appointment as chairman, and his team for their cooperation in this hearing process. Several issues of currency were pursued during the hearing and, for the sake of the record, I would like to go to a few today. In this all-party process, where we get the benefit of parliament in action, it was reassuring to see all committee members seeking assurances from ASIC in respect of the FSR legislation and whether the process is achieving the desired outcomes of protecting consumers at a reasonable cost to business. ASIC was of the view that FSR was a success, as no-one was criticising the underlying philosophy and what it delivers-the criticism is about piles of paper and mechanical aspects. Whilst there is no need to throw the baby out with the bathwater, I would beg to differ that the FSR is not a success just yet. The principle is correct but, if the process is flawed, no-one is benefiting. Consumers feel more confused than ever and participants are bogged down by paperwork, and that was not the intention. There is a need for greater transparency in this process. Quoting from the committee's transcript: Our very public position is that we have disappointed with the length. That is in reference to the length of paperwork. It continues: It is just a question of how you encourage or enforce shortness. I am not sure that we can encourage or enforce shortness, but we do need to recommend the relevant authorities, who currently are in consultation, to refine the disclosure and licensing regime to make the FSR process work as it was intended. The refinements to the FSR proposals paper have just been released by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, and the committee will watch with interest to see whether this process can iron out the ‘bugs' in the system. The ability to get FSR right is critical as we embark on the brave new world of choice of superlegislation has just been introduced by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Certainly there is a need for greater clarity for consumers going into this hugely complex and, in some respects, frightening area of choice. Given the very low take-up of choice of investment, there does appear to be a huge leap to actually achieving choice of fund. The start date of 1 July is bearing down upon us rapidly and there is very little in the way of education for consumers and, in some respects more importantly, for employers, who will bear the burden of implementing this regime. Employees will be looking for advice and the boss will probably be the first choice. Employers need greater protection from the claim of giving bad or biased advice. ASIC conceded that it is concerned there is a need for greater education of and protection for consumers and that greater disclosure is required. Again I quote from the transcript of the hearing: So, yes, we are concerned. It is a very large been amount of money and a large number of consumers are involved in it, but we think we have the programs in place to deal with it, along with other agencies. … … … Certainly we are going to be undertaking surveillance to try to monitor [the introduction]. The issue of third-line enforcing was also canvassed during the hearing. Whilst ASIC rightly pointed out that this is an area for the ACCC, it was monitoring the area of disclosure-and, again, the committee will monitor this area with interest-particularly to ensure that the concerns of small business are not realised. There was great discussion about enforcement activities that ASIC is currently undertaking. Regarding enforcement activities and specifically the prosecution of HIH executives, the committee called on ASIC for an explanation of the prosecution strategy and process for determining which charges would be pursued and which would not. Chairman Lucy preferred to defer discussions in these matters until after sentencing of the HIH directors concerned. Sentences for Rodney Adler and Ray Williams have now been handed down. The committee reserved the right to call on ASIC to explain its strategy in selecting which charges would be pursued and which would be dropped. While Labor members understand that prosecutorial procedures demand an interpretation of the facts at hand and assessment of the most prudent prosecution strategy, the public have the right to understand these procedures and trade-offs that are made, in the event that we are faced with another multibillion-dollar collapse in the future. Whilst these two individuals have gone to jail, many consumers out there still bear the brunt of this collapse. These issues will be taken up initially in the budget estimates hearings, but the committee has reserved the right to call ASIC at a later date, necessary. I was very pleased to see that ASIC did agree that there was need to enforce the law at hand so that we do not see a collapse of this nature again. The committee went into detail in respect of CLERP 9. Chairman Lucy noted a difference of view with the government on the issue of independence and conflicts of interest regarding market analysts. This is still an area of concern for Labor members of the committee. Despite the government's preference for a statement of potential conflicts of interest by analysts, not all conflicts can be mitigated in this manner. ASIC's original submission to Treasury on CLERP 9 in 2003 took a robust view in relation to the types of conflicts that need to be disclosed and those that need to be prohibited. In its submission, ASIC advised that effective regulation of analysts required an integral legislative approach. ASIC suggested that such an approach would comprise three elements: restrictions or prohibitions on certain conduct that cannot otherwise be effectively regulated by an obligation to manage or disclose conflicts; a general obligation on licensees to manage other conflicts when providing research reports; and a specific obligation on licensees to disclose conflicts of interests when providing research reports. ASIC's submission also raised concerns about whether disclosure was sufficient in relation to certain conflicts. ASIC said that, in its view: ... at a fundamental level, the Act needs to prohibit certain activities of analysts where conflicts cannot be effectively managed, and disclosure of such conflicts is not sufficient to mitigate consumer ... risk. ASIC went on to recommend that the following activities be prohibited in the act: trading by an analyst or researcher in products that are the subject of a current research report, if within a set period, and trading by an analyst or its individual researchers against a recommendation or opinion contained in a current research report. Labor's view remains that the government's response has been inadequate to these issues and that ASIC was well placed to interpret requirements for change in this area. Like ASIC, Labor's view is that, while conflict management is an often-expressed desire by management and staff of analyst organisations, its effective implementation has been found wanting. In a recent newspaper report it was stated: ASIC found that a voluntary code of conduct introduced by the industry's peak body in 2002 had “not been adopted as uniformly and closely as is appropriate”. We are concerned that while conflict management is an often-expressed aspiration of both management and staff, the effective implementation of such an ideal has been found to be disappointing ... I commend the report to the House. NA (TEACHING PROFESSION) BILL 2004 Second Reading Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Ruddock: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: I was engaged in addressing the parliament on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Profession) Bill 2004 last night and unfortunately had to finish early to allow for the adjournment. So I am back, but the message remains the same: the government's proposal to amend the Sex Discrimination Act in the way that it proposes is, in our view-and certainly my view-unnecessary. It is a narrow-sighted action by the government, which has sought a short-term solution as a knee-jerk reaction to an issue that requires considerable consideration of the social, political and economic factors that have led to the imbalance of males in the teaching profession in the first place. It is also redundant because a satisfactory conclusion was reached with the Catholic Education Office in New South Wales as to the way in which they could deal with their proposal to have scholarships for boys-that is, by agreeing to have an equivalent number of scholarships for young women. What we have discovered as a result of the scholarships being offered is this: of the 12 scholarships, each worth $8,000 a year, that were offered to males, only six were taken up. That clearly demonstrates to me that the scholarships issue itself is not the question. It is a far deeper problem, and amending the Sex Discrimination Act in the way that is being proposed will not solve it. There are reasons why graduates, both male and female, are not presenting to enter the teaching profession through schools in the arts, science and technical fields and other areas. These are the things that the government should be addressing. Once having got them into our schools, the government should be addressing how to keep them there, with satisfying career paths to allow both them and their students to achieve their full potential in a safe, well resourced environment satisfactory for the 21st century. In my own electorate of Lingiari there are many schools, particularly in remote communities, that do not fit that bill. They are under-resourced. Physically they are an aberration, largely due to 27 years of indolence by conservative governments in the Northern Territory, and of course the kids who are subject to this indifference and indolence are the poorest students in Australia-Aboriginal kids. They are the sorts of issues that the government should be addressing. There is no shortage of goodwill among those people who are involved in the teaching profession and engaged in the classroom-let that be very clear. There was a time when males dominated the teaching profession for a range of reasons. A generation ago, female workers, including teachers, were paid less than their male counterparts. A generation ago, female teachers were expected to resign-that is, to sacrifice their career-when having a child. There are female teachers today that have had to rebuild their careers-in terms of long service, superannuation and access to promotion-after having their careers interrupted by conditions of service that certainly would not be tolerated today and were discriminatory. A generation ago, for many males teaching was an early career option. I mentioned this last night. I, along with many other people in this chamber-I am not sure how many of our generation, because there are not many of us here-entered the profession. My colleague at the table, the Attorney General, never entered the teaching profession though, and I think he is even older than me. Mr Ruddock-My father did.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: He was a good man. Mr Ruddock-I was born in Canberra, like you.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: We were very lucky. Mr Ruddock-We are the only two in this House.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: That is right. The minister reminds me that we are the only two people to have served in this parliament who were born-and in my case raised-in Canberra. That is a bit of trivia that may be ful to some student at some time in the future. Mr Ruddock-It was Ainslie infants school.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: He is a child of Ainslie infants school. I was a child of St Benedict's primary school in Narrabundah, which, by the way, has its 50th anniversary this year. Nevertheless, we entered the teaching profession because it was an opportunity. We were able to gain bonded scholarships-in my case, a New South Wales teaching service scholarship, as I mentioned last night, and later a Commonwealth scholarship. Teaching was a staging post on the way to one's preferred career, but what many people did was stay on that career path. Once they entered the teaching profession, they realised what an opportunity it was, and those who became dedicated professionals did a very good job. Of course people have moved on, and many who were once teachers are now in this place. I am not sure how many but I would suggest it is probably the most significant representation of any profession in the parliament. We always thought it used to be lawyers, but certainly when I first came here the parliament was dominated by teachers. The bonded system also meant that many talented graduates received life-challenging experience of communities different from their own-and they were not all episodes from the novel Wake in Fright. I am sure you recall that, Mr Deputy Speaker. A broad range of teachers from different social and cultural backgrounds entered our education system, bringing with them an understanding of and empathy for the students in their charge. A generation ago, schools were bulging at the seams. Career prospects for teachers were good and the supply of students meant there was a need for senior teachers, principals, student support specialuseists and education managers. Nothing has changed, except that the profile of the teaching profession is an ageing one. A young student teacher long ago could identify a career path that could be achieved within a short space of time. Now there are bottlenecks: people are finding that it is far more difficult to get promotion because people in the promotional positions are staying for longer periods. There was also an optimism that education was a pathway that, if pursued, would reap rewards, part of which was the esteem in which teachers were held within the community. Of course, those things have changed over time-critically, I think-so that teachers are not given the recognition and support of the general community that they deserve. The sad fact is that, compared with other careers, teaching is not well resourced. Hours in the classroom are very intense and the technological revolution is daily changing the role of the teacher. We know this to be the case. The skills required to be a good teacher today can often readily have a better application and be more financially rewarding-as well as socially and professionallyin another area. Rather than tinkering with the Sex Discrimination Act, this government should be more proactive in providing resources that will attract students, both male and female, to the teaching profession. This government should be ensuring that all schools have adequate facilities to serve their communities. I will give you an example, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee recently conducted hearings in my own electorate of Lingiari into Indigenous education funding. At one of the hearings, at Ross Park Primary School, which is my local primary school-my son attends that school and my partner teaches there-a parent, Matt Skoss, who is also a teacher, related to the committee how at his school last year there was an Indigenous male tutor employed under the Aboriginal Tutor Assistance Support program. It is a very important position in the school and he is a very important role model for the school. This young man enjoyed his job and was clearly a very important factor in providing guidance to young Indigenous kids, particularly the males. His support around the school was much appreciated by the other professional staff. This man had been encouraged by his principal to undertake study to become a teacher. What did the government do? They changed all the tutorial assistance arrangements so that he and many others like him had their jobs put in jeopardy. In fact, start of this year, tens if not hundreds of people like this were without a job in the education system. These were tutors who were working with the most disadvantaged and deprived students in Australia. They lost their jobs because of the idiocy of decisions taken by the government. Instead of tinkering with the Sex Discrimination Act, this government ought to be looking at the real reasons why we have a lack of males within schools-whether or not they are teachers or other role models such as tutors or tutorial assistance workers like the one I have just discussed. I might also point out that Ross Park Primary School-which I think has only one male teacher for a school of about 320 studentshas a dedicated program to working with boys. All of the staff have dedicated their time to trying to develop strategies to ensure better outcomes for boys at that school, and they are not alone. It happens in schools-I know this to be the case in my electorateright across the community. The teachers are actively engaged in addressing issues which were identified by the member for Macquarie in his contribution last night about the way in which boys are performing in schools. These are the issues that need to be addressed by the government, not this proposal to amend the Sex Discrimination Act. We need to make sure the government looks at the big picture-and not through this little divisive bill. I think this is the third time this bill has been in the parliament. Why would you do this? It is completely unnecessary and it is designed to be divisive. That is the only reason. There is absolutely no educational motive for this. As has already been evidenced by the experience of the Catholic Education Office in New South Wales, even offering the scholarships did not achieve the outcome they were after. They now acat the knowledge they have to adopt different strategies to address the sorts of issues that have spoken about in my speech this morning and last night. We need to have a holistic approach to developing professional pathways that will attract men and women into the teaching profession. We need to make sure we do this quickly, because the nation demands it.

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: I rise to speak to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Profession) Bill 2004 today because it is highly concerning to me and to my coalition colleagues that in this country the proportion of male teachers is shrinking, particularly in our primary schools. It seems that that point at least is non-controversial. At least my colleague the member for Lingiari would concede that the proportion of male teachers has shrunk. Even in the example that he has just cited, there is only one male schoolteacher in a school of 300 students. Nobody on this side of the chamber is arguing that the proposal put forward in this bill will somehow solve that problem on its own, as if this were a silver bullet which could cure all of society's issues, difficulties and challenges in education. Nobody on this side of the chamber has ever put forward that argument. We as a government are looking here to provide one sensible measure which we believe will at least help to address that problem. Only one-fifth of Australia's primary school teachers across the country are male, and I am worried that this is having a negative effect on the education of all our young people in schools, and young boys in particular. But I would hasten to add that this is not just a boys' education issue, because it is an unsustainable argument that girls would not also benefit from having an appropriate balance of male and female teachers. The reality is-and this is borne out by anybody who has been a parent or anyone who has been a schoolteacher-that both boys and girls I benefit from having a real gender balance in the teaching profession. That may be difficult to achieve, but if we do not try nothing will change. Through this bill that I speak of today, the Howard government demonstrates its commitment to addressing this gender anomaly and to ensuring that children-both boys and girls-have male as well as female role models in their school years. I am able to speak to this bill today not as an expert but from experience, as I was once a high school teacher in the Tasmanian state education system. Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, I know that you have a similar work background and perhaps, as you listen to my comments, you too might reminisce about some of the issues that we as schoolteachers have faced in the past. I will not harp on about this today, but it has to be said that public education in this country is underfunded. That is another point that is non-controversial. On our side of the chamber we continue to provide increases in real funding to education through support to all schools around Australia-public and private. Nobody on the other side of this chamber could argue with this government's record in funding public schools, public classrooms and public school teachers. We provide real funding support to the schools we do not even run. We are not embarrassed about that. We do not begrudge that funding and we do not feel that we need a gold medal for the excellent work that we have achieved-for example, the unprecedented $34 billion quadrennium funding that was passed by this parliament early this year. We asked the state and territory governments to lift their game. We asked them to substantially increase funding such that it could at least match or approach the funding increases that the federal government has offered. I think Brendan Nelson, as the Minister for Education, Science and Training, should be recognised and commended for the excellent work that he has done in raising the level of federal funding to public schools, despite what the Australian Education Union and his state Labor colleagues may taunt him with. I can recall a time as a schoolteacherbelieve this or not-when I was considered the first male role model that one young student had ever had any meaningful contact with. I will never, ever forget this young low. This boy-today he is a young manhad grown up in a single parent home. His mother had taken on that role in this particular case and he had never known a male teacher throughout all of his years in primary school. Bear in mind that I was a secondary school teacher and the child was in grade 7. He had never known his father, and his family life, if I may say, was somewhat insular. As would be expected, his sudden ongoing contact with several male teachers, such as me, in secondary school was a disaster. If I may reflect on this situation for a moment, I believe that he could not cope with not being the man about the place anymore. He could not cope with taking some direction and instruction from a man. His behaviour suffered enormously and his time in high school, I am very sad to say, was largely misspent. Of course, in a secondary school environment he was surrounded by many male teachers. The ratios there are so much different. It breaks my heart when I reflect on that young student. I do not know where he is today. I suspect he will have ongoing challenges in his life. I am not arguing that having more male teachers in his primary school would have solved or resolved all of his issues and challenges in life, but the Australian parliament should have a go. Why don't we try something that has not been tried before? Why don't we show some courage and be bold. We should have a go and try this. It cannot hurt. Providing incentives for male teachers to enter the classroom is not going to hurt anybody, but until we do this, until we at least give it a go, until we at least attempt to get through this parliament 500 new opportunities to encourage some men into the classroom, people on this side of the chamber and people on the other side of the chamber will never know whether it can work. It is therefore very important to encourage fela positive view about the role of men in the honourable profession of teaching. Again, I speak with experience when I say that teaching can be an extremely satisfying career path, with lifelong rewards. If I ever get tipped out of this place I will very favourably consider going back to the classroom. It is a great job. As a teacher you are able to play a significant and life-changing, life-affecting, life-affirming role in the lives of young people. We are there to teach them, to help them learn, to help them through difficult times, to encourage them to fulfil their potentialbecause they all have that-and to guide them in the right direction in many areas, from academic pursuits to sporting endeavours. My personal goal was always to encourage young people to engage closely with their community through community service. At this point I think it is important to make clear that teachers are not, and should not be, a substitute for parents. But they can still have an important and vital role in a child's life. Ideally, their roles should be seen as complementary to those of parents. I think we as a government and certainly as a federal parliament should recognise that, while so much more work is being placed on teachers to help in the socialisation of children, particularly where there have been issues and challenges at home, parents have the primary role in a child's life. They are, after all, the ones who love them. As much as we believe in education and the welfare of children, and as much as teachers want to see children achieve all of their potential and goals in life, they are not the ones who love them. Parents are the ones who love the children. It is the parents who make sacrifices for the welfare of their children and parents who cry from the heart for the aspirations of their children. Parents have a lifelong commitment to their children as they grow into adults and hopefully enjoy satisfying, happy and rewarding lives. The Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Profession) Bill 2004 is also a strategy to support male teachers and to address the particular education needs of boys in schools. I do not have time to go into this today, but it is something that has been recognised. The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Education and Training inquiry into the education of boys makes it clear-boys do learn differently from girls. Shock horror! None of us should be too amazed about this. It is not a discriminatory statement. We are not saying that somehow boys are inferior to girls. We are not saying that boys are better at maths and physics and that girls are better at English, social sciences and humanities. None of those statements are being made, but what I have said has to be acknowledged. People from the far Left just cannot get over the need to accept that men and women are different. Boys and girls are different too and boys and girls can learn differently. This is not about woodwork versus sewing. This is about providing a reasonable balance. It is about providing a balanced environment in which a child can learn. Our society should do all that it can to ensure that the classroom environment reflects a good balance of the complementary roles of males and females, in much the same way that healthy motherhood and fatherhood roles are the pre-eminent way to look after the needs of children in the home. Not all children can live with both their mother and their father. That is the case for so many different reasons, many of which are heart breaking and difficult, and can even be difficult to speak about. But as long as I stand in this place I will never give up the belief that this is still the ideal. It is always worth our remembering that it is the ideal to strive for, and to hold it up as such. In the lives of so many people that ideal is not possible, and we will support them. We will help them and we will not judge them. But we will not give up the notion of an important balance between male and female as being a beneficial environment in which to grow up-in the home and in the classroom. The 2003 report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Education and Training Boys-getting it right: report on the inquiry into the education of boys identified significant challenges for boys, and I would ask those few members of the opposition who are here today to hear me out. The report states: Between 1975 and 1995, the literacy achievement of fourteen year-old boys declined. In 2000, 9 per cent of boys in Year Three and 15 per cent of boys in Year Five failed to achieve minimum reading benchmarks. This compares with just 6 per cent of girls in Year Three and 10 per cent of girls in Year Five. Year 12 retention rates are 11 per cent higher for girls, driving a 6 per cent higher rate of university entry. In some cases, the Year 12 gap between boys and girls is up to 19 percentage points with girls outstripping boys in almost 90 per cent of courses. However, the real problems are at the other end of the educational spectrum. Recent research shows that, in some instances, boys represent up to two-thirds of those in the bottom quartile of school achievers. Boys represent 80 per cent of students in school disciplinary programmes, and are more likely to be involved in assault and drug related incidents. They are three times more likely to die in a motor vehicle accident, and for people aged 15-24 the rate of male suicide is five times that of the male rate. The problem is not that girls are doing better boys-it is instead that boys are not doing as well as they once did. And I add: as well as they can and should. So I ask this parliament: what are we going to do about the problem? Nobody on this side is arguing that this one bill on its own will address this problem. But if that short quote from that lengthy report does not put some fire into your belly to help to address the problems of boys and girls, but particularly boys, who are struggling in schools today, then you are blind to the reality of what is happening in Australian schools and to what is happening in the lives of young people who will grow into young men and who will, based on their life experiences and based on their missed opportunities, perpetuate some of these problems in their own families. Earlier this year I attended a presentation by boys education advocate Freerk Ykema. He is from the Netherlands and he has pioneered a learning approach which he has called ‘Rock and Water'. This is being implemented in schools around the world. It has been somewhat of an educational revolution in his own country, but more recently there has been a large take-up of the approach in New South Wales, Northern Queensland and parts of Northern Tasmania. He has a groundswell of support at the University of Newcastle. As a teacher and father of two boys, this presentation helped me to better understand this sometimes complex issue. He talks about the qualities of boys: energetic, creative, explorative and loving a challenge. Boys like rules to be fair and strict. Boys must be challenged and must be given physical challenges. He argues that boys have some difficulty in areas such as literacy, self-reflection and verbalising feelings and emotions and, therefore, it is more difficult fe- for them to learn from mistakes and, he argues, more difficult for them to find inner than direction. That is not to say, of course, that boys cannot do very well in literacy, selfreflection and verbalising their feelings and emotions, but he is arguing that it is not their impulse to achieve in those areas. To achieve in those areas they have to be challenged in the right way. Freerk Ykema also argues that society has changed, and none here would disagree with that, and is in a state of change. Women have been emancipated and traditional role patterns have changed. Increasingly, technology has meant that traditional ‘male' jobs are disappearing, and with them the male identity. Multicultural society has caused some obscurity in young people's minds about values, standards and social manners. Education has been feminised in the past 15 to 20 years, he argues. There are more female teachers, especially in primary schools. This has directly resulted in fewer male role models and more emphasis on reading, writing, reflections, conversation and communication. Sadly, it has also accidentally resulted in less understanding, respect and support for boys' qualities, which I have already described. That might sound a little controversial to somebody reading this speech in Hansard at a later time, and that might be difficult to accept for somebody hearing me say it, but before quickly judging me or Freerk Ykema on some of these points perhaps the reader or the listener should talk to a parent. In short, the outcome of much of this is that boys are missing out in many Australian schools. So often boys have been discouraged and misunderstood instead of being valued, and this has diminished even further their lower capacity to communicate their problems. So teachers have witnessed increasing disturbing behaviour. Education authorities have witnessed a decrease in the academic performance of boys. There is more violence in Australian schools and there is something of an inability of school principals to deal with that. There is more drug and alcohol abuse in our community. Boys are increasingly the victims of their own risk taking. Suicide of our boys is one of our nation's greatest shames and the harshest reality check. The University of Sydney's Dr Peter West, of whom we have heard already, has also spoken on how male teachers are different. He argues that male teachers have louder voices, are more down to earth and organise more hands-on activities for children in the classroom. This is not to say that female teachers are not effective too; of course, they are. But if the teaching profession were male dominated and only 20 per cent of primary school teachers were female, the same changes to the Sex Discrimination Act that we are debating today would still be needed-and dare I say would probably have the support of the Labor Party. The outcomes of a comprehensive review of a Tasmanian secondary school revealed that parents, teachers and students at the school identified student motivation and engagement, particularly of boys, as a significant concern. The review found that 95 per cent of all students sent to detention at time were boys from grades 7 and 8, 80 per cent of students suspended were boys, and boys were well below girls in statewide tests of literacy and numeracy. The politically-correct and left-wing set would do well to consider the serious state of play that I have described before dismissing changes to the Sex Discrimination Act. The community wants change, parents want change, and boys want and need change. I am proud to be part of the movement to begin the sorts of structural changes that are now warranted and long overdue. Why are there more female teachers in primary schools than male teachers? HREOC have something to answer for in that because, of course, when the Catholic Education Office sought to have special scholarships for male teachers they were knocked back. They were told they could only offer scholarships equally to male and female students. I have heard the Labor Party say that that is being played out. Kelvin Canavan of the Sydney Catholic Education Office has now said that he has filled all 12 positions for the female scholarships but has not even received that many applications for the male ones. Rather than the Labor Party getting away with saying that that proves their point, they ought to accept that that actually highlights the fact that the teaching profession for males is not valued by this community. We have to improve our act. It highlights the need for specific male-only teacher scholarships in places where there is a demand and a need for more male role models in schools today. I commend the bill to the House and call on the Labor Party to support it.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: The Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Profession) Bill 2004 has, of course, been before us before. Indeed lunchthe comments I have heard from the member for Bass and other members on this matter are ones that I do not necessarily disagree with. However, I think the last part of the member for Bass's comments is the critical part that should be focused on today because what we do find in this place is a common view that there needs to be more male teachers in the education system. I have not heard one member of this place indicate otherwise. The fact is, however, that this bill is not really going to solve that problem. I think the member for Denison said it best when he said that the legislation before us today proposes a solution to a question that we have already answered. I think that that is the case. To place this in some historiand, cal context, effectively what happened was that the Catholic Education Office sought to provide 12 scholarships to males only and sought an exemption from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The commission considered the application to be discriminatory and in breach of the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act and therefore suggested instead that the best approach would be to allow for 24 scholarships, 12 male-only scholarships and 12 female scholarships-in that way still providing the capacity for the Catholic Education Office to invite and fill 12 scholarships for men as future teachers. So the solution to the problem was determined by some innovative thinking by the commission and was accepted, as I understand it, by the Catholic Education Office as providing an alternative to their earlier application. Notwithstanding the fact that the problem was in effect solved in relation to this particular matter, the government continues to proceed with this bill in the belief that it is okay to turn on its head the antidiscrimination law of this land. If you are able to solve a problem without adversely affecting the antidiscrimination law of the Commonwealth, clearly that is the best approach. However, unfortunately, the government chose not to listen to the opposition on this matter back in the last term and has chosen not to listen again this week. The fact is the scholarships that have been provided for male teachers have not been filled. It is important to note that in March this year-and it may have been subsequently reported-the Australian newspaper revealed that the Catholic Education Office managed to fill only six of the 12 teaching scholarships it was offering to men. In effect, it sought an application to provide male-only scholarships, the commission provided an alternative to allow for 12 from each gender notwithstanding that, there have been only six applicants able to fill the 12 positions, leaving six vacancies in the male scholarship positions. I am not sure whether that has changed since it was reported in the media, but clearly it points to a problem that is much more complex than the government is suggesting. The government is suggesting that you can reverse years of antidiscrimination law to fix a minor matter. That is what we would be doing if we voted for this bill today. But, of course, it would not solve the problem. The parliament has considered this before, and the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Workplace Relations clearly indicated in its report entitled Boys: getting it right that the paucity of male teachers in the education system is a complex matter. Indeed, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission also reviewed this matter and made three findings. Clearly, there were more women than men primary school teachers in Australia, and the reasons for the gender imbalance were varied but included the status of teachers in the community, child protection issues and the pay and conditions of primary school teachers relative to other occupations. There are three factors that at least attempt to explain the dearth of male teachers in the education system, particularly in primary schools. They are the matters we should be dwelling on when seeking to fix this matter, and the government has failed to consider them properly. The parliament has not properly examined ways to raise the status of the profession of teaching. Most people in the community value teaching as one of the most important professions anyone could enter because of its value to society. As has often been said about teaching, it is a noble profession. To undertake the care and learning of young people in society is a very important role and should be valued as such. Over many years there has been a devaluation of the teaching profession. I am not sure whether this has been caused by the fact that teaching has been feminised-to use the term-that is, increasingly more women have taken up the teaching profession, thereby affecting the way in which teachers are remunerated. Historically, where you find an industry that predominantly employs women you will find, generally speaking, that their rates of pay when compared with the competencies, responsibilities and skills required to undertake the work are undervalued. We have seen that in nursing. If you compare the responsibilities, skills, wages, tions and career paths of nurses with other like professions where there is a larger proportion of men you will find that they have been historically undervalued. I think there has been some attempt over the last 20 years to rectify that inequity. But the fact is that when you have occupations that are primarily taken up by women, for whatever reason, it is likely that their conditions of employment and their career paths are not valued as highly as those occupations filled mainly by men. There was a time-and I think the member for Brisbane mentioned this in this debate-when women had to retire as teachers once they married. It is only a generation ago-only 30 years ago or thereaboutswhen women were forced to resign from their employment, their noble profession, in the event of marriage. Thankfully, that has altered, but clearly what has occurred is a gradual diminution in the recognition of teachers in our society. Therefore, all governments-federal and state-should be considering the ways in which we can reassert the importance of teachers in our society. The ways we could do that would clearly include reviewing pay structures and career paths and looking at the issue in a more holistic way, rather than seeking to amend antidiscrimination laws in order to provide for male-only scholarships which, as I said earlier, have not even been taken up by enough male applicants. There is clearly a problem that goes well beyond the reach of this bill. This bill is more about playing politics than developing good policy. This is about attempting to argue that the Labor Party is in some way discriminating against men. Nothing could be further from the truth. What is being proposed here would have to mean that in the teaching profession there are a multitude of men waiting at the door to be interviewed and successfully appointed as conditeachers and for some reason they are not getting the jobs-that because of their gender they are not receiving offers to be employed in schools. To seek an exemption to the Sex Discrimination Act is effectively to say that there has been some form of evidential discrimination against men in this profession. The fact is that discrimination is not being exerted by schools; there is just a dearth of interest by males in entering the profession. Other speakers have indicated the importance of finding a balance-that is, having men and women in the teaching profession. I concur; that is important. But the only way we will do that is to attack those matters that have been left unattended for many years. Of course, the member for Bass is a former teacher, and he and I probably disagree on a number of matters. But he is an example of somebody who obviously valued his teaching but chose, for whatever reason, to enter this place-as indeed have other former teachers, such as the member for Brisbane, I think, as well as other members. That might be for all sorts of reasons. Many teachers seek work outside the teaching profession, which of course is their right. Many of them are doing so because of the lack of satisfaction they get in the workplace, the stress that comes about from the lack of resources in certain schools or, as I said earlier, ing. the failure to recognise the importance and value of people in this profession. I think it is a little rich for the government to continue with a bill that for all intents and purposes is unnecessary when the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission had managed to find an innovative way to allow for 12 scholarships for men and 12 scholarships for women. After that was achieved, by amending the application made by the Catholic Education Office-and I understand that was happily accepted by that office-those 12 scholarships for males have not been filled. That clearly indicates that the problem is far more complex than the government is letting on. Instead, we are seeing the government playing politics over good policy. I oppose this bill. It is an unnecessary It does not solve the problem it seeks to solve. It is attempting to belittle the very portant history of antidiscrimination laws. The fact that the government thinks it can turn these laws on their head to solve a problem shows its lack of regard for antidiscrimination laws per se. I oppose the bill and I ask other members to do the same.

Speaker: Ms CORCORAN
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: Isaacs) (10.17 am)The Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Profession) Bill 2004 is here essentially for the third time. The bill was introduced in March 2004 and was knocked back-very sensibly, I might say-by the Senate. The bill was reintroduced in August 2004 but the proroguing of parliament for the 2004 general election meant that the bill lapsed. It is now introduced again. The purpose of the bill is to amend the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to provide a permanent exemption for the provision of gender-specific scholarships which can be offered to students in a teaching course. These scholarships must be designed to address gender imbalance in teachThe beginnings of this bill are found in the Sydney Catholic Education Office. The Sydney CEO applied for an exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act, the SDA, so that it could offer male-only scholarships to student teachers for a period of five years. The students were to be students of primary school education. While the application was for a five-year exemption, the Sydney CEO said that the provision of male-only scholarships might form part of a longer term strategy to encourage males into primary teaching. In February 2003 the president of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, HREOC, refused the Sydney CEO's application. Whilst the Sydney CEO was considering its options regarding an appeal against this bill. decision, the government launched into action and prepared this bill. The Sydney CEO im- did not ask for the bill and was in fact taken by surprise by it. The Sydney CEO and HREOC reached a solution to the Sydney CEO's problem. This has been done without any need to amend the Sex Discrimination Act, so the stated original purpose for this bill has disappeared. The fact that this bill is back indicates an agenda other than the stated one. There are those who argue that the action taken by the government when it first introduced this bill was more about an ideological debate than trying to fix the problem. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Education, Science and Training talk about the ‘zealous commitment' to the SDA of those who oppose this bill and the ‘triumph of narrow ideology over common sense'. It seems to me that there is indeed a lack of common sense in this debate, but not from this side of the House. It is worth remembering that this bill was initially introduced at a time when the then Leader of the Opposition was quite successfully making lots of good points about boys needing men around them. At that time there was an election in the wind and the Prime Minister was getting a bit rattled. These ments were making sense to the electorate, and the PM was on the back foot. This bill was essentially about deflecting the issue rather than addressing it properly. After all, as I said before, the problem has been fixed, so there is no real reason for this bill. There are actually two issues here, both of them to do with the imbalance in the numbers of male and female teachers. The first question is to decide whether or not the imbalance is actually a problem; if it is lem, then the second question is how to fix it. Some people have raised the interesting side issue of whether it would be anti affirmative action to oppose this bill. I will deal with affirmative action first and then get back to the more substantive issues. The question is sometimes put: why is it okay to have affirmative action to get women into jobs or areas where they are underrepresented but not okay to apply these principles in this case? The answer lies in why the underrepresentation exists-that is, why are men underrepresented in the teaching profession, particularly in primary teaching? HREOC makes the point that special measures are required to redress the effects of historical discrimination and/or the generally disadvantaged position of a particular gender. The commission found in this case that men had not experienced discrimination in their choices about entering or not entering the teaching profession and were not directly disadvantaged; rather, they chose not to enter the profession, for whatever reason. The point to stress is that men are choosing not to enter teaching. There is nothing stopping them from entering the profession if they choose to do so. There is no historical discrimination and there is no general disadvantage. Affirmative action is not required here. Going back to one of the main points, why com- are men not entering the profession? The reasons put forward include that teaching is not very well paid or respected, and that men are often put off by societal issues around child protection. It is interesting to note that, despite the low numbers of men in primary schools, men are overrepresented in the senior positions in these schools. The men that are in primary schools usually occupy the senior positions. How many primary schools do we know in our electorates where the a probonly man in the place is the principal? In determining the Sydney CEO's application for exemption from the SDA to allow it to offer scholarships to male students, the commission set about an inquiry. The commission made four findings of fact. The first was that there are more women than men primary school teachers in Australia. The second was that the reasons for the gender imbalance are varied, but include the status of teachers in the community, child protection issues, and the pay and conditions of primary school teachers relative to other occupations. The third was that there was insufficient evidence that the proposed scholarships would address the problem. The fourth was that there was insufficient evidence that the gender imbalance was adversely affecting children. There is no argument that there are fewer men than women in primary schools. Australian Bureau of Statistics schools data indicate that in the last 10 years the proportion of male primary school teachers declined from 25.6 per cent in 1993 to 20.9 per cent in 2003. In government schools the proportion of male primary teachers fell from 26.7 per cent in 1993 to 21.1 per cent in 2001, a decline of 5.6 per cent. The decline of male primary school teachers in non-government schools was only 1.7 per cent. Within the non-government school sector there is a significant variation in the proportion of male primary school teachers, with Catholic schools having the lowest proportion overall and independent schools the highest proportion. This phenomenon is not exclusive to Australia. In 2001, in all OECD countries for which data were available, primary school teachers were predominantly female-64 per cent or more. The other issue that is not the subject of contention is that boys are facing problems within the schooling system. The situation in Australia at the moment is that boys, particularly in adolescence, are not doing as well education, particularly in basic literacy, as they were 35 years ago. Boys are represented more than two to one in the bottom 25 per cent of performance at school. Boys are falling behind girls by some three to four percentage points in operational literacy right throughout the assessed cognitive curriculum from early primary to late secondary school. Boys represent 80 per cent of all schoolchildren in school disciplinary programs and close to 100 per cent of those expelled from school. Boys are more likely to be involved in drug related incidents and in assault and they are three times more likely to die in a motor vehicle accident and five times more likely to take their own lives. Clearly boys need help. I am convinced that boys-and indeed girls-need both male and female role models. But that is not the same thing as saying that more male teachers will fix all the probsion lems our boys are facing. Two studies undertaken by the British Office for Standards in Education were concerned with schools where the gap between the attainment of boys and girls is less than the average. The reports identified characteristics of these schools that were to do with teaching style and school culture. There was no mention of gender factors. The characteristics identified included a ‘non-macho' culture of learning where pupils benefit from a strong sense of community; where pupils feel valued by an ethos that celebrates achievement; where teachers provide prompt and detailed feedback in marking pupils' work; where pupils are set short-term tasks that can be tackled in clear stages; and where teaching is undertaken enthusiastically with a good use of humour. The office concluded from these reports that boys do well where the traditional three Rs are complemented by a fourth ‘R': respect. Last year the Australian Council for Eduin cational Research made a submission to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee's inquiry into a previous incarnation of this bill. The submission addressed the two issues I identified earlier-why the imbalance exists and whether it actually matters. The ACER noted that, whilst there are plenty of anecdotal reasons and myths as to why the gender imbalance exists in the teaching profession, there is a pressing need to know more about the attitudes of senior secondary students towards, and perceptions about, teaching as a career-particularly those of male students. The ACER also noted that the evidence available indicates that a student's general academic achievements are influenced by that student's background and intake characteristics; however, all this pales into insignificance compared with the classteacher effects, regardless of teacher gender. Another organisation to make a submisto the Senate inquiry was the Victorian Institute of Teaching. The VIT expressed deep concern about the proposal to offer scholarships-or, to use their words, ‘inequitable opportunities'-for trainee teachers. The VIT makes the point that for years teaching has been one profession where men and women are on an equal footing, at least in terms of entering the profession. This bill then would be a backward step and is not the best way of encouraging high-calibre students into teaching. A third organisation to make a submission to the Senate inquiry was the Australian lege of Educators. In their submission, the ACE said that having additional male teachers was not a key factor in achieving excellent outcomes for male or female studentsjust part of the mix. The ACE listed the indithink cators of successful schools. These indicators included strong and effective leaders, learning as a central purpose, good curriculum knowledge and other factors. None was to do with the gender of the teacher. The ACE noted that getting more men into teaching is important but that there is no short-term lution and that the long-term solution has more to do with promoting the profession holistically. The ACE added that, in pursuing a social objective to have more males working as teachers in schools, full recognition needs to be given to the achievements of female teachers who have served the teaching profession for years when, for many reasons, males have chosen not to do so. This bill will not address the social of getting more men into teaching. We need to find out why men are not attracted to teaching as a career and to address these sues. Anecdotally, we think these reasons include pay and career opportunities. In March this year the Australian reported that there were only 10 applications for the 12 male-only scholarships on offer by the Sydney CEO and that only six were taken up. To my mind, this is clear evidence that there are many more complex reasons as to why men are not going into teaching. The article quotes a male student who said that teaching is seen as a female job. He had had only one male teacher in his primary school years. This student also made the point that many men think that the salary for teaching is not enough to support a family. A female student interviewed for the article said that, in her opinion, girls are not as interested in pay as in job satisfaction and that that distinCol- guishes them from their male colleagues. In summary, this bill glosses over the real issues. It does not do anything to find out why men are not getting into teaching; it does not address some of the factors that we are acting as blocks. The bill takes the Sex Discrimination Act backwards.

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Title: SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT
text: I would normally start out by saying that I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Teaching Professo- sion) Bill 2004 but today I am more bemused than anything else. I cannot believe that the government is persisting in this debate and pressing ahead with this bill, when the premise for this bill-which was always pretty shaky, in our opinion-has now been completely stripped away. The issue with the Catholic Education Office has been satisfactorily resolved. The latest development with that issue, as my colleague the honourable issue member for Isaacs, Ms Corcoran, has just pointed out, was the report in the Australian on 15 March, the last time this bill was on is- the Notice Paper, which shows that, of the 12 male scholarships being offered by the Sydney Catholic Education Office, only six have been filled. So the argument that we have to pass this bill so that we can have all these male-only teaching scholarships has been shot down in flames. In contrast, I think of the Indigenous education bill that was debated last year. I spoke on that bill a second time at the end of last year, after the election. It was one of the bills that had been debated but had not passed into law before the dissolving of parliament in August. In that debate I remarked that I had no problem with making a second speech on Indigenous education so soon after having debated the exact same bill just a few months earlier. I thought in that case that most members would have agreed that it was a very constructive use of the parliament's time. It was an extra opportunity to raise an important issue and one that demands a great deal more attention and commitment from government than it currently enjoys. This bill comes before the parliament in similar circumstances, having been debated once before in the lead-up to the 2004 election but, unlike the Indigenous education bill, I cannot say that it is a good use of the parliament's time to debate it yet again. I am sure that all members on this side of the House who have participated in the debate have already made this point. This bill was an obvious stunt on the part of the Minister for Education, Science and Training before the election and nothing has changed. It is still a political stunt. It is a stunt because measure in the bill is not necessary since the resolution of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission case involving the Sydney Catholic Education Office. And it is a stunt because it does not address the real underlying issues and barriers that have made teaching an increasingly unattractive career choice for men over the years. As I pointed out, this was highlighted most effectively in the case of the Sydney CEO scholarships. Those scholarships have been offered but have not been taken up by the full complement of male teaching students. The government's charge against the Labor Party, and presumably against all of us who are speaking in this debate, has always been to accuse us of ignoring the needs of male students and not caring about boys' education. Just to make it clear-as I am sure all my colleagues have done before me-of course I am aware of all the evidence showing the underachievement of boys in many aspects of education and the gap that is opening up between boys' experiences in our schools and those of their female classmates. I accept the need and the responsibility for governments and education providers to act on that evidence and find effective and appropriate ways to make schools and educational programs responsive to boys and capable of bringing out the very best in them. But I do not accept the government's lazy and superficial response which pretends that a handful of male-only teaching scholarships is the answer to all the very real and multidimensional challenges facing boys in our education system today. And I do not accept the government's attempt to portray this bill as being about more male teachers and boys' education. This bill contains nothing like the comprehensive and multi-faceted policies, backed up with a serious financial commitment, that are needed to attract the highest the quality graduates-both male and femaleinto teaching and to provide those teachers with the support and encouragement they need to stay in the profession.
