People come from all over the country and, indeed, from all over the world-from rural centres and cities, from all kinds of socio-economic and political backgrounds and with all kinds of skills and interests. It is about the Australian way of life. In essence, they are places of socialisation where we mature as young adults and develop a sense of place in the nation and the world. They are places to encourage new ideas and dreams. The new ideas first hatched on these campuses will shape and develop kindred spirits and help us as a nation to mature and nurture our place in the world. Student unions are about our future leaders. Our elite athletes and artists will be covered and developed on university campuses. So I am going to vote for a wellrounded education. That is why I am pleased to oppose this bill. I do not care what university students campaign for or against. That is the nature of freedom of speech. They have campaigned against us in the past when we were in government and, when we form government in the future, without a doubt they will campaign against us again, just as they campaign against the current government. They were on the streets during the last election campaign. They have been on the streets about Iraq. I tell you what: we copped a hiding from some of those student unions about our position on Iraq too-so what? They are entitled to their view about life. It is about freedom of speech and association. Let us front up to the fact that the real debate is about allowing university students to participate in a vibrant non-academic lifein sporting clubs, in the arts, in debating and in many other social activities. Do not deny students these opportunities by being meanspirited. Encourage and cultivate them. We are all big enough to cop criticism; we cop it at home with our own kids. I have two kids at university. They certainly do not agree with me about everything, in the same way that I had debates with my father about decisions he had to make when he was in government. That is the nature of freedom of speech and we should be encouraging and fostering it. For students, campuses can be daunting. That hand of friendship through clubs and associations is important in assisting students to adapt to university and make new friends, some of which are long lasting. It is reflected on the other side of the House: many long friendships are established at university-not just in the Young Liberal club but also in sporting activities such as the rugby club at the University of Sydney. I am proud that we disachieved that, irrespective of the views on the other side of the House. Students with special needs, like single mothers, will suffer if we do not face our responsibilities to encourage and foster these services. These students rely on access to good-quality, convenient and affordable child-care services, to medical clinics, to assistance in obtaining part-time work and to assistance in finding accommodation. It is our responsibility to assist these young people. It is our responsibility to invest in their future. The Australian Labor Party, in its opposition to this bill, is not driven by ideology; we accept the role of student unions. Let them criticise the government of the day. I think it is terrific to have such a fertile bate in the Australian community. By encouraging these services we can guarantee university students a well-rounded education. Let's encourage them to fully participate in the community life of their universities. Without compulsory fees, these services will be significantly reduced and it will be harder for our young people to participate and develop themselves through university life. It is about services and facilities; it is not about ideology or a mean-spirited approach to education in Australia. I am proud to stand in opposition to this bill. We are not talking about trade unionism; we are talking about services needed by ordinary young Australian men and women, and by those who come to Australia from overseas to study, to assist them in developing and educating themselves.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: After listening to the bizarre and rambling dissertation of the member for Batman on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005, I have heard some arguments from the Labor Party that I have never heard before. Somehow mateship and friendship in Australia are totally reliant on compulsory unionism. I have never heard such a ridiculous proposition. Bizarre claims were also made about the right to protest. No-one cares about what student unions do as long as they do it without forcibly acquiring the money of every other student to do it, which seems to be the point that the previous speaker misses entirely. Whether he misses it deliberately or through utter ignorance, I fear it is the latter. This debate sums up so much about the difference between this side of the House and the other. Simple matters of freedom, choice and conscience are difficult and complicated questions for the Australian Labor Party. Mr Gavan O'Connor-What about the dethree-year-old behind barbed wire at Villawood? You talk about freedom!

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY SMITH
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: The member for Corio seeks to interject. I would have thought that he would be a secret supporter of this bill. Compulsory unionism at Melbourne university has brought forth Richard Marles, who is about to steamroll him in Corio. I would have thought that the member for Corio would have been very happy with the recent developments with Mr Landeryou-but I will come back to that later in this debate. I am very glad that the next recipient of corrupt Labor student unions is in the House to speak on this bill following me. This legislation is simply about the principle of freedom of association-the principle that students going to university should be able to choose whether they belong to an organisation or not. Through the industrial relations reform agenda of the government, we have introduced voluntary membership to unions against the wishes of those opposite. Campuses remain the last bastion of compulsory unionism. That fundamental principle, the freedom to decide whether or not to belong to a union, is one that those on this side of the House have always stood up for and will always stand up for while those on the other side of the House have always opposed it. In a choice between the right of someone to choose to belong to an organisation, the Labor Party will always subjugate that right because they will always do everything they can for their union mates. They have always been opponents of freedom of association for a number of reasons-not just philosophically but also pragmatically because they rely on the funds that compulsory membership brings. It brings a great deal of money to the Australian Labor Party, as a previous speaker, the member for Indi, pointed out. Unions contribute massive amounts to Labor coffers. Where compulsory unionism still exists it means, in frank terms, that workers have their money taken against their will. Part of that money is donated to the Australian Labor Party against the will of workers. With the opposition of the Labor Party we have forged many improvements in Australian workplaces. This bill, which deals with voluntary membership of student organisations, is not a simple or radical bill; it is a bill that simply says: if students wish to join a union they can, but they will not be forced to join a union if they do not like the services it offers; they will not be forced to join a union to fund the bizarre and wasteful excesses of student unions. Aside from addressing important issues of freedom of choice, this bill exposes another great hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party, particularly from the opposition's lead speaker, the member for Jagajaga, who has spoken today-and has bleated it persistently since this bill was first introduced-of her so-called concern for the financial burdens that students on Australian campuses face. It is beyond belief that members opposite can say on the one hand that they want to relieve financial burdens on students but, on the other, oppose a bill which will abolish the only compulsory up-front fee that is charged to all students. Unlike HECS, the fees charged by student unions must be paid in full and must be paid up-front. There is no allowance for deferred payments whatsoever. And being up-front, these fees are a far greater burden on low-income university students. On that point I want address the misrepresentation of a previous speaker by a member on the other side who said that perhaps Liberal students on campuses did not understand many of the burdens of students because they had not had part-time jobs. I can tell him that the member for Indi, whom he made that accusation about, worked part time all through her university career. I worked a night shift as a part-time cook all the way through university to fund my way through. That is precisely one of the reasons why so many students object to having their hard earned earnings taken by a student union that wastes them or, in the case of Melbourne university, goes bankrupt. By virtue of the fact that those opposite, such as the member for Corio, mentioned nothing of the excesses of student unions, I say to them: ‘You support them.' A compulsory student union has engaged in fraud and mismanagement of the highest order and members of the Labor Party are appearing before court, but the opposition comes into this House and carries on like a parrot and addresses none of those issues. I say to the people of Australia: the members opposite, by their silence, support the very fraud of those student unions that we have seen at Melbourne university. The union fees charged are grossly inequitable. They pose a barrier. We are saying that, if unions offered good services that students wanted to pay for, they would have no trouble attracting members. Those opposite fear student unions might have trouble attracting members because of the very behaviour that the member for Indi outlined in her contribution and the behaviour that I have already alluded to and will allude to further in this contribution. For decades student unions have been grossly unrepresentative of the student population. The previous speaker from the other side spoke of how healthy it is to have a debate, how healthy it is to protest. No-one cares what a student union of leftists does: no-one cares if they dye their hair green and roll down the gutters outside Melbourne university-no-one cares less. What they care about is having to fund it. Why should every student on every campus have to fund every Labor Party loop? That is the only point. If what they were protesting about were so good, people would join that union voluntarily in droves, but this is something that completely eludes those opposite. The member for Indi outlined some of the very examples of the wastefulness of student unions. She spoke of the Monash Student Association printing stickers, paid for by every student forced to belong to that union, saying: ‘Bomb the White House'. How ridiculous! Every student was forced to pay for that sticker-something those opposite, including the member for Corio through his silence, obviously support. The fact that the member for Corio is silent is something that would almost make the front page in this place. I think he is reflecting on where a former Melbourne student union president is right now. What part of Geelong is Richard Marles in as we have this debate? What part of Corio is he in? Which street is he driving down? Which factory is he recruiting members from? That is what the member for Corio is thinking. That is what he is reflecting on today as we take part in this debate. I would to say to him: think again; vote with us on this bill-it is in your own interests. The member for Indi outlined some of those examples of wastefulness. We have had recently the best one that absolutely nails the pathetic case put forward by those opposite. That is the University of New South Wales guild that actually used compulsorily acquired student funds to have a $600 prize for the campus that brought in the most protesters against this bill, so even against this bill they had to use compulsorily acquired student funds to pay for protesters. This is something you would see in the Eastern bloc. It is absolutely ridiculous but those opposite somehow manage-I do not know whether they practise in the morning putting on a straight face before they come in hereto defend this rubbish. They are more than happy to do it. These student protests are not the expression of the beliefs of students on campus. They are just a cynical attempt by student leaders to try to trick the public into believing that there is some sort of dissatisfaction on campuses with this bill. Last year the same students led protests against the government's introduction of higher education reform. They have done so in the past; they will do so again. Some of the most conclusive proof of just how biased these student unions are while not representing students is how in the last election the National Union of Students spent $250,000 of their money campaigning against the Howard government. They did not spend any money campaigning against anybody else. They just decided that with the compulsorily acquired funds they would campaign for the Labor Party, so no wonder you get those opposite defending the indefensible. The ALP claims that it supports the plight of university students, but it is happy to sit back and let $250,000 of compulsorily acquired money from students-those who work in the part-time jobs that the previous Labor speaker was talking of-just be taken away and given to the ALP. Of course you can see why they are prepared to defend the indefensible. These are the sorts of outrageous ways in which student unions on Australian campuses waste the hard earned money that they acquire from students. These are the things that Australian students are forced to fund against their will, just to to get protesters get an education. But potentially even more damning than such offensive campaigns is the serious financial mismanagement that the member for Indi spoke about that occurs with these compulsorily acquired funds. Last year we had the example-and it is very much up in lights now, and the member for Corio would be very familiar with all the principal players-of the collapse of the Melbourne university student union, with the university forced to expend hundreds of thousands of dollars in a corruption probe with concerns raised about the signing of many controversial contracts following the election of a bor Party aligned administration. Many of the wrongdoings of these characters have been exposed in great detail. We have had this cat and mouse chase with Mr Andrew Landeryou, who left the country and has come back and is now operating a web site, I believe, on which he is going to tell all on the Labor Party-so that is one to log into every day, member for Corio-about everything that has been going on in the Labor Party to do with this deal. But the bottom line is you had the member for Jagajaga worrying about student unions not existing under voluntary membership and worrying that if you actually gave people a choice they might not join. She was very worried that student unions might not succeed. With compulsory membership at Melbourne university the union collapsed! That is the absolute hypocrisy of it. I say to the member for Boothby that I am worried that they actually do not see the irony in this. If I thought they went back to their offices and thought this was a bit of a tough gig-trying to defend this indefensible, corrupt, criminal behaviour-but they would do it, that would be one thing. They are ignorant. I think they have an absolute morality gap on this sort of thing. The investigation is ongoing. We are sure that will unfold in great detail over the ing weeks and months. But what did it all mean for those students at Melbourne university, those students who paid that compulsory fee of $382? What it meant was that the union which forced them to join against their will took their money and sent itself broke. What did they get for their money? Where was this greater good that those opposite speak of? The member for Jagajaga went out of her way, as did the previous speaker, the member for Batman, to criticise the Australian Liberal Students Federation. Let me say quite openly: I was a member of the Australian Liberal Students Federation and, yes, I Lawas a president of the Melbourne University Liberal Club-and proudly so. What I say to her is that without the Australian Liberal Students Federation and the Julian Barendses and the Rohan D' Souzas of Melbourne university, this scandal would never have been uncovered. The Australian Liberal Students Federation are the only organisation that have acted in the interests of all students. Without their actions, without their investigative work, this corruption would still be going on today. So, rather than criticise them, those opposite-if they genuinely believe they have the interests of all students at heart-would be praising them. Only by passing this bill can we grant students genuine choice about whether or not they wish to join a student union. All we are saying is that we will give students the choice. They have choices everywhere else. That is a big problem for the Labor Party. The students are 18. They can choose what car they drive, they can choose where they work and they can choose what university they go to, but clearly those opposite believe, in some condescending way, that they are not capable of making a choice about whether or not to join a union. We say that if they are old enough to vote and old enough to go to a campus they can choose whether they buy a comproduct or not. They can choose whether they are going to join the union. That is what we are doing: we are giving them a choice that they should have and that they should have had years ago. Those opposite do low-income students an extraordinary disservice in failing to let them have that choice. The problem for those opposite, as I said at the start of the speech, that allowing choice and freedom of association is abhorrent to them because it would expose student unions-the sorts of people that come up through the Labor Party ranks and the sorts of people that the member for Corio is familiar with-to the reality of the outside world. The real fear is that it would force student unions to offer services students want. This was the experience in Western Australia. Those opposite do not have to fear what would happen under voluntary student unionism: you know. As the member for Indi said, it was introduced in Western Australia and none of the doomsday predictions eventuated. Student unions lowered their fees and offered better services. None of the dire predictions of the student unions or, might I say, the vice-chancellors came true. Rather, we saw what common sense would naturally predict. We saw a voluntary regime where unions could charge what they wanted. They started to provide services to students that students actually wanted and, far from reducing services, the evidence is that they increased them. They provided voluntary union guild loans, which had not previously been available, and the list goes on. None of this should be a surprise. Our modern economy-the member for Batman also tried to address this in his rambling, rolling dissertation-runs on the basis of choice. The government does not prescribe what goods consumers must buy. It allows them to make an informed decision, and that same process is needed with respect to compulsory student unionism. In concluding, this debate says a lot about the differences between this side of the House and the other. The Labor Party love to mouth words about freedom of speech and of choice and about students' rights, but the thing you can always rely on with the Labor is Party is that, if there is a choice between an individual's personal rights and the Labor Party's collective self-interest, it is always the latter that prevails. The Labor Party's primary objective is to look after themselves. That has always been the way and the students of Australia ought to know it, and they ought to know it in this debate. The Labor Party will always abandon individual interests in favour of their own collective self interest. It is a pleasure to speak in this long overdue debate. It is a pleasure to speak on it after the member for Indi, who worked so hard for voluntary student unionism in the time. I was with her on campus, and after the member for Boothby, who did the same thing in South Australia. This is a bill that should have been passed decades ago. The fact that compulsory student unionism still exists on university campuses, which hold themselves out to be bastions of freedom, is a sorry reflection not just on that collective roadblock opposite but on the university administrators and vice-chancellors who, for reasons of convenience, sit happily by as willing and meek shop stewards. This bill should be passed and should have been passed decades ago. I commend it to the House.

Speaker: Ms ANNETTE ELLIS
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I rise today in full and total opposition to the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. Members opposite have been trying to kill off student organisations in Australia for years. Anti-student organisation legislation has been moved in this place on numerous occasions and, to the credit of the senators involved, those bills received the treatment that I believe they deserved. In the past, bills like this have created a convenient opportunity for Liberal and National MPs to make anti-student union speeches safe in the knowledge that no real damage would be done. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said today. In a very short while-in fact, on 1 July-the coalition will gain control of both houses of parliament and bills like the one we are debating today will become reality. I was listening with interest to the previous speaker, the member for Casey. He said it was about time we had this debate. Let me tell him and others that I had the privilege of participating in exactly the same debate back in March 1999 in this very place. At the time, there was great consideration of a higher education amendment bill and we arguedvery strongly, I believe-to reject the bill, and it was rejected. In recalling that particular debate, I have had a little look at the Hansard of March 1999. The member for Bruce, on our side, made a great contribution to that debate at the time, and I have no hesitation in referring to it here today. I recall it for the benefit of members. I find it interesting, considering the speaker who just addressed the House and the considerations that he was putting forward. I want to refer in part, if I may, to part of the speech that the member for Bruce delivered. He was lifting these words out of a publication that had appeared some years earlier on the issue of compulsory unionism. He said that the article was not recommending the abolition of it. His quote from the article went on: ... since the various student unions do have a positive contribution to offer to student welfare and student education they should be supported by all those who profit from them. It seems reasonable that all those who do profit should make some contribution in return. The funding and therefore provision of the various student services would be impossible unless there was some requirement to pay a contribution towards them. The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes. The fact that there are some political donations made on behalf of SRCs and AUS. that may be abhorrent to some people who have contributed union fees does not mean we should therefore create a situation whereby all activities including those that are profitable to the people concerned are financially penalised by voluntary payments ... the facilities of student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions ... The member for Bruce pointed out very carefully that those words were uttered by the current Treasurer when he was in the student movement during his days at university. I think it is a good idea to remember how people can be convinced to change their minds, but one wonders how we can ever believe anybody when words like those are said so stridently. Student organisations have been a part of campus life in Australia for the better part of a century. I understand that when Bob Hawke was a student the then peak national student organisation, the National Union of Australian University Students, had Liberal Party members and Liberal Party sympathisers on the national executive. Whatever the differences between student advocates and the government of the time, until now no Australian government has had the arrogance to really seek to destroy student organisations. Now student organisations are facing extinction at the hands of a government caught up in outdated ideology. I would like to use my time here today to address some of the arguments used by the government to justify their attacks on Australian students and to talk about some of the ramifications of the passage of this bill. A common argument used by coalition MPs and right-wing commentators is that compulsory union fees are a breach of freedom of association-that is, students are somehow forced to accept the services pressed upon them by their student association. At one point someone even took that argument to the Victorian Supreme Court. Unsurprisingly, the case was rejected. The court found that if you choose to attend a university you choose to accept the conditions of enrolment at that campus, including the payment of fees to the relevant campus organisation. When people say that student organisations make an essential contribution to the university experience they are not just defending their former classmates but stating a fact recognised by the Victorian Supreme Court. Another fact ignored by the freedom of association argument is the democratic nature of student organisations. If the on a particular campus want to reduce the amount of money that each member pays, they are free to do so through their own processes. If students at the University of Canberra, for example, decide that they no longer want their own campus based organisation, there is nothing to stop them taking the decision to wind up their association. Conservative politicians love to use the word ‘freedom' when attacking student organisations because it is the only argument that sounds vaguely credible. Student organisations provide myriad services to students on campus. Members opposite try to use the political activities conducted by student organisations to support an argument in favour of destroying them. Forget for the moment that an opinionated student population could be considered a positive side effect of having a decent education system and that student politicians are democratically elected, these organisations provide much more than the political advocacy that is sometimes seen on the six o'clock news. Student organisations provide support so fundamental to campus life that it is often taken for granted by some of their members. These organisations distribute information on local transport arrangements, employment opportunities and ways of avoiding drink spiking-a terrible problem amongst the young at the moment. Counselling, and suicide and rape prevention programs are examples of services provided and paid for by student organisations. Other examples quoted by ACT universities include advice on Centrelink programs, legal advice, health advice, financial advice, rooms where young women can congregate and discuss issues, sexual harassment contact officers and self defence classes. They also provide subsidised food and coffee, and photocopying, students printing and faxing facilities. When I mention those issues, I cannot help but reflect upon the Minister for Education, Science and Training being absolutely obsessed, during the opening of this debate some weeks ago, with the price of sausage rolls. I felt that that was a bit of an insult. I am sure that the provision of services by student associations through universities in this country goes far beyond the level of the price of a sausage roll. I found that comment quite demeaning to the whole debate. Under the current system, many campus organisations provide on-campus advocacy services for students. In practice that means that if a student feels that he or she has been unfairly treated they can seek advice from their student association. Here in the ACT if a student at the University of Canberra thinks they have been discriminated against or harassed, or if they need help dealing with the university bureaucracy for any reason, their student association is there to help. They have a full-time advocacy officer employed to ensure that students' rights are maintained. Office bearers at the Australian National University Students Association earn less than the minimum wage they would receive at MCDonald's or Woolworths. Despite this, anyone who has walked through the main courtyard at ANU during their O week market day will know that the lack of remuneration has not dampened their spirits at all. They have sailing, rugby and hiking clubs. They have debating, law, literary and Baha'i societies. The lists are long but comprehensive and it is voluntary for whoever wishes to join any one of them. ANU students organise political debates between Labor and Liberal parliamentarians. Latter year students volunteer as mentors for campus newcomers and ANU Students Association representatives mediate between students and faculty representatives during disputes. To take away their student associations is to take away all these services and more. The services and advocacy provided to Canberra students by Canberra students affect the entire university experience. Attacking those organisations will deny future students the experiences enjoyed by many of the members opposite. Let us look at this in a more purely politiprotesters cal sense. In their eagerness to write off dent organisations as one-eyed, left-leaning organisations, government members are offending a great number of conservative students who will suffer alongside Labor, Greens and Democrats, and anyone else for that matter, voting students at universities. That is why I believe student organisations are finding support in some unlikely places. The Victorian state branch of The Nationals has recognised the effect this legislation will have on rural campuses and their surrounding areas, and it has rejected this legischaracter lation, comparing the collection of student union fees to government rates and taxes. Coalition members and senators from rural areas would do well to consider the contribution that regional campuses make to local economies. Student organisations provide services, infrastructure and jobs in many rural areas. As their funding is cut, so too will be the services they provide and the jobs associated with that service provision. The Nationals senator elect Barnaby Joyce was quoted in the Australian on 27 April this year, refuting previous claims that he planned to support VSU and declaring his opposition to the bill in its current form. If that report is accurate, he is to be commended for having the courage of his convictions. When the coalition government authorised Australian universities to raise HECS fees and introduce up-front fee places, many student organisations reacted by organising protests. The protest events were designed to register students' opposition to increased fees and up-front fee places and could not have endeared their organisers to the campus vicechancellors. Despite this the Group of Eight universities and the Australian ViceChancellors Committee, both populated by the same vice-chancellors who faced student just last year, have publicly destuclared their opposition to government interference in the collection of student fees. In a press release issued last July, the ViceChancellors Committee described the government's decision not to proceed with a bill remarkably similar to the one we are debating today as common sense. In a press release issued in December last year, the Chair of the Group of Eight said: Any move by the federal government to dictate the purposes for which universal student service fees may be collected and disbursed will interfere in the autonomy of universities and damage the of the cultural, social, sporting and learning environment of the university. That pretty much sums it up. Interfering with the collection of fees is an unwarranted, unwanted intrusion on the part of the federal government and will hurt the university environment in many ways. If the Minister for Education, Science and Training thinks he knows more about the value of student organisations and their contribution to daily life on campus than the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University, he is more arrogant than anyone could have guessed. The students do not want this bill, the versity vice-chancellors do not want this bill and some of the more level-headed coalition parliamentarians really and honestly do not want this bill. At the federal level this bill has failed before, and if common sense prevails it will fail again. Reference was made by the previous speaker to the situation in Western Australia. While anti-student union legislation has a habit of failing at the federal level, VSU has been tried at the state level, with disastrous results. Conservative governments in Western Australia and Victoria brought in antistudent union legislation during the 1990s and their student populations paid the price. Under VSU, Curtin University in Western Australia was forced to drastically reduce the level of support provided to students. Emergency loans, subsidised catering and rape referrals are just some of the services that were cut as a result of that policy. To their credit the Gallop and Bracks Labor governments repealed the state VSU legislation and, thanks to the support of organisations like NUS, campus organisations managed to weather that storm. Under the legislation being debated today, the attacks on student organisations will be on a national scale. There will be no support from sympathetic organisations in other states because everyone will have the same problem. Students nationwide will pay the price for coalition ideology, and the experience of going to university may never be the same. Far from being unique to Australia, universities all around the world recognise the need for student run organisations. Fees charged by Australian student unions pale in comparison with our international competitors. The highest fee charged by an Australian student organisation is between $500 and $600, which is about a quarter or a fifth uniof some of the charges faced, for example, by equivalent universities in the US. Australia has the dubious honour of being one of a very small minority of countries that questions the need for student organisations. International students contribute approximately $1.7 billion per year in tuition fees and charges, and approximately $5.9 billion per year to the Australian economy overall. In exchange for the fees charged, student associations and unions provide much needed support for international students. Moving away from home can be stressful enough for domestic students, but international students face added pressure from cultural and language barriers. Threatening the services and support provided by student organisations can only diminish the appeal of Australian university places, which is one thing that we do not want to do. If Australian campuses lose the funds provided by international students, it is unlikely, given its recent track record, that this government would cover any gap created in that way. There will be less funding available and students will suffer. The arguments put up in support of bills like this over the decades, and this matter has been debated on so many occasions in the past, are based on outdated ideology and without any vision for the future of education in Australia. We have heard members opposite try in vain to argue that universal student unionism is in violation of the principles of freedom, and we have heard members give their highly unflattering opinions of student politicians. What we have not heard is how this legislation is going to help students or contribute to a positive university experience. I have outlined just a few of the positive contributions that student organisations currently make to campus life, but nobody has said how taking away services and removing student advocates is going to help anyone. I have never heard of a student wishing away the information or advocacy services provided by their student association or union. I would be surprised to find a student who did not appreciate advice from an older student mentor, and I would be shocked to meet a student who received help from their student association with a successful academic appeal yet remained ungrateful. I refuse to believe that the Liberal and National caucuses are united behind such a bloody-minded attack, and I call on members opposite to exercise their consciences and vote down this bill. I would like to again refer to words the current Treasurer wrote some years ago. He said: The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes. The fact that there are some political tions made on behalf of SRCs and AUS that may be abhorrent to some people who have contributed union fees does not mean we should therefore create a situation whereby all activities including those that are profitable to the people concerned are financially penalised by voluntary payments. I could not have put it better myself. I suggest that those opposite make the time to reflect upon the words of the current Treasurer when he was giving that opinion some years ago now on the right to have voluntary union fees in universities in Australia.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: There is a romantic nostalgia today about university unions. I think of that scene in the 1981 British film Chariots of Fire where a young Harold Abrahams is at his university orientation. He avoids the spruiker of the Fabian Society; he joins the Gilbert and Sullivan Society; and he is of course the star recruit of the Cambridge Athletics Club. But this picture of extramural life has about as much to do with Australian students today as other aspects of the University of Cambridge in the 1920s. When universities were almost exclusively populated by full-time undergraduate students fresh out of school, compulsory union fees were accepted as a part of university life. However, today, higher education has changed dramatically so that there are more part-time, mature age, external and overseas students than ever before. The Dawkins reforms of the late 1980s mean that many universities are now spread over a number of campuses and students on outlying campuses cannot possibly access the main union building or union services. People now take crossinstitutional courses, and they often get a bill for union fees from two universities. Is it really fair to slug an external student a fee for union services when they may never donavisit the campus? At Deakin University, for example-in the member for Corio's electorate, perhaps-37 per cent of students are external students. Most of them will never visit Geelong-not to study, anyway. They cannot possibly access the university services. Is it really appropriate to expect a mature age student or a part-time student who attends lectures in the evenings after work to pay for services when they have no time or interest in participating in campus life? Like many in this debate, especially the previous speakers the member for Indi and the member for Casey, I can claim a long standing interest in the issue of university union fees and the campaign for VSU. It was the issue which drew me into politics. As President of the Adelaide Medical Students Society in 1989, I was able to achieve half union fees for clinical year, off-campus, medical, dental and agricultural science students at the University of Adelaide. I did it with the support of the University of Adelaide Liberal Club and the students themselves. The argument then, as now, was that students who cannot possibly use the services should not have to pay for them. We have all heard of the financial problems that university unions will have under VSU. Currently, there is obviously a bit of fat in the system. Last year, during the sixweek period of the federal election campaign, the National Union of Students spent over $75,000 on broadcasting electoral advertisements, over $40,000 on publishing these electoral advertisements, nearly $50,000 on producing campaign material like how-to-vote cards, posters or pamphlets and just under $90,000 on direct mailing. That is over a quarter of a million dollars of students' money being used in a federal election campaign. This is hardly core business of student unions. This is hardly student services. To emphasise the point, the mailing address for the electoral return for the National Union of Students is care of Trades Hall, Victoria. Locally, in my electorate of Boothby, students' funds are being funnelled to party political campaigns. I have received a leaked memo which showed that the Union Board of Flinders University on Monday, 7 June last year resolved: That the Union, jointly with SAFU (Students Association of Flinders University), request SOC (Student Organisation Committee) use its small projects fund to contribute $8,000 to a cross camseat. pus 2004 Federal Election material fund with information on the importance of preferencing the Coalition last. That resolution was moved by a staff member of a South Australian Labor senator. When you can do things like that, when you have control of student funds, it takes the work out of fundraising. This shows that student unions have been captured by the Labor Party and they are not representative of the general student body which funds their activities. Last year's minutes of the National Union of Students SA executive show that they established a federal election committee, and the SA President, Ms Meagan Hackett said: I am asking each campus student union and /or association to donate money to this campaign, to ensure that education remains one of the most topical election issues … According to Ms Hackett: The Flinders University Union has so far committed $6000 while UniSA will donate between $3000-6000 as well. Committee members included representatives from all three universities. I also have a copy of a letter which was sent out to voters in the seat of Hindmarsh from the National Union of Students. Far from making education topical, the direct mail campaign was directed against the Liberal candidate in Hindmarsh and urged voters: ‘Don't let Simon Birmingham and John Howard take away our future.' Mr Albanese-That's what you're doing. Very perceptive.
