Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: Unions will have fewer resources for these sorts of activities under voluntary student unionism. But I have a sneaking feeling that, faced with a choice between counselling and paying money to the federal election campaign, student funds are still going to find their way into the eral election campaigns in 2007, in 2010, in 2013 and so on. Since the introduction of the tertiary education charge in 1986 and the introduction of HECS by the Hawke Labor government in 1988, student rallies have traditionally been against fees. The recent National Day of Action was the first student march I have ever seen which was in favour of fees. Not surprisingly, it was very poorly attended. The member for Casey talked of the University of New South Wales offering students funds to actually encourage people to bring along people to the march. In George Orwell's Animal Farm, the revolutionary call to arms for the animals was ‘Four legs good, two legs bad'. It seems that the message from recent student marches has been ‘Union fees good, HECS fees bad'. In other words, whether the fees are good ones or bad ones all depends on who receives them. A dollar from a student going towards their HECS fees is bad. A dollar from a student going towards their union fees is very good. This point is emphasised by the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Committee's report into the 1999 VSU legislation, which gave the bill a resounding recommendation. That committee suggested that opponents of voluntary student unionism then, as they are now, were guided by their vested interests in union administration and party affiliated student bodies. Australia is a nation leading the world in developing a cultural environment free of discrimination. This freedom encompasses diversity on all grounds, including race, sex and colour. However, discrimination on one ground still exists within our education system-the compulsory nature of membership of a student union. Membership of any assofedciation should be the free choice of every individualMr Albanese-Like the AMA.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: The Australian Medical Association is a voluntary association. Its has as its members about 50 per cent of medical practitioners. You would be much closer to the Doctors Reform Society of Australia. Membership of any association should be the free choice of any individual, but this is critical when the organisation is, by its very nature, political. Despite claims to the contrary, students have no option to conscientiously object to the activities of their student unions. They cannot withdraw. As it stands, all students are required to be members of their respective student unions on campus. For example, I know personally of a student who was threatened with disenrolment and forfeiture of his place in law for not paying his union fees. There is compulsion at the university level; there is compulsion at a national level. Each university is associated with the National Union of Students, and they pay a fee of $5 per student to the NUS for each enrolled student, regardless of whether they wish to join. This is the same NUS who spent $250,000 of student money in last year's federal election campaign. One argument we often hear in favour of compulsion involves comparing a union fee to government taxation. I am sorry to break the news, but university unions are not a fourth level of government in Australia. Freedom of association is a fundamental right, one which is implicit in our Australian way of life and guaranteed to us under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The rest of the Australian community is bound by these logical and rational principles of dom of association. In some areas, such as workplace relations, this House has itself legislated to enact such freedoms-for example, the 1996 Workplace Relations Act, which gave the idea of freedom of association the status of a basic human right in tralian law. Another argument which supports voluntary membership relates to the activities of the unions. The forced contributions of students often go to blatantly political causes. Historically, the Australian Union of Students supported extremely divisive issues. In the 1970s, the AUS supported radical proPalestinian Liberation Organisation resolutions. They passed resolutions saying that marriage was a form of prostitution. They gave money to the Shining Path guerrilla movement in South America. We had compulsory student unionism but, led by people like the Treasurer and the health minister, campuses disaffiliated from the Australian Union of Students because they were so far removed from and so unrepresentative of the opinions of students. At a campus level, the problem is that these political escapades on issues which divide popular opinion are just not the domain of organisations whose members are not members of their own free will. The successor of the Australian Union of Students, the National Union of Students, regularly engages in similar escapades, as election return I have previously mentioned demonstrates. As an example, recently the National Union of Students spent compulsorily acquired student funds on protesting the government's immigration policy at the Baxter detention centre, regardless of whether students agreed. Individual student unions or guilds have been associated with protests that have left substantial damage bills, such as the free- $11,000-worth of damage inflicted on the Murdoch University Senate building. The president of that student guild, who was in his 12th year of study at the time, claimed that the protest was not organised by the guild, yet he conceded that both he and other Ausguild members were present. This is not the type of behaviour which should be subsidised by students at large who have no choice about whether they pay for it. In Victoria, as we have heard, the Melbourne University Student Union was wound up early last year. This happened under the compulsory unionism regime. After the VSU legislation comes into force from 1 January next year, if a university union fails because of mismanagement or some of the misadventures we have seen, we will be told: ‘It is all due to VSU.' None of it will be due to the responsibility of the administration. But the Melbourne University Student Union was wound up after a student housing lease deal went bad, exposing the union to losses of up to $40 million. Several matters were referred to the police, and the liquidator recommended investigation into corporate governance issues such as falsification of records and conflicts of interest. Their financial records show expenses such as $213,000 on legal fees in 2002. Furthermore, in the Age of 26 July 2003, Darren Ray, the 2002 union president, admitted winning his election by the ‘proving that the union paid for an axe used in a rampage by a minority of students who wrecked the office of the Vice-Chancellor.' These are not the expenses that give value to students for their union fees. Forced membership has created a culture of economic inefficiency. Voluntary student unionism will unleash powerful market forces on the student services sector, which will provide better, more efficient, greater value services to students at a lower cost. Currently, under the climate of coercion, students pay substantial up-front union fees of around $300 but up to $500 in New South Wales and receive no choice in the services provided to them. Quite obviously, different students place different demands on student services. Some students are heavy users of all facilities, while some students use few or none of the services on offer. Clearly, this cross-subsidy is inefficient. The end result substantial overuse of many services, many of them subsidised out of students' pockets. This is the classical free rider problem in economics. Free market forces are the key to efficiency, greater welfare and a more sensible allocation of available resources to students. A user-pays system will always be more efficient in the long run and will be more beneficial to students, despite the protests of those who gain the most from a system which compulsorily acquires fees and allocates benefits. If a group of people wish to pool some sources to collectively partake of products and services then there should be no legislative proscription on this. Similarly, there should be no legislation which allows the compulsion of people to be such members. Historically the idea of a voluntary communal effort has worked quite well. Although largely forgotten, in the early 20th century friendly societies provided excellent service under this concept. People would of their own volition undertake to be a member of a friendly society, pay a fee and gain the benefits of communal products and services in certain areas. In Australia this was once well evidenced by friendly societies facilitating the delivery of medical and pharmaceutical services. They were the catalyst for networks of regional hospitals and friendly society pharmacies. The key difference is that it was voluntary. You opted to join; you had a choice. Importantly, only the people who derived value from such services were members. Those who did not wish to participate were never compelled to do so. That is very different from the situation with student unions today. I would like to address the issue of sport. It is an issue close to my own heart. All of my family have had a big involvement in university sport-intervarsity and so on. Voluntary student unionism should not be an is obstacle to playing sport. It should not be an obstacle to successful university games, successful intervarsity competitions or even Australia's gold medal haul at the Olympic Games. There are really two issues here: participation and resources. Does Kevan Gosper really believe that our budding Olympians will only participate in university sport if they are compelled to do so? Does he really believe that these people who are so motivated that they will go all the way to the pinnacle of their sport need to be compelled to join their union and that otherwise they will re- spend university life sitting on the lawns drinking a milkshake? Come on! That is the East German, Soviet style model of mass participation. On the issue of resources, we need to remember that at many universities the sporting grounds are provided by the university, not by the union. Moreover, most university sporting clubs compete in competitions against non-university clubs whose only revenue is the funds they raise themselves. The issue of child care is emotive. In my state of South Australia there are three university child-care centres. At the University of Adelaide over 58 per cent of all child-care places are used by staff. Only 16 per cent are used by students of the university. Why should the general student population subsidise child care for staff of the university? The Waite Campus Children's Centre on the Urrbrae campus of the University of Adelaide in my electorate is situated at a facility that is primarily research based. As such, only a very small group of undergraduate students has ever used child care at this ity. In 2003 the University of Adelaide embarked on a misadventure of allocating childcare places to be managed by the student union. They actually lost the government benefits for these places, which was a disaster for students and showed why unions should not politicise child care. Child care is an important issue. It should not be addressed through compulsory student unionism. We have allocated over $8 billion over the next four years for the child-care benefit and the Child Care Support Program. The government recognises child care as an important issue, and the suggestion that only university unions can have a real effect on the affordability, availability and quality of child care is preposterous. It is time to subject student unions to the same conditions under which individuals, small businesses and corporations in Australia have thrivedthe strongest force for efficiency and best practice that the world has ever known, the dual concepts of freedom and choice. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I am extremely happy to oppose the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. I am even happier to do so, having heard the first three speakers on the government side, and I am very pleased that it will be opposed at every stage of its passage by the Labor caucus. I had no idea just how precious the people on the other side of the House are. I did not realise that they spent all of their university education time fighting battles in student politics and apparently losing. According to them, those past defeats have to be put right, and every university in the country is going to feel it. They just do not get it. Universities are not there just to turn out units of production facilfor the corporations they speak about so wisely. Universities are not there just to turn out Liberal politicians. Universities remain, and have to remain, the guardians of knowledge, the bastions of freedom of ideas and freedom of ideals. They have that purpose and they must retain it. This is just one piece of legislation in a suite of legislation that basically wants to diminish and undo the roles that universities have taken on, roles that Australians are rightly proud of. Our universities have been incubators of ideas and knowledge. We are not a huge country; we do not have great population size and we will never have market size or proximity to bigger markets. We have always had to compete on knowledge, on our cleverness, and unfortunately under the Howard government cleverness is something that is not nurtured. It is something the government want to diminish on all fronts, and I guess this bill is just another of those fronts. This bill seeks to prohibit higher education providers from requiring students to join associations or to pay fees on enrolment that do not relate directly to their courses. In other words, universities cannot assist student organisations to collect those compulsory fees so that they can provide important services and amenities. Interestingly, not surprisingly, if those universities breach this legislation in any way they will be fined to the tune of $100 per student. Just imagineand I am sure Lord Nelson imagines this all the time-if universities were to fail this ideological impost of his, the government would be able to rip out another $5 billion from university funding. That is some stick, but that is what is happening. This government's long standing ideological obsession with student organisations over the past 25 years is well known. It rests on some ability to say that this is another form of political unionism. Antiunionism is something, but it is also anti-intellectualism worse kind. It opposes freedom of ideas and freedom of expression of ideals that run counter to its rather limited set of ideals and ideas, which are, of course, user pays, survival of the fittest and move delivery of every government service to its private sector mates. This legislation is just another attempt to bully universities and students into this government's miserable agenda. It has an appalling record in higher education. This is now the fourth attempt by this government to ban automatic membership of student organisations, having had its legislation knocked back in 1999, 2001 and 2003. But it keeps trying. This latest move comes in the wake of the government winning a majority in the Senate to take effect after July this year. Here we have a government drunk on powerpretty drunk this week, I would have thought, if the corridors of power are any guide-determined to flex those unchecked muscles by bullying universities and students into submission. It is working on its hit list. It is payback time. Look out Australiastudents are first. This government tries to hide its dogged pursuit of student organisations under the guise of this wonderful word ‘choice'freedom of choice-arguing that universal membership of student organisations compromises freedom and civil liberties. It is an infringement, it says, of the freedom of association. Individual choice is an important part of democracy, but the whole plank of civilised society rests on a simple principle: individuals all contributing so that the whole may benefit. Democracy comes with responsibility for all. That is what student unionism implies. It says that you have a responsibility to help others. It is a pretty simple principle. Fortunately in Australia. I think it is one most Australians are proud of. But we have to move to a new way of of the thinking, apparently. The Liberal government's thinking is: survival of the richest. It is some sort of new approach to Darwinian processes. I reckon it would make a good PhD topic, actually. It was the survival of the fittest. Now it is the survival of the offspring of the most wealthy-a new selection process put in place by the Howard government. Silencing dissent is another goal. This legislation certainly is an attempt to silence student organisations, because they have been successful in highlighting the antistudent, antieducation and antiknowledge policies of the Howard government. Students dared to criticise the Howard government's massive HECS hikes. No wonder. I despair when I think of when my daughter will be able to get around to having children. She has to pay that HECS debt back. She has to work, as she did throughout her studies as well. This bill is political retribution against student organisations that have opposed decisions made by the Howard government to cut billions of dollars from university funding, to double the HECS fees over the past eight years, to allow increases up to a further 25 per cent, which 30 universities, I think, have taken on, and to allow the student to staff ratio to increase by more than 30 per cent. These policies have allowed universities to enrol students paying $100,000 and up to $200,000 in some universities while students with better marks miss out on places and to slug students with bigger HECS debts, adding to the $11 billion of already-owed HECS debts. But the obsession goes on. It has been going on for a quarter of a century, so I guess we have to see it through. Young Liberal students apparently could not get the numbers on campus, so they have asked their parliamentary mates now to force their will upon students. Current membership arrangements are not, as it is claimed by the Liberal Party, an infringement of the freedom of association. That has been tested by High Court cases and by the ACCC, but that is not good enough for the government. This legislation, they think, will achieve a great deal. Fortunately the Group of Eightthe AVCC-similarly noted their disappointment that the minister and the government have chosen to ignore their strong support for a compulsory service fee. They argued that to introduce this new legislation on the premise that these fees represent the last bastion of compulsory unionism is akin to using an elephant to squash an ant. Students fees fund much more than a small number of elected representatives. Penalising universities that seek to levy a compulsory fee for health services, for example, will be a watershed in the history of higher education and may forever change the sense of campus community that has a long and proud tradition in this country. I congratulate the universities. When they are under extreme pressure to deliver financial imperatives imposed by this government and to deliver an agenda that I know many of them find unpalatable they show some courage. I am pleased to say that those sentiments were endorsed recently by University of Newcastle Vice-Chancellor Professor Nick Saunders, who also stated on the public record that voluntary student unionism would result in a depletion of services and facilities for students on campus. Heaven help us at Newcastle University, because he knows our university cannot pick up the bill for those services. Most people, with the exception apparently of those sitting opposite, understand that student organisations make a valuable contribution to university life and provide vital services and support. Those services include child care, free employment services, advocacy and welfare services, free legal advice, health services, interest-free loans, subsidised catering and facilities and also services that help students stay at university and finish their degrees. But student associations do have a very important role, more so today because universities have changed under this government. We see higher student-staff ratios, more online courses, tutorials with over 100 students in them and lecturers being required to take on greater course loads and administrative duties, while still desperately trying to maintain their research presence and outcomes. Those things have had a big impact on universities. Student associations now take on more dispute resolution, conflict resolution, students who have to appeal against grades, failure of the university to perhaps recognise students' special needs, harassment cases and intimidation claims. Those are the sorts of things that student unions also provide. I am proud that one of my daughters was president of a student union. I know what hard work she did. I also know that the work was very challenging. For her to represent students to the university council and university senior staff was very difficult. But that work has to be done, and those are some of the important services that student associations provide. I have heard this government say, ‘Why should poorer students have to pay compulsory student fees?' I am really sick of the reverse classism that those opposite use. This paternal benevolence and patronisation of lower income families really gets my blood boiling. The Minister for Education, Science and Training says ‘Why should boilermakers pay for the sons and daughters of lawyers to go to university?' It is because they want their sons and daughters to go to university too. Get real! Our country has been built on each generation aiming higher and improving its outcomes through knowledge and training. I find the minister's comment offensive in every way. At the University of Newcastle there are many students who are the first in their family to go to university. It remains a university where the majority of students still come from families that have not had that experience. They need these services more. They rely very much on support from student organisations. It provides the orientation and support that these students-and, as the member for Boothby pointed out, the increasing number of overseas students who now attend universities-need. Let me say something about those overseas students: the University of Newcastle would love to have more international students, but the reality is that it is very hard international students. Many of them are also working. Some at the University of Newcastle are spending half of their day driving to and from Sydney to work and then trying to fit in their studies. It is a reality that it is harder for students in regional universities: the labour markets are thinner. Remember that over 50 per cent of students at universities like the University of Newcastle now are part-timers. Many are part-timers because they are out trying to work for a living and to pay their HECS fees. It is just an appalling situation. But student organisations do create the vibrant campus life that makes universities the interesting and exciting places they should be. Student organisations are also part of making a university degree a fulfilling experience and a more holistic one, which, I really believe, turns out better young Australians. So, sorry, Minister, your unrelenting attacks on student organisations do threaten to change so much more than ‘the price of a sausage roll'. But we are not surprised you continue to patronise the Australian people and trivialise universities. I have not seen any aromatherapy or belly dancing courses lately, but apparently the Minister for Education, Science and Training has. He gets around, that's for sure. That brings me to regional universities. Regional universities really do know that student unions are part of the whole fabric of our community. The services that they provide are important to strengthening our community. In particular, we have heard about sporting facilities. Newcastle University Sport, NUSport, for example, was recently awarded the Newcastle City Council's commitment to participation award for their contribution to sport in the whole Hunter region. I have taken representation from them that the delivery of their services to the university for and to the region will be seriously compromised if this legislation passes. I do not think this government has much idea of just how universities are woven into regional economies. One result of this legislation will be rather savage cuts to student sports organisations. Scholarships will be cut, subsidies to sporting clubs that promote fitness and participation certainly will be cut and some facilities will be closed forever. Let us be realistic: student facilities provided for universities do benefit the whole region, as regions do not then have to provide all of them. It is a shared responsibility, and it is one that has worked very well. The University of Newcastle is facing some financial problems. We are doing it tough. We have had $120 million in funding ripped out of our university since this government came to office, and we have had a period of direct assault on our university. The outcome, no matter what, is that 450 jobs will have to be shed. It is proposed that they be shed over one year. Why not do it over three years? We just do not have the money. It is time that the government took seriously the problems at the University of Newcastle and supported its call for some financial assistance that would allow it to phase in that restructure over three years and not over one year, thereby alleviating considerable pain to a regional economy. The University of Newcastle is not alone in its struggle to survive financially. RMIT and the University of Western Sydney are also posting deficits. Yes, it is hard to suddenly change the whole culture to respond to financial accounting standards. Deputy Speaker Baldwin knows that there are some rather major government departments struggling at the moment to reach acceptable financial accounting standards. But the root cause of our problems is definitely a fall in government funding. The federal government used to contribute 90 per cent of university revenues 25 years ago. Now it contributes only 40 per cent. Such savage cuts to funding and subsequent cuts to staff numbers have had an enormous impact on the University of Newcastle. At a community meeting in Newcastle last Saturday, 7 May, organised by students, it was resolved to put the following demands to the federal government: one, that the government does not pass voluntary student unionism legislation; two, that the government funding to tertiary public education be reinstated to the 1996 level so that excessive job and course cuts need not occur at the University of Newcastle; and, three, that the universpin-off sity's regional status be reinstated. We have got a problem with regional status. We are not allowed to have it; apparently we are not entitled to it. Wollongong is, and we are pleased for Wollongong, but we are also desperate in our region to make sure that those community based and regional programs that enable students to have a second chance and gain access to university will be funded. We actually have the highest number of second chance programs in the country. We provide more of those opportunity programs. We also provide courses from New England across to the coast, up to Port Macquarie and down to the Central Coast; but, no, we are not regional apparently. We have a proud history at the University of Newcastle, and it is one the House deserves to be reminded of. We are No. 9 on the research table. We are a university that has one of the best medical faculties in the country. We have some extremely wonderful and successful relationships with the community-Hunter Medical Research Institute; Newcastle Legal Centre; ResTech, a research and development partnership with Ampcontrol; Family Action Centre's Engaging Fathers program-and the university's Professor Graeme Jameson has now been made a laureate professor. He is one of the top 10 researchers in the world. We are a highachieving university and we are proud of our students and staff. We are proud of their achievements now and we want that to continue. That is why we oppose this legislation. At the heart of this is the real agenda of this government. This legislation is not just an attack on students and an attack on unionism or associations; it compounds the onslaught by this government on higher education. It is an onslaught that will be felt in my region very sorely with the loss of 450 jobs, with a of another 150 jobs. Five hundred jobs in a year? The university is going to be hit hard. Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, those people come from your electorate as well as my electorate. I ask you, on the record, to make sure that you ask the Prime Minister and the Minister for Education, Science and Training to look favourably on our regional economy, on our knowledge infrastructure and certainly on our university. This legislation is anti freedom of thought. It is an attack on ideas and ideals. It attempts to erase the dissenting voices of students, those critical minds and critical voices that we need. When I say critical they are critical of us here; they are critical of everyone and everything to some extent. That is part of the role of learning. Learning is about improving, understanding, testing and finding new ways. That is how the solutions to the problems of now and the problems of the future are found. I oppose this legislation. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SECKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: What a very interesting speech we have just heard from the member for Newcastle. She has come up with an answer that I do not think any survey in the world's or in Australia's history has ever come up with: students are only studying part time because they have to work part time to pay off their HECS fees. For a start, they would not be earning enough working part time to pay off HECS fees, so it is an amazing claim to make in the first place. In actual fact, they are probably working part time to pay off their compulsory student union fees-not their HECS fees. What an amazing claim made by the member for Newcastle, who is not staying around to hear the object of ridicule. The member for Newcastle seems to think that this argument is about attacking unions, or even attacking student associations, when it is nothing of the sort. The whole basis of this legislation freedom of speech, freedom of action and freedom of association. The member for Newcastle, in her feeble rebuttal of these core rights, seems to think that students have a responsibility to compulsorily support each other, even if they cannot afford it. We know that many of them cannot afford those few hundred dollars that they need to pay for those compulsory student fees. I rise today to give my support to the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. In seeking to amend the Higher Education Support Act, the government is looking to afford university students the same rights that they enjoy outside the university environment inside the university environment. These amendments will ensure that from 2006 students in Australia are not forced to become members of a student association or to pay fees for nonacademic student services. Compulsory student unionism has been an issue of concern for the Liberal Party for some 25 years. The Labor Party will claim that this is just another bone for Liberal students and their supporters and that we are opposed to compulsory student unionism purely because of the word ‘union'. As I said before, it is not about unions or student associations; it is about compulsion. Just as we, on this side, do not like to see compulsory unionism out there in the normal work force, we do not like to see it inside universities either. History and common sense show this is not the case. The Liberal Party has been continually fighting for VSU-that is, voluntary student unionism-and will not stop fighting for it until we can guarantee students the freedoms enjoyed by the rest of Australian society. VSU first emerged as a policy of the Liberal government during Malcolm Fraser's time as Prime Minister. Although it was not put to the House, it planted the seed and we is have seen Liberals, Liberal students and the general student population across the nation lobbying for VSU ever since. Early in the first term of the Howard government, the coalition floated VSU legislation. It was hotly contested by the National Union of Students and the Labor Party, who were unable to see the benefits VSU would deliver to the student population. It was subsequently rejected by the upper house, to the dismay of many students and Liberals nationwide. We are back here in 2005 fighting for VSU because we believe students are capable of making decisions for themselves. We are not opposed to compulsory student unionism because of the word ‘union'; we are opposed to it because of the word ‘compulsory'. Compulsory unionism in the workplace is all but gone. With the workplace relations amendments before the House this week, the underhanded, devious compulsory unionism we have been witnessing through the charging of bargaining agents fees to non-union members will also be a thing of the past. I had the pleasure to speak on that in the House yesterday. However, apparently our higher education facilities-those institutions that house our future professionals, academics, tradespeople and leaders-believe that they should have the right to force free-thinking individuals to join a union. These institutions are where young Australians develop their moral, ethical and personal values systems. I ask: just what are we teaching them through compulsory student unionism? Those on the other side of the House will argue that we are trying to rid universities of unions, that we are trying to prevent students from having a voice at university. This could not be further from the truth. We have no problem with university unions. What we have a problem with is students being forced to join university unions. We want to give students a choice on whether or not they join a union. University unions as they presently operate do not represent the student body at large. Student elections generally have a dismal voting turnout, which means that the student council represents a very small percentage of the student population. Further to this, there is very little consultation with the studentsany action is usually the decision of the student council alone. In my opinion the lack of support shown for student elections is the student body speaking up. They are saying: ‘We don't care about the student union. We consider it irrelevant to our studies and we consider it irrelevant to our daily lives.' If majority of students feel like this-and we know they do; just look at how many vote in the student elections-why should they be forced to pay a fee for representation that they do not need, want or use? At the moment the policy of our higher education institutions can only be described as ‘no union fee, no education'. Currently Australian students are unable to enrol in their university course unless they pay a union fee of anything between $100 and $600. Enrolment is completely dependent on a student's ability to pay this fee. What choice do they have? Furthermore, if they do not pay this exorbitant fee, some universities block their students from accessing their results, from using the library and from graduating. A student can be 100 per cent dedicated to their studies and achieve excellent results, and yet the student union will stand in their path and say they are not eligible to graduate until they cough up their money. Perhaps I am a little too matter-of-fact about these things, but I would have assumed that if you have done the hard yards you deserve the reward at the end regardless of whether or not you choose, or in many cases are financially able, to pay excessive union fees. I had the same experience myself. When I went to university as a mature age student in 1990 to do my economics and politics degree, the first thing I found out was that if I did not pay the student union fee I would not be able to graduate, I would not get my results and therefore I would be wasting my time. Can anyone say how that is fair? I do not think anyone could possibly suggest to anyone that that is fair. The fact that I would not have had access to those results I think is just one of those crazy suggestions that have been put out there to enforce people to join their unions. The Labor Party's key argument for opposing the higher education support amend the ment bill 2005 is that it will cause vital student services, clubs and societies to fold, destroying vibrant university life. This is absolute rubbish. I would reason that if the services, clubs and societies in question are important to the student body then they will be supported and they will remain. What is wrong with the students paying their subs for these groups by choice, just as they would if they were members of any other group outside university? When I was at university I played cricket for my local team, for my local town. That is where I actually paid my subs. But I still had to support the university cricket team, even though there was no way that I was going to be playing for the university cricket team. So I was actually paying two lots of subs but playing for only one group. There are many students in that situation; and others do not have the time. When I went to university I did a full-time course in two days. I was there every minute of the day, basically, doing my studies. I did not have time to spend, even to join the Liberal club, believe it or not. I did not have time to spend at the bar, play sport or to take up all the other services. So I did not feel the need to actually pay for them. But if I had used them. I would have been quite happy to pay, just as anyone else does in normal life. If they require a service it will be supported either by those who choose to join student organisations or by those who pay for the service they require. Those organisations that do a decent job in representing students' interests will have student support. What these amendments will mean is that by 2006 student organisations will no longer be able to rely on union funding-they will have to function in the real world. What a better way to teach young people. They will need to attract members by offering students something they want, enjoy and need. Students will voluntarily support these organisations and they will thrive if they are doing their job. This change will benefit the students. As we saw in Western Australian universities, under VSU services became more focused on meeting student needs and less focused on meeting union needs. More importantly, perhaps, is the fact that at present there are many students at university who do not and cannot access the services offered by student unions, as in my own case. I know that when I was at university as a full-time and part-time student I did not have a minute in a day to spend enjoying the services provided by my hard-earned dollars. I, like so many other students, had many commitments outside the university. I was serving in local government, running my farm and trying to spend time with my family as well. So I did not have time to use those services, and I certainly was not an orphan in that regard. I have spoken to a lot of young people from my electorate of Barker, which is a rural and regional electorate. Almost without to fail, they have expressed their annoyance at being forced to pay union fees for services they cannot use. Some of these young people are doing it tough. In order to further their education and study at university they need to move to Adelaide or, in some instances, interstate. They have to pay for rent, they have to pay for food and they have to pay for all their other associated living expenses. To do this, many students need to work in part-time jobs or cut back to part-time university hours-although not, as the member for Newcastle suggested, to pay off their HECS fees, which they would not have earned enough to pay in the first place. Those who have full-time university contact hours have to rely on Youth Allowance or the support of their parents. When do these students get to use the services provided by their unions? They do not. But at South Australian based universities they are still expected to pay between $273 and $362 in student union fees. To a student on Youth Allowance living away from home, that is a lot of money. Unlike our taxation system, the amount you pay has absolutely nothing to do with the amount you earn or your ability to pay. The Labor Party is also running the line that VSU will mean the end of political activism. It should be obvious that compulsory funds are not all that is needed to make political activism possible. Where there are passionate, strong-minded people there will be activism. Just as political parties, community groups and lobbyists manage to carry out their political activities without compulsory funds, so too will university groups. However, VSU will give these university based groups a focus. It will cause them to focus more carefully on campus-specific issues-issues that are of far greater benefit to the student population as a whole than some of the issues being pushed by unions today. We are bringing in VSU through these amendments because it is clear that compulsory student unionism is a violation of students' rights to freedom of association. In the themselves. Workplace Relations Act 1996 the government gave expression to this freedom as a basic human right. The Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 will simply bring higher education into line with the rest of Australian society. There is absolutely no reason students should not be afforded this basic freedom. Not only is freedom of association a right upheld by this government; it is a part of accepted international law. Article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states: Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association. No one may be compelled to belong to an association. That is really quite a simple statement, and gets straight to the heart of why we need to put an end to compulsory student unionism: compulsory student unionism is a violation of human rights. Apparently, though, students should not be given the freedom to associate as they choose. Apparently, the Labor Party does not think our students are capable of making their own decisions. I find this incredibly bizarre given that in the eyes of the law we consider them capable and responsible for their own actions. They have the right to vote in federal, state and local government elections, they make decisions every day in relation to their lives outside of higher education and they are able to raise and support families. Yet the Labor Party say that they do not know what is best for them. They say that student unions are best able to determine what is best for students. I say that is absolute rubbish. It has been proven time and time again by the decisions students make outside the university that students are more than capable of deciding what is best for However, I believe there is another reason the Labor Party so strongly supports compulsory student unionism, and it has to do with money and power. We are all aware that the National Union of Students, the peak body of student unions, openly admits to being a supporter, both financially and politically, of the Australian Labor Party. It is in the ALP's best interest to support causes put forward by their financiers, without so much as a second thought for those the causes will impact on. We see this in the ALP's relationship with trade unions. Services are important, but there are many things which are union funded that cannot be used by the average student. The Labor Party and the student unions are not telling us that these student union fees which are ‘only in it place to provide support and services to students' are the same fees that pay for the facilities, air travel and allowances of union officers. I am afraid I fail to see how that can be of benefit to the student population in general. It would seem that, if you are not a member of this exclusive little club, if you do not spend every waking hour at university or if you are a part-time or external student, you will benefit very little, if at all, from ting your hard-earned cash into your student union. We are putting this bill forward to ensure that universities can no longer charge students for these non-academic services, and the student population will thank us. Importantly, the amendments to the higher education bill also include mandatory penalties for breaching the government's VSU policy. As we can well appreciate, it is pointless for the government to put forward this bill for the benefit of students without including measures to ensure that the changes are upheld by higher education institutions. There is nothing ambiguous about the changes or the penalties that will come into effect in 2006. There is no reason that higher education providers will be unable to act in accordance with the new amendments and, as such, the consequences for non-compliance are not discretionary-providers will comply or they will be penalised. I am very proud of this government's commitment to freedom of association and the commitment of the Prime Minister, John Howard, and the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, to voluntary student unionism. These amendments will give students these basic rights within higher education institutions and will allow them to enjoy simple freedoms. I only hope the Labor Party can look past politics, power and money and do what is best for our students.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question putis to the Prime Minister. Why couldn't the government find Ms Vivian Solon for two years, given she is still with the Catholic nuns she was handed over to on her second day in the Philippines after being deported? Does the Prime Minister agree with the statement of Father Mike Duffin, the Catholic missionary who found her, that ‘if the government says they don't know where she is, it's a bit hard to believe'?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Clearly, the circumstances of this case, on the available information, appear very sad and it will be a matter of sorrow and regret that this lady, who appears to be an Australian citizen, has been deported. I can report that discussions are currently under way with the person in the Philippines, involving the Australian consulgeneral, and offers, if it is her wish, to return to Australia with government support have been made. In the meantime, as the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has indicated, this matter has been  results of that inquiry, not only in relation to this issue but also in relation to Cornelia Rau, are available, the government will then consider what further steps should be taken in what appears on the face of it to be a very sad and unhappy circumstance. Budget 2005-06

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer advise the House how hard working Australian families will benefit from this budget? Are there any alternative proposals?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Paterson for his questions and I can advise the House that hard working Australian families will benefit from this budget when income tax cuts are passed through this parliament. Income tax cuts are due to come into effect for every Australian income tax payer on 1 July 2005. Thresholds will be changed at the upper end; rates will be cut at the lower end. In order to get those income tax cuts in place by 1 July 2005, legislation has to pass the House of Representatives and the Senate to enable the Commissioner of Taxation to publish the schedule so that employers know how much to take out and know to take out less after 1 July 2005. I am asked whether there are any alternative proposals. Apparently the Leader of the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party are going to vote against these income tax cuts. If they are able to vote against these income tax cuts, they have the capacity to delay an income tax cut to every Australian taxpayer. I am very confident that, when the new Senate assembles after 1 July, the new Senate will pass this law. They will not defeat this income tax cut. What they are able, at most, to do is to delay this income tax If you ever wanted any evidence at all that Labor stands for higher taxes, you are getting it from the Leader of the Opposition now. I am pleased to see that not everybody in the Labor Party supports the Leader of the Opposition in his tactic of opposing income tax cuts. According to the Australian Financial Review today, one member of the Labor Party described this tactic as insane. According to the article ‘Labor divided over tax cuts' in today's Australian, one long-serving Labor MP has said, ‘We've blown our brains out.' Mr Laurie Ferguson was interviewed on the way into the parliament today and was asked these questions: JOURNALIST: Should Kim Beazley be opposing the Government's proposed tax cuts …? LAURIE FERGUSON: I think Kim and Wayne Swan will be handling that. JOURNALIST: What do you think though? LAURIE FERGUSON: They will be handling it ... JOURNALIST: Do you think you are setting yourself up for a political death? LAURIE FERGUSON: I think they are handling it ... They are handling it. That is precisely the problem: they are handling it. The income tax cuts have been supported by Geoff Gallop, the Premier of Western Australia, who in fact said that these cuts could only be introduced because of the good work of the Western Australian people. They have been welcomed by Kevin Foley, the Labor Treasurer of South Australia. According to the ABC radio in the Northern Territory, Clare Martin has told Labor's two Northern Territory members not to oppose the cuts. ‘That is the federal budget, and I would not be opposing tax cuts,' Clare Martin said. If the two Labor members from the Territory do not oppose the tax cuts that bill cut. can go through the Senate, Australians can have the tax cuts that they deserve and they ought to be delivered on 1 July. Mental Health Services: Detention Centres

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that nine expert mental health groups, including the Royal Australian and New Zealand colleges of psychiatrists and general practitioners, have today issued a plea for the government to establish an independent mental health panel to assess and monitor the mental health care provided at all detention centres? Is the Prime Minister aware that Labor has called for mental health services in detention centres to be provided by independent professional practitioners for more than three years? Will the Prime Minister now act on this expert advice and finally implement Labor's plan?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I understand and respect the comments that are made by mental health experts. We always take them very carefully into account. I have indicated, in relation to both the Cornelia Rau incident and the latest case that was the subject of the first question asked by the Leader of the Opposition, that we first must establish the facts of what occurred. When we have the results of that inquiry the government will then be in a position to decide whether further examinations, further inquiries or further investigations are needed. I can assure the House that the government take these issues very seriously and we are as concerned as other Australians are to ensure that, first of all, we get to the tom of what exactly happened in both cases. Then we will be in a more soundly based position to take decisions on action for the future. Employment

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer outline to the House the results of the April labour force survey? What do these figures indicate about the strength of the Australian economy?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Bass for his question. The monthly labour force figures for April were released today and they showed that employment increased by 6,900 people in April. More importantly, they showed that the number of full-time jobs in April increased by 39,100 and that was offset by a decrease in part-time positions of 32,200. The consequence is that the unemployment rate remains at the lowest level in 28 years, at 5.1 per cent. More than that, this is the 21st consecutive month that unemployment has been below six per cent and the fifth consecutive month that it has been at 5.1 per cent. More important than that, the participation ratethat is, the participation in the work forceis at the highest level on record, at 64.5 per cent. Since this government was elected in March 1996, 1.6 million new jobs have been created in Australia. There are more Australians in work than ever before. The participation rate is the highest recorded. Now is the time to reform the welfare system to encourage more people into the work force. People never had a better chance of getting a job in the last 28 years than they had in the month of April in 2005. This indicates that the Australian economy continues to grow. There are still further reforms that have to be put in place to improve its capacity. But I think all botAustralians today will welcome the fact that job creation has been strong and unemployment low in the month of April. Immigration

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister concur with the comment made by his Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs in Senate question time: ‘The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs does an excellent job'? Does the Prime Minister believe that deporting a mentally ill Australian citizen, engaging in a two-year cover-up of this and then failing to find the deported citizen should be described as ‘an excellent job'? Will the Prime Minister now concede that a royal commission must be called?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: In relation to the government's response to this matter, I can only repeat what I said in the answers I gave to the honourable gentleman's first two questions. As to what the minister said, I would like to see the context of her remarks before responding explicitly to the question of the Leader of the Opposition, except to say this: generally speaking, the department, as all departments do, works very hard for the elected government of the day. As to the particular circumstances of this case and the Rau case, I refer the honourable gentleman to the answer I gave to his first two questions. Budget 2005-06

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the Deputy Prime Minister advise the House of the benefits for regional and rural Australians of reforms introduced by this government? Are there any alternative approaches?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. There is no doubt that the seven million Australians who do not live in the major centres of the country, those who live in regional Australia, benefit from the government's tax reforms, presumed only, of course, that they are passed. They will give real cash-in-hand benefits to people in regional Australia and that will benefit average everyday workers in regional Australia-farm labourers, carpenters and electricians. I can provide an example-a butcher from the electorate of Groom. He has been in contact with my office. This butcher is not a wealthy Australian and he does not purport to be. He has a wife and two young kids and he works 40 hours during the week at a normal rate of $22 an hour, for a package of about $45,000 a year. But he is trying to get ahead and he has been doing a bit of overtime on Saturdays. He noted that he is basically on 30c in the dollar now, which is a lot better than what he was on under Labor, when he was paying 43c in the dollar on the old scales back in 1999. He also goes on to say, ‘I hear all this talk about the proposed changes only being worth $6 a week to me.' He says: ‘They're not; they're worth $31 a week to me. They are really worth having. They will make a difference and I would very much like to have those tax cuts.' I suspect that story is being told all over regional Australia as people shake their heads in absolute and total disbelief and, I would think, total bewilderment at the proposal by those opposite to oppose these measures. Indeed, I think country people everywhere will be wondering whether there is anything that is good for regional Australians that the Labor Party are actually prepared to support. Is there anything at all? They oppose not only the tax cuts; they oppose Roads to Recovery, they oppose Regional Partnerships and they oppose Sustainable Regions. They oppose everything. There is a very interesting question that must be asked of some particular members in will this place. There are not many regional members in the federal parliament from the Australian Labor Party. But there are some: the member for Capricornia, the member for Hunter, the member for Richmond, the member for Ballarat and the member for Lingiari. The questions that have to be asked are: will they all be in here tonight, which way will they vote and will they then go home and explain to their constituents that they opposed tax cuts for workers in regional Australia? In particular, it has to be asked whether the member for Lingiari will personally explain to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Clare Martin, why he opposed her recommendation that they get on with the job and pass the tax cuts. Budget 2005-06

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister and it concerns his 16th budget. Can the Prime Minister confirm that for a family with a $200,000 mortgage the latest rise in interest rates will cost an additional $32 a month, $8 a month more than the tax cut your 16th budget gives to average-income earners?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I can certainly confirm to the Leader of the Opposition that the family he referred to is more than $500 a month better off as a result of the lower interest rates under this government. I am very happy to confirm that. I can also confirm that that particular family will be better off as a result of the tax cuts that the Leader of the Opposition is trying to block. I am not surprised, at this question time, by the sombre demeanour of those who sit behind the Leader of the Opposition-they are more attentive than usual to their electorate correspondence during question time-or by the restrained enthusiasm they have demonstrated as the Leader of the Opposition has asked his question. I think that one of the more amusing press statements on the budget was one that came out this morning from my friend the prospective leader of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Bill Shorten. He endorsed our policy in black-and-white when he said: The top marginal income tax rate thresholds should be raised to create a competitive tax system. He put out a statement yesterday saying that the AWU rejects the Prime Minister's budget claims. That is a pretty extraordinary example. All I can conclude is that on the subject of taxation relief, given what Mr Shorten said, he has already as a prospective leader of the Labor Party learnt something from the current leader of the Labor Party, and that is the capacity to walk both sides of the street on the one issue. Economy  is to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House of action the government is taking to further the international competitiveness of the Australian economy? How does this help Australia's exporters?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Forrest for his question. Coming from Western Australia, he knows how important it is to have a very strong domestic economy as a platform for Australia's exporters. To make the most of global market opportunities we have to work off a strong economic base in Australia, and that has been the absolute focus of our government since 1996. In this year's budget we continued our commitment to strong, sustainable growth that provides further opportunities for Australia's exporters to benefit from a strong economy. It is a budget that delivers an $8.9 billion surplus; it forecasts three per cent growth in the GDP; it forecasts a seven per cent increase in export volumes-not values, but volumes; and it also delivers about $1.8 billion worth of tax relief to enhance the competitiveness of Australian businesses-in particular, Australian export businesses-including the abolition of the three per cent concessional tariff on imported business inputs. The budget also delivers $21.7 billion worth of personal income tax cuts to help create a more competitive fair, productive and work force. These reforms build on previous reforms that we have introduced. We need to recall the tax reform package that also delivered a $3½ billion tax benefit to exports. You would recall, Mr Speaker, that in the tax reform package we took $3½ billion worth of embedded wholesale sales tax burden off the back of our exports. You would also recall that back then those measures were opposed all the way by the Labor Party and by the Leader of the Opposition in his previous incarnation. Ultimately they were passed and, of course, we know the results have been significantly beneficial to Australia's export industries. We get a sense of deja vu this week. This government is proposing significant tax cuts to improve the competitiveness of Australia and, again, they are being opposed by the Leader of the Opposition in his latest incarnation. He will never learn. We have continued to prove the benefits of a strong economy for Australia's exporters-a strong, competitive and efficient economic base to compete in the global marketplace. This budget is all about taking that further and doing more. But, shamefully, the Leader of the Opposition is going to continue to oppose these measures, as he has done for years and years and years. I believe we will ultimately win this debate. The Australian people want these tax cuts delivered. There are many members of the Labor Party backbench who also want them. There was an article in the Daily Telegraph headed ‘Kamikaze Kim: Labor blocks cuts'. There was an article in the Australian in which there was a comment from a Labor Party MP who is obviously a former union official. The article states: One critic of the decision said Labor was likely to cop a backlash from middle Australia. “I was a union official for many years,” the MP said. “You don't knock back a pay rise.” I think the millions of Australian workers who want this pay rise would agree with him and would want the opposition to support the government in delivering these tax cuts.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Why does the government

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I want the organ grinder. Why does the government oppose an increase in the minimum wage from $12 to $13 an hour for an employee on $24,000 a year while at the same time supporting a tax cut of $65 a week for an employee on $120,000 a year?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am delighted that the member for Lilley has asked me a question about real wage increases. It gives me an opportunity to compare the performance of the Australian Labor Party when it was in office with the performance of this government. I will come back to the minimum wage case in a moment. The record will show that, in the 13 years of Labor government, real wages in this country rose by 2.9 per cent. That same record will show that in the nine years of the coalition government real wages have risen in this country by no less than 14 per cent. When I opened the successful campaign for the election of the member for Greenway in the last federal election, I had the great pleasure to say that the proudest boast I could make to the people of Western Sydney was that under this government we had delivered lower unemployment, lower taxation and lower interest rates but higher real wages. That is the record of this government. As to minimum wage cases, the member for Lilley will, I am sure, be aware that the government has always argued a fair and reasonable position at minimum wage cases. We have never taken the view that there is never a case for some increase in the minimum wage. What matters to Australian workers is what they actually get, and what Wages they have got under this government is manifestly more generous than what they ever got under you. Budget 2005-06

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister advise the House of measures in the budget which improve the health of Indigenous Australians?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Pearce for her question. She has shown a long-term commitment to Indigenous health. I can take this opportunity to reassure her and all members of the House that overall this has been a good budget for health, with 98 separate measures and $3.3 billion worth of additional spending over the forward estimates period. Importantly, there is $170 million more for Indigenous health. That is important and necessary because, quite tragically, Indigenous people have a life expectancy some 20 years below that of the wider Australian community. In particular, there is $40 million more the Primary Health Care Access Program. That should mean four new clinics in Indigenous communities and an additional 50 health care workers, doctors and nurses. There is an additional $102 million for the Healthy for Life program. That should mean an additional 200 health professionals in Indigenous health clinics around the country, particularly targeting child and maternal health and chronic disease management. And there is $9 million to supply unsniffable petrol to an additional 23 Indigenous communities. Overall, Indigenous-specific health spending will be 21 per cent more next year than this year. Indigenous-specific health spending is up. Since 1996, it has more than doubled in real terms. I should take this chance to mention that Indigenous health has been a particular interest of the retiring president of the AMA, Dr Bill Glasson. I want to express in this place my appreciation of the leadership that he has shown over the last two years.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is also to the Prime Minister. Why since 1996 has the government opposed, in total, minimum wage increases of $44 a week or $2,300 a year for an employee on $24,000 when it now proposes a tax cut of $65 a week, over $4,000 a year, for an employee on $120,000 a year?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The national wage case positions that have been taken by the government have been based on its assessment of what is good for the economy and good for the employees of this country. Even for the member for Perth, the evidence is on display today: the lowest unemployment rate in 28 years. How can any Labor spokesman on workplace relations have the hide to ask questions on things like that when, under this for government, not only has unemployment fallen but real wages have risen? This government, the Howard government, is not only the best friend that Medicare has ever had; the Howard government is the best friend that the workers of Australia have ever had. We have delivered. We have delivered jobs to Australian workers. We have delivered tax cuts to Australian workers, and we want to deliver more, but you are trying to stop us. We have delivered lower interest rates to Australian workers. We have delivered a future to Australian workers that was never even dreamed of under the former Labor government. We will continue to take approaches to the management of the national economy that are designed to promote fair outcomes for lowand middle-income earners. I refer the member for Perth to the recent research of NATSEM which showed that, under the tax and payments policies of this government, the bottom 60 per cent of Australian families have been left in a much betWages ter position. When you compare every group, you find that they were better off under the policies of this government than they had been under the policies of the former government. Of all the things this government has achieved, there is nothing I am more proud of than the fact that the average worker has been looked after. The average Australian worker is better off. That is why those workers voted in their thousands against the Australian Labor Party at the last election. It will always be the commitment of this government that we look after the interests of the working men and women of Australia. Budget 2005-06

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House how Australia's national security is being strengthened by measures in the 2005-06 budget?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Herbert for the question and for the interest he has in security measures. I note that for his constituents in Townsville this is a particularly significant issue. This budget is yet another example of the determination of the government to continue to enhance the security of our nation and of the Australian people. We have provided over $67 million over four years to develop biometrics for border control, to provide Australians with highly secure and reliable passports. Australian passports will be leaders in the world. We have provided nearly $100 million over four years for security enhancement to our embassies, bringing our total commitment across all agencies for that particular purpose since 2002 to around $1 billion. Obviously, the government places the highest priority on the safety of the thousands of Australian and foreign visitors to our missions abroad, as well as the safety of the people who work in those missions. Indeed, the security measures we had put in place at the Jakarta embassy saved many lives in September last year, when that embassy was bombed. We are also providing in the budget a further $22 million over four years to the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, ASIS, to boost the collection of intelligence on the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and also to ensure that Australia can play a significant part in the strategy of our allies and our friends, particularly in the region, to encourage joint action against international proliferation activities. We have also provided $9 million over four years to ASIS as part of an additional package of $40 million to a range of agencies-which will be coordinated by my department-to boost regional cooperation in the fight against terrorism. I note that since 1995-96 this government has increased expenditure on the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and lifted it up to be an organisation we can be proud of, representing and promoting the interests of Australia. We have increased spending by 130 per cent in real terms. We do take its work very seriously. It is worth noting that, since financial year 2001-02, the government has committed over $5.5 billion to national security issues. This budget should remind Australians that this is a government that is determined to take the fight to its enemies. Budget 2005-06

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Can the Attorney advise the House of the governIt ment's commitment to bring about generational changes to the family law system? Can the Attorney also outline measures contained in the budget to assist families with relationship difficulties before and after separation?

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting Ms Gillard-You're the man to know about generational change!

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I also know about the value of experience. I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question. I know that, as a new member, he has a very real interest in the plight of Australian families. He seems to be more aware than members opposite of the very significant investment in the family law system contained in the budget-almost $400 million committed over four years. It will create a new system, a new culture; it will help hundreds of thousands of families through relationship difficulties. It is comprehensive and it is targeted at every stage of relationships: pre-marriage, with counselling and educational services; early intervention, with over 100 services to keep families together by helping them to resolve difficulties before they become insurmountable; and immediately after separation, with $188 million in family relationship centres to help separating families before conflict becomes entrenched. For when contact arrangements break down, it quadruples contact orders-programs to help separated parents where conflict is entrenched. There are also 30 new children's contact servicessafe houses for handing over children The important changes that are contained here will also help people resolve their disputes before having to involve the courts of Australia. It is an area in which there is too much litigation and not enough mediation. We want to change the culture of family separations. We want to stop people fighting in the courtrooms instead of sitting down and working these issues through. The major initiative here is the network of 65 new and innovative family relationship centres, which will be the front door to the new family law system. It has associated with it a number of other significant benefits: an outreach program for servicing rural families, some for the first time; a national family telephone advice line; and family resource centres will be established, not only in capital cities but also in major regional centres. These measures have been very warmly welcomed. The major organisations involved in dealing with family relationshipsCatholic Welfare Australia, Family Services Australia and Relationships Australiayesterday put out a statement congratulating the government on its commitment to supporting family relationships. I want to quote people from two of those organisations. Frank Quinlan, Executive Director of Catholic Welfare Australia, said: We support a less adversarial Family Law System and the Family Relationships Centres proposal seems to go a long way towards meeting this aim whilst ensuring the children involved are protected. Children's welfare must be paramount Sarah Lees, National Manager of Family Services Australia, said: This is the outcome we have been looking for. For years the industry has been speaking as one voice, the voice of the child and of the family. This budget is an indication that we have been listened to and Australian families have been listened to ... Budget 2005-06

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for La Trobe. We are glad he is here; he is a very strong member for that wonderful part of the eastern outskirts of Melbourne. I have been out there. I have seen how effectively he is working with his local community, and we want him to keep it up too. Well done to you. The budget, he will be pleased to know, delivers all of the government's election commitments extremely well. In fact, $1.4 billion in new initiatives will provide for skills needs. It is the biggest ever commitment to the vocational and technical education sector by any government. In total the Howard government's 10th budget delivers $10.1 billion over the next four years. The government is offering more than $4.9 billion to the state governments of Australia, provided they are effective in the use of their funding for the institutes of TAFE and, of course, private training providers. We want to see a change to the system. We have another 116,400 places on offer at the moment and we want to make certain it is no longer simply the doctors and lawyers of Australia that can travel from one state to another and practise their professions. We would actually like to see the plumbers and the electricians being able to do the same thing. It is ridiculous: if you are a hairdresser trained in Queensland today, you are not allowed to cut hair in New South Wales. Can you believe that? It has only been in recent months that a hairdresser trained in Victoria has been able to cut hair in New South Wales, provided they are over the age of 21. Can you believe that?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: They are in areas with skills needs all around Australia. You know what, the member for Grayndler reminds me that the Labor Party offered zero dollars over zero years for the same sort of approach. Budget 2005-06 Miss JACKIE KELLY (2.48 pm)-My question is addressed to the Minister for Workforce Participation. Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
