This government knows that people who are coming off welfare and into work and who do have a work capacity lead much better and more fulfilling lives, not just for them but for their parents. It is part of the reason, of course, that in this country we have an unemployment rate at a 27-year low. The Howard government is investing almost $400 million in helping parents back into the work force, which includes 137,000 employment preparation places. We are helping people through the Job Network system by providing training and support to those who most need it. In the budget this week, this government announced that people with disabilities will be the beneficiaries of an investment of $555 million to help them get back into the work force, with over 100,000 places in employment services for job seekers with disabilities, including over 20,000 places for disability open employment services. The very long-term unemployed are also beneficiaries of this government's program, with over $360 million provided to help the long-term unemployed back into work. As the Prime Minister said earlier in question time, this government is a great friend of those people who are looking for work, and will provide them with the opportunities. Budget 2005-06

Speaker: Mr BAIRD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Ageing. Would the minister advise the House of the support the government is providing for senior Australians in the 2005 budget?

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Cook for his question and note his interest in these matters. The Australian government recognises that, with the ageing of the population, there will be an increasing demand for health and aged care services, which is why the Australian government has more than doubled funding for health and aged care. In aged care there has been a 140 per cent increase since 1996. Along with the measures announced by the Treasurer in the area of health, $3.3 billion worth of initiatives, senior Australians will welcome the extra funding in aged care. Building on the $2.2 billion package delivered last year, the single largest investment in aged care by any government at any time, this budget delivers a further $528 million in specific aged care services. We all know that the prevalence of dementia will increase as the population ages. This government is delivering a further $320 million in funding on top of the $2.6 billion that we already invest to ensure that people who are living with dementia, their carers and their families can receive appropriate support by way of earlier diagnosis, more training and education for aged care workers and more places for people living with deIn this budget we have also increased funding for carers. These people carry out the very demanding role of caring for older Australians. On top of the $100 million we already invest in carers support, a further $208 million in support for carers is contained in this budget. This will enable people who are employed to place their loved ones with day centres that will have longer hours. There will be more weekend respite and more overnight respite. This budget also includes funding for up to 1,700 nurses who will be focusing on aged care over the next four years. But the budget is not just about health and aged care. There is also financial support for seniors with initiatives in the Medicare levy threshold and the senior Australian tax offset threshold, in relation to the seniors concession allowance and the seniors utilities allowance. Because of the strong financial management of the Australian economy, this government can deliver real outcomes, real services and real support for older Australians.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I arrived at work today to find this letter from Nancy in my email: I am writing regarding Peter Costello's budget delivered last night. Once upon a time, being a mother and raising young children to be good and proud adults was considered a worthwhile job, and a job worth doing. It seems today that being a mum is a dirty word. I have 3 children, 2 in high school and a toddler. I now have to consider the option of putting her in child care and leave the family home to work out side. Why are women not given the choice. I believe that women who do work out side the home have every right to do so, but I also think that we should be given the choice of what is right for our families. When we went back for our 3rd child, it was under the agreement that I would be there for her, during the day, before school and after school (when the time comes, as I was for my other children) She is now not going to have that option, because being a mum is no longer good enough. I would hope that the Labor party will condemn this budget and support mothers (single or other wise) to have the options and choices that they rightly deserve. Doesn't that say it all? Since when has ‘mother' become a dirty word? This government talks about choice for mothers and choice for parents, and in this budget it shows that has always been empty rhetoric. When it comes to tax cuts, we know who is going to benefit most once again from this budget. No wonder the backbench of the Liberal Party were cheering on Tuesday night: they are going to do very well out of this. Unfortunately, their constituents are not going to do so well. How can a budget that delivers 45 per cent of tax cuts to the top 10 per cent of earners be considered fair? There is no fairness in this budget: there is no fairness when it comes to the tax cuts and there is no fairness when it comes to welfare reform. How can a budget that delivers a $2½ billion superannuation surcharge tax cut to people earning over $100,000 a year be considered a fair budget when so few people are paying the superannuation surcharge? When we look more closely at the welfare reform measures, we see there are two great unfairnesses. The first is that there is for the first time a two-tier system for parents on parenting payment and a two-tier system for people on disability support pension. How can it be right that two different people with the same disability or with the same caring responsibilities receive two different payments, depending on when they went onto benefits? The unfair changes contained in the 2005 budget make life harder for the neediest Australians and they fail to deliver on the real need for welfare reform. For months the government has been trumpeting its plans for welfare reform. The centrepiece of this budget was supposed to be about moving people from welfare to work. Those of us who are concerned about the poorest Australians were watching very carefully, hoping, in a triumph of optimism over experience, that this government would invest in the child care that these parents needed and in the training that these parents needed and help them find work. What a sad disappointment it has been. What a huge letdown. What a tragic waste. What a wasted opportunity this budget is. When it comes to tax cuts, with $22 billion to spend, it is mindboggling that the tax cuts for the lowest paid Australians are so low. The government says that it believes in the rights of all mothers to stay at home and look after their kids, but this budget makes it clear that it is only married mothers who are allowed to stay home and look after their kids. Why is a woman who stays at home and looks after her children called a homemaker? She is employed in domestic duties. She is rewarded with family tax benefit part B because this government says that it believes in choice for stay-at-home mums. But if her husband dies or leaves, suddenly that changes. If she is doing the work of two parents because her husband has died or left her or is violent and has driven her and the kids from home, then suddenly she is a bludger. The government's rhetoric about women is: ‘It's great to be a homemaker and we'll give you tax cuts to stay at home. What's more, we'll make child care so expensive and so hard to find that it's not worth your while working.' But if the father of your children leaves or dies or you cannot live with him and you cannot find work overnight, then suddenly you are a bludger. The Prime Minister pretends that he values the work of ing children, but this budget shows that he does not. The Treasurer is out there encouraging us to have more children, but if women do their bit for our declining population and then end up alone they get treated like shirkers and bludgers. Labor believes-and this government used to say it did-that the most important job of any parent, partnered or not, is looking after their child. Some parents choose to combine this with working outside the home; some do not. Many would dearly love to but cannot. When I grew up, my mum was there every day after school with a snack and a question about how my day had been and what had I learnt at school. I choose to work and I cannot offer that lovely experience to my children. But for this government to tell mothers that they are not allowed to make that choice because they have no man to support them beggars belief. It would be nice if single parents had more choices. It would be great if they could simply choose to engage in fulfilling part-time work between 9.30 am and 2.30 pm and then run home to pick up the kids from school. But where are the jobs for these people? The Howard government has done nothing to increase the number of permanent part-time jobs. New jobs are mostly casual, meaning parents cannot plan child care. They cannot knock back shifts either. Who is going to care for the kids at irregular intervals and short notice? Casual jobs are insecure. How can parents who have a responsibility to put food on the table week after week be expected to give up social security benefits and start paying for child care, transport and all the other work expenses for a job they could lose tomorrow? The government has not supported a claim before the Industrial Relations Commission for the lowest paid casual workers who have been with an employer for more than a year raisto request permanent part-time work. With permanent part-time work these parents could plan their child care. They would know how much was going to be in the pay packet at the end of the fortnight. It would make it possible for those parents to combine work and family responsibilities, but does this government support that? No way. It is not interested in helping; it is just interested in punishing. The government will not provide incentives to employers or even show any moral leadership in offering work during school hours. Most Australians at some point in their lives rely on government benefits or receive a payment to help them make ends meet. For most the period is short and the amount is modest. Welfare recipients are not a breed apart; they are not a separate species. They are our neighbours, our sisters, our parents and our children, and this government has relied on false stereotypes of teen mums and bad backs to justify these cuts. The reality is different. Over 64 per cent of single mothers are working or looking for work, and most would love to be in the work force if we gave them the help with training and child care that they need. Their children are the poorest in the land. They are already missing out on meals and school excursions. Make no mistake: this attack on mothers is an attack on their children. It is also worth noting-and I note with a sense of shame-that, under this budget, two single mothers get two different payments and are subjected to two different regimes depending on whether they go onto benefits before or after 1 July 2006. This applies to disability support pensioners as well. They will be required to undergo regular updates on whether they are still disabled. There are two different regimes. A parent whose youngest child is over six and who already receives the sole parent pension will continue with the same entitlements and burdens as they have currently, but an Australian whose marriage breaks up and who goes on the sole parent pension after 1 July 2006 suffers an income drop of $44 a fortnight when their child turns six years old. It is incredible that two parents who do the same work at home and face the same barriers to employment will receive two different benefits. I am sure that the government, in the name of streamlining, simplicity and efficiency, will decide sooner or later that disability support pensioners, who receive two different levels of benefits-$77 a fortnight differentshould receive a streamlined payment, and you can bet your bottom dollar that it will not be the higher payment that everyone receives; it will be the lower one. This budget's other great lack is that it does absolutely nothing to provide the child care or the training that these parents need to re-enter the work force. The government has made much of the 84,000 out of school hours care places that it has provided. We heard the figures today. There will be 190,000 extra people moving into the work force and 35,000 people are already on waiting lists for those out of school hours care places. Where are the extra places coming from, and what does the Prime Minister think those extra kids are going to do? They will go home to empty houses. They will be a new generation of latchkey kids. When it comes to training, the government has done nothing to help with the training needs of welfare recipients. Many of them have not finished high school. They need training to be employable, to make them attractive to employers. Everyone agrees on that. At the same time that the government is talking about sending people back to work, it has turned 400,000 young Australians away from TAFE and universities. At the same time as we have a skills shortage, it has turned 400,000 Australians away from TAFE and universities. There is only one Job Network place for every seven parenting payment recipients. What are the others going to do? They will suffer the punishment and they will suffer the cuts to their benefits, but they will receive no help, no aid. When it comes to disability support pensioners, again it is only cuts the government has in mind. We should not be surprised, though: it is a Liberal budget. It is a budget for the wealthy, the natural constituency of the Liberal Party. No wonder there was cheering and clapping here the other night from all those people up there in their black ties and cocktail dresses, the backbench of the Liberal Party here-all on over $100,000 a year. They are doing really well out of these tax cuts. They are doing really well out of the cuts to the superannuation surcharge. Let them go home and explain it to the people on minimum wages in their electorates. This government has accused us of class warfare, but this budget makes war on the poor. It is a budget that does so much for so few and so little for so many. It benefits the minority at the expense of the majority. As I said, 45 per cent of the tax cuts go to the top 10 per cent of earners. The superannuation surcharge of $2½ billion goes to a minority of high-income earners. It goes to only one per cent of women workers, incidentally. These tax cuts are the most unfair proposed by any government in recent history. It is the same government, mind you, that has opposed every pay increase for workers on the minimum wage since it came to government. This government is happy to give tax cuts to its wealthy mates, but it will oppose to the death any wage increase for workers in the hospitality industry who are turning down beds in great big hotels that government members are happy to spend the night in. If the government had its way, the poorest workers in this country would be $45 a week worse off than they are at the moment. Let's put a human face on this: Louise from Victoria, a single mother with four kids, still has three living at home studying. She does not drive a car. She cannot afford it. She ran a small business from home designing mirror frames. She is terrified by this attitude to single mothers and she is offended by the stereotyping. She knows that the lack of apprenticeships means that her kids cannot get jobs. She does not have a husband or a father for her kids. She does everything for herself. Why does she deserve to be punished? (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Menzies-Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service) (3.15 pm)-Nothing illustrates better the total lack of intellectual and sustained thought and policy development of the Australian Labor Party than its response to this budget. Amazingly, in the last two days when we have debated matters of public importance in this place-a debate which is conventionally led by the opposition in this House-we have not seen at the dispatch box, leading the debate on behalf of the opposition, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the shadow Treasurer. They seem to have gone missing in action. As I said, nothing so clearly demonstrates the total lack of policy development and the total lack of an intellectual core to the Australian Labor Party, which in its past has better and more fully represented the workers and others in Australia. We have just heard from the member for Sydney a concoction of inaccuracies, of which there are so many I am not sure I would have time to list them if I set out to do so. Let me just take a number of them for a start. She said that there are no incentives for employees in this particular budget. Wrong. She said that there is a limit on the numbers in relation to the Job Network. Wrong: the Job Network remains uncapped for people about whom she was speaking. She said that the government has opposed every pay increase in the Industrial Relations Commission. Wrong. Mr Adams-Every time!

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This year, as in other years, as the member opposite will know if he looks at the record, the government is supporting a wage increase for Australians. One could go on about a speech which was replete with inaccuracies.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Lyons is warned.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If the opposition wants to come in here and argue to the people of Australia that it has a policy position which it wants to advocate to them and if it wants to persuade them that it is an alternative government, then it ought to at least put accurate facts on the table. The package of Welfare to Work is a $2.6 billion package which will increase economic participation of people in this country. It recognises that every Australian of working age has the right and deserves the opportunity to participate in Australia's We are here on a day on which the unemployment rate is once again at 5.1 per cent and on a day when the Australian Bureau of Statistics has revealed to us that there are more Australians in jobs than ever before in this country. Significantly, 286,200 jobs have been created over the past year, almost 72 per cent of which have been full-time positions. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has measured an increase in full-time employment over the past month. Whenever else but on such a day and in such circumstances would it be opportune to try to bring about some reforms which would give those people who have been locked out of the economic life of this country the opportunity to particitragedy pate in it? We do not, for one moment, walk away from this policy. This is a policy that says to sole parents and to those who are capable of working, ‘We will look at your ability and your capacity rather than as we have done for so many years in the past'-and it seems the Labor Party still want to do this‘continue to concentrate on disability and incapacity.' Where is the bravery of the Labor Party? The member for Lilley in 1999 said, ‘Labor wants to ensure that our system of social security is not encouraging dependence.' Where is the bravery of the Labor Party? And what does the Labor Party stand for when it seems to be arguing now and during question time that somehow these reforms have gone too far and are so tough? The Leader of Opposition on AM yesterday morning was asked in relation to his response to the budget: One of the centrepieces of this budget is the welfare changes. Mr Costello last night mentioned the genuinely disabled, suggesting perhaps some on disability pensions now are shirkers. What do you think? The response from Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, was: prosperity. Well, they squibbed reform ... Which way does the Labor Party want it? Mr Lyons interjecting

Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Was the Leader of the Opposition correct yesterday when he said, ‘They didn't go far enough; they squibbed reform,' or is the Labor Party right today when they say that somehow this has gone too far? Which side of the road is the Labor Party walking on today? This is the great of what was once a great political party in this country-namely, the Australian Labor Party. Those who made it a great political party in the past must be turning in their graves to see what we get as an opposition today. On top of that, the party that have traditionally, historically, represented the workers of Australia come in here and say that they will oppose tax cuts, including tax cuts which will reducing the 17 per cent rate-the lowest rate of tax threshold in this countryto 15 per cent. That is a rate which applies specifically to the working men and women of Australia. And the Labor Party, the great historical party of the workers of Australia, come in here and say, ‘We are going to oppose those tax cuts.' No wonder in the last election, and in the elections before that, the working-class men and women of Australia, looking to the interests of their families and those that they support, have walked away in their droves from the Australian Labor Party. This is a reform which is timely. It is timely because we have a situation where we have more people in jobs in Australia than ever before. It is timely because the unemployment rate is at 5.1 per cent and because we have the opportunity now to say to people in Australia that the best form of welfare, if we can appropriately bring it about, is to give a job to as many people in this country who are capable of it and who want one. Even Andrew MCCallum, the President of ACOSS, acknowledges that the best form of welfare is a job. That is what we are on about. We had a lot before from the member for Sydney about sole parents. I ask rhetorically: is the Labor Party seriously suggesting that we should imagine that a typical single parent, aged between 30 to 39, raising a child or two, usually as a consequence of divorce or separation, does not have the same aspirations for herself and her children as every other Australian? Why does the Labor Party take the view that we should condemn that woman to, on average, 10 to 12 years on welfare, that we should make her family one of those families in which 800,000 kids are growing up in a jobless household? Why does the Labor Party imagine that those people do not have the same aspirations as other Australians? And why does the Labor Party suggest that we should not do something about a social situation which will mean that the chances of those children being on welfare in the future are greater than they would otherwise be? We do not seriously entertain the proposition that has been put forward by the Australian Labor Party. We will not condemn people in those circumstances to not having an opportunity to participate in the prosperity of this nation. As I said, all Australians should be able to contribute according to their ability to the economic life of this country. This is where we are starting from. It is about participation. It is about looking at people's ability and their capacity to work, rather than saying that someone who in the past was put on a disability support pension has basically been condemned to a dead-end payment-the reality for many people. Over the last couple of months, the Minister for Workforce Participation and I have spent quite a period of time consulting with disabled groups and other representatives of welfare beneficiaries around Australia. One of the things they said to us was that they have the same aspirations for a job as anybody else and that they would like some assistance with that-and this package has assistance in it. We heard complaints about additional child care. There is provision for more than 84,000 additional child-care places in this package. I remind the House that the 84,000 additional outside school hours care places in this year's budget are more than the total provided by the Australian Labor Party when they were last in government. There were crocodile tears from the member for Sydney before about these reforms-reforms which are aimed at giving people an opportunity to participate in the economic life of this country. We have made a deliberate policy decision that, if people do have the capacity to work, we should treat them in that way. We have been generous about it-for example, for sole parents waiting until their youngest child turns six and providing an additional transition period of 12 months to those who would go onto the benefit in the next year or so. I remind the House what other countries do. In Austria, Germany, France, Italy, Norway-one of the so-called socially progressive countries of Scandinavia-Switzerland and Denmark, lone parents on benefits are required to look for work when their youngest child is three, not six. And in the past these countries have had governments equivalent to those of the Australian Labor Party in this place. We are giving people the opportunity to participate in the work force of this country and, when the immediate requirements of their preschool aged children have passed, we will encourage sole parent beneficiaries to look for work and will put them on newstart allowance. We have been generous about newstart allowance not just for sole parents but for all recipients of newstart lowance where we have made the taper rate operate in a way that retains more of people's income. These are positive measures. You would hardly imagine, listening to the member for Sydney, that this is a $3.6 billion package of expenditure-this is not a savings measuredesigned to increase the work force participation of those who unfortunately are presently locked out of the economic life of this country. On top of that, not only does the opposition oppose giving these people and their children a better chance, looking at their capacity to work and doing something about them achieving their aspirations-that is what they were telling the Minister for Workforce Participation, me and all others in the coalition-but the opposition is opposed to the tax cuts in this budget. In the time that I have been in this parliament I do not recall an opposition that has been so inept in its response to a budget. Where are the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer? Not only are they missing in action-we might see something of the Leader of the Opposition tonight-but, essentially, they are seeking to deny Australians billions of dollars worth of tax cuts. On one hand, they complain about the minimum wage and, on the other hand, they say they are going to block the tax cuts. How absolutely ridiculous a position is this for an Australian opposition? It would deliver obvious advantages and benefits to the men and women of Australia and their families. Why is the Labor Party so opposed to giving Australian workers and their families more money in their pockets? Why is it saying, ‘While we control the Senate in this place, we will vote against'-presumably with the assistance of minor parties-‘a benefit which would flow otherwise from 1 July to the al- families and workers of Australia'? The Australian Labor Party was once the great party of the workers of Australia. All one can conclude from this debate is that the party which once represented the workers of Australia has abandoned them. The friends of the workers of Australia are on this side of the House.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This budget shows how woefully out of touch this government is with the challenges and struggles of making ends meet for millions of Australians. Everyone in this House thinks that work is better than welfare. Everyone in this House believes that if it is possible for someone to work then they are better off than being on welfare. But where the opposition and the government differ, and differ bitterly, are over the means of achieving that outcome. The government have just discovered welfare to work disincentives. They have only just found out about them. They have only just accepted that what Labor has been arguing for years is right-this government must do something about welfare to work incentives-but in their implementation of that program they have shown their callousness and their disregard for the needs of millions of Australians. In this budget we see three things: first, a clear indication that this government is out of touch with the needs and challenges of people on a disability pension and a parenting payment; second, a continuation of their ideological obsession with punishing instead of helping people get back into the work force-we have seen that since this government came into office in 1996; and, third, a continuation of this government's favourite tactic. This government loves the fact that people on a disability pension are being portrayed in the community as shirkers. Their favourite tactic is the dog whistle. We have heard that the Treasurer's favourite headline, out of all the headlines that been written about this budget, is that of the Daily Telegraph on Tuesday: ‘Workers 1, Shirkers 0'. We saw the picture of the Treasurer reading that headline with a huge smile on his face-not untypically, with a huge smile on his face. Well, somebody has got to say it: not everybody on a disability pension is a shirker. Not every single parent is a shirker. It would have been better if one of the members of the government could have come into this House and said, ‘Hang on a minute, that's not right; not everybody's a shirker,' but not one of them has said it. Not one of them has had the guts to come into this chamber and say, ‘There are people on the disability support pension and there are single parents who are not shirkers.' In fact, the vast majority are not shirkers. They are people who have been dealt a hard blow in life and deserve this government's support, but the government are happy to see them portrayed as bludgers and shirkers. That is a national disgrace. We saw this in 1996: this government came into office and abolished a range of programs which helped people from welfare to work-Jobstart, the national training wage, New Work Opportunities, Landcare and Environment Action Plan and job skills. They slashed all those and what did they create? What did they replace them with? It was Work for the Dole. What did Work for the Dole contribute? There was no training and a worse result in getting people from welfare back into work, but it was an excellent result in portraying unemployed people as shirkers. This government is at it again with welfare to work policies which do not produce results but which do portray poor and disadvantaged people in the community as shirkers. Let me turn to some of the practical ramifications of this year's budget in relation to welfare. As the honourable member for Sydhave ney said, from 1 July 2006, people applying for the parenting payment will receive the current entitlements until their child turns six. From then, they will receive a so-called enhanced newstart allowance, which will involve an obligation to work at least 15 hours a week. The taper rate for this enhanced allowance will be 60c in the dollar instead of 70c. But what is the biggest obstacle for single parents wishing to transfer to work? The answer, of course, is child care, particularly out of school hours care. This government has announced 84,300 new out of school hours places. At first glance that sounds impressive, but the devil is in the detail. Firstly, the majority of these places will not come on line until 2008. Half the funding for these places is not available until 2008-09, but of course the welfare changes come into effect in 2006. So there is a very significant lag. I am not sure what the single parents who are transferring from welfare to work are meant to do for two years while these places are coming on line. That is just the nub of the problem. We already have a shortage of out of school hours places as it is. As we speak, there is a shortage of over 30,000 places across the country, so of those 80,000 new places more than 30,000 are going to be taken up just fulfilling the shortfall that is currently there. That is not taking into account all the people whom this government is trying to move from welfare to work and is not creating anywhere near enough childcare places. I have seen this in my electorate. We have seen after school hours care centres close. Just last year we saw the Smithfield West after school hours centre threatened with closure. It was only through a community campaign and cooperation from the local council and other child-care providers that we were able to keep that open. Talking to the mothers and the fathers who relied on that centre for their after school hours care brought home to me just how important it was for parents, both in family situations with two parents and in those with single parents, and how much they rely on after school hours care. There is a national crisis in after school hours care and the government have done nothing about it. Even now, the places they are creating will go nowhere near meeting the new demand that they will be creating. In addition, the government have made some quiet changes to the JET scheme for sole parents which will reduce the incentives for sole parents to move from welfare to work. So not only have they done nothing; they are actually making it worse. They have quietly introduced changes in this budgetthey have not gone out and talked about them. They have changed the JET scheme to say that sole parents with disabled children should not be able to go into long-term ing to get them back into the work force-a callous budget-cutting measure which goes against the grain. It goes against everything the government are meant to be achieving, against all their rhetoric, and yet they stay quiet about it. I talked before about the enhanced newstart allowance and the taper rate of 60 per cent. They call it the enhanced newstart allowance-I am not sure where it is enhanced from. It is true that the taper rate for the normal newstart allowance is 70c in the dollar. But what is the taper rate for the parenting allowance? The taper rate for the parenting allowance, up to $146 a fortnight, is 40c. So, by moving people from the parenting allowance onto the newstart allowance, they are again reducing the incentives from welfare to work, again going against the grain of all their rhetoric and their promises. Again we see the devil in the detail. What support is the government providing to people on the disability pension to transfer from welfare to work? In fairness, as the member for Sydney has outlined, there are some vocational training places, but again they are sadly inadequate. There are not many-600,000 parents have to fight with 65,000 mature age unemployed for just 12,300 vocational training places. This is not a proper plan to help people off the disability support pension. It is a way, however, to transfer people from one form of welfare to another. If a disabled person is classified as being able to work 15 hours a week then they will be moved to Newstart. This means that a disabled person will be $77 a fortnight worse off, even if they are doing everything they can to find a jobeven if they are applying for every job they can think of, even if they are struggling in their wheelchairs with public transport to get to job interviews, even if they are doing trainwhatever is possible to get a job. Mr Fitzgibbon-Shame!

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: ‘Shame!' is right. This is a very sad result indeed. We must do more to help people on the disability support pension back into work, not just punish them. The Prime Minister showed a sad lack of understanding in question time. More in pity than in anger I say: a sad lack of understanding of the needs of people on the disability support pension. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has said: The Treasurer said that welfare to work changes are meant to encourage unemployed people and part-time workers but they are only penalising people and acting as another disincentive to The Prime Minister said the other day that this government was an enlarging government. It is not; it is a punishing government. It is not interested in enlarging the lives of people on disability pensions and sole parents who are struggling and trying to get back into work. If it was, it would be doing something for the current disability pension recipients. It would be creating incentives for them. It would be giving them support to get back into the workplace. But those people, as the Prime Minister said, are grandfathered. There is no support for them, no encouragement for them and no training places for them. They are left out in the cold. We have an obligation as a parliament, as a government and as a society to look after those who have been dealt a hard blow in life. We have to extend a hand to them and help them back into the work force-not punish or penalise them for the circumstances they find themselves in. This is a punishing budget from a punishing government. It should hang its head in shame for this outrageous budget. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms LEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Farrer-Parliamentary Secretary (Children and Youth Affairs)) (3.39 pm)-It is a pleasure to talk on this matter of public importance in the House today following the excellent budget delivered by the Treasurer on Tuesday night. I would like to quote Winston Churchill, who said, ‘We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give.' I think that statement underpins the philosophical differences that we are seeing come through this debate on both sides of the House. ‘We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give.' The opposition are concerned only with what people need, from their point of view, to get-what handouts, what entitlements, what benefits and what welfare. But on this side of the House we are asking peowork. ple: ‘What can you contribute? How can you make a life by what you give and in so doing find happiness?' That is an important philosophical difference that we have really seen come through clearly in this MPI. The first speaker wove the usual web of nonsense and inconsistencies-I am not allowed to call them lies. The second speaker continued with the same sort of rhetoric, putting words in our mouths-‘shirkers', ‘bludgers', ‘struggling in wheelchairs to get interviews', ‘a punishing government'. These are not words that the government use. Do not put words in our mouths. How can this be a punishing government when we are spending $3.6 billion with these measures? And we are spending for the next eight years to encourage training and opportunities to move people into a real place in the real economy. This centrepiece of the budget attacks the very real problem of intergenerational welfare. I want to explain where the need comes from, because obviously members opposite have not worked it out. The proportion of working age Australians receiving income support payments has risen from one in 20 in 1974 to one in five today. In June 2004 there were some 2.7 million income support recipients aged between 16 and 64-over 20 per cent of all working age Australians, most of whom rely on income support for the majority of their incomes. We are talking about a group of people affected by intergenerational welfare whose long-term life chances are being lost to them. As the Prime Minister said in question time, it is in the interests of this government that we look after the interests of the working men and women in this country. As Minister Andrews, who spoke earlier, said: we must give people the opportunity to participate in the working life of this country. Welfare is a safety net, a very good safety net, but it is not a way of life and nor should one see it as that. It is better to be on work than on welfare, and we need to encourage the transition from welfare to work. Again let me highlight where the need comes from with a couple of figures from the recent past. The number of Australian families with children under the age of 15 who had no parent in work increased from 280,000 in 1986 to 390,000 in 1997. About three-quarters of the parents in these families were not in the labour force. Among the quarter who were unemployed, perhaps 40 per cent had been unemployed for more than one year. But what we see now is that around 690,000 children live in households where no parent works. I think that is one in five one in seven Australian kids growing up in a household where no parent works. There has been a substantial increase in the extent of income support dependence and worklessness in this country. At an OECD conference in 1996 Professor Esping-Andersen said, ‘We face a crisis of polarisation if the losers of today are losers for life, and if they pass their underprivilege on to the next generation.' I do not think government wants to stand by and see underprivilege being passed on from one generation to the next. This is about finding portunities for young people to have a ‘real place in the real economy'-I think I am quoting Noel Pearson when I say that. If we look at the American experience we see that growing up poor increased the probability of long-term poverty in adulthood by three times for poor blacks and eight times for poor whites. The daughters of welfare recipients were more than twice as likely to receive welfare themselves than the daughters of nonrecipients. The member for Sydney should take note of that point. In Australia we have not yet completed similar longitudinal studies, but there is evidence that the anyexperience is comparable. The lowest participation rates were found among young people from families with no parental employment, and that should come as no surprise. We must support parents who have the greatest responsibility of all-to care for, provide for and nurture their children. I have got into the habit of checking from time to time the web site of the Australian Greens. Prior to the last election it was with great concern that I realised that people who held these views managed to put them on the national agenda in this country. It is with a sense of relief that I have now realised they will not be able to do that after 1 July. I want to touch on the Australian Greens, and I hope or none of their ideas find their way into this debate. They have an idea that we should have a universal guaranteed adequate income scheme with the following characteristics: everyone gets a particular amount of money, no-one has to pass an activity test and no-one pays tax under a certain level. Everyone is somehow supposed to find an adequate wage in that scheme. I am really pleased that after 1 July this this year we will have an opportunity to do what has not been legislatively possible over the last nine years. I think what has come op- through today is that Labor is scaring the public with this nonsense about parents being forced to work. It is all very well to stand here and trot out the rhetoric, as the member for Sydney has done, about mums having to go back to work and not being able to be at home after school. I share that concern with her. My mum was not there when I got home from school either, but she certainly demonstrated to me a model in which you work hard, get where you want to in life and try your best. It is something that women in this place should all understand. The member for Sydney gave the example of a constituent who sent her a fax in which she said she is going to be forced to go to work and will not be home when her children come home from school. What the member for Sydney should do is inform her constituent of the facts, which is that if she is currently receiving sole parent pension she will be asked when her youngest child turns six to look for 15 hours work a week, which is about three hours a day. I am confident that, should she be able to do that, she will be able to be at home at least some of the time when her children get home from school. It is the responsibility of the opposition to educate their constituents. This is a new and important measure and it matters a great deal to the future of this country. So, please, give them the facts. I say to those who are reading about this debate and trying to get to grips with it that they should contact members of the government and we will give you the facts so that you can understand how it will affect you. I want to touch on some of the remarks that members opposite have made on this subject. This welfare to work measure hinges around mutual obligation. Senator Penny Wong said: Mutual obligation is the touchstone of Labor's approach to increasing work force participation. … It is our view that government should be doing everything possible to help unemployed people who are reasonably able to work to find work. That is obviously a situation where everyone wins. It is good for the individuals concerned, good for the community … The subject matter of the MPI today is that we are not doing the real work. We have not heard from the opposition what their ideas on this are, but we do know that they support mutual obligation. The Leader of the Opposition has said: Labor supports mutual obligation where people are capable of working; and the government provides them with the opportunities they need to find and keep work. He has also said: To increase work force participation, our tax and welfare systems also need to provide greater incentive and reward for effort. The member for Lilley has said: What this country needs is … real reform which puts incentive into the system … So where is the real reform? I guess we will have to wait until tonight to hear what is said, but I hope what we hear in the opposition leader's budget reply tonight centres on the facts and does not use this ridiculous rhetoric that we have heard today. On welfare to work in general, the member for Lilley has said: Labor recognises that encouraging people to move from welfare to work is a policy objective in its own right and one of the most important we can have. We want fewer people on welfare and more people in work. We could not have put it any better ourselves. The Minister for Family and Community Services, Kay Patterson, has responded to the further scaremongering about child-care places by the member for Sydney this morning. I encourage the member for Sydney to catch up on those few facts as well and, importantly, to understand that the number of long day care places is uncapped and is constantly increasing. Since 1996 the number of places has increased from 168,000 to over 229,000. The member for Sydney falsely assumes that no formal care is availit is able for parents employed in shiftwork when in fact family day care very much has those options. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to this debate on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. This bill is the last of those implementing the government's Backing Australia's Future package. It is quizzically named Backing Australia's Future, because it is far from ing that. Instead, it is yet another attack by the Howard government on the ability of Australians to access education. The bill's purpose is to prevent higher education providers from requiring students to join student associations. In other words, students will not have to pay fees to assist their student association when they enrol in their courses. The government claims that this is necessary to ensure freedom of association. However, it is clear to us that the real intent this legislation is to knock out another voice that opposes government policies. Freedom of choice, speech or association is the last thing the Howard government wants in our higher education system. In effect, this bill not only attacks students but also attacks universities. It is not only students who say that they need student associations; the universities themselves have told the government that these institutions are needed on campus. Under the preposterous guise of freedom of association, the government is using this bill to destroy students' services, students' rights and students' support networks. The bill is the latest in a series of measures the government has put forward to damage the higher education system and distort it into one based on privilege over merit. The Backing Australia's Future package has seen a rise in the HECS fees charged by universities of up to 25 per cent from 2005 and has paved the way for full fee-paying domestic students where privilege rather than merit will guarantee a university place. The government has made universities harder to get into and too expensive for many Australians to access. Now it will also seek to abolish the remaining vestiges of student support on campus. All of this has been done in an attempt to silence student criticism of the terrible mismanagement of education policy we have experienced under this government. This is do- political payback of the cheapest and lowest kind. We already know that existing provisions allow students to opt out of associations, but this bill will prevent higher education providers from collecting fees for student associations. The Trade Practices Act 1974 contains provisions that ensure a student's rights to freedom of association should they object to joining a student association. This right has already been tested by the Australian Competition and Consumer of Commission. This bill is unnecessary in achieving the government's supposed goal of freedom of association. That right already exists. The real intention behind this bill is ideological. In 1997 we saw the Howard government rip into unions with masked guards, military recruits and dogs on the docks. We are going to get another round of that after 1 July. Now it is happening again through this witch-hunt against student representation. This is all a vain effort to silence any opposition and criticism of the Howard government's changes to education policy. The government is punishing all those who dare to speak out. So one-eyed is the government's dogged pursuit of unionism that it is willing to destroy student associations, which more closely resemble service and welfare support organisations than unions. To their credit, students have long been involved in the political process and political activity. They have been effective critics of governments for decades. The previous governments of which I was a member, the Hawke and Keating governments, were confronted by student opposition often-just as John Howard's successive governments have been. In the face of reforms pushed by the Minister for Education, Science and Training, reforms which strip the ability of ordinary Australians to access education on academic merit rather than on their financial position, students have to put up a fight. It is clear to me that this bill is political retribution a means of neutralising public comment on the government's education policies. If this bill becomes law, students will have paid a heavy price for standing up for themselves and standing up for others. They will have lost important support that many rely on at one time or another in their studies. So determined is the coalition to gag students while creating a privilege based education system that it has even managed to write a flaw into the bill-the catch-all prohibition of any fee that does not relate directly to the course. Let us consider the consequences of that. It will prevent universities from gathering student association fees. It will also prevent them from collecting parking fines, library fines or accommodation charges at halls of residence. Of course, none of these are directly related to university education courses. Surely even this government must recognise that this bill will result in a massive erosion of the facilities and capacities on university campuses. The government seems willing to let universities crumble and decay. That is the ultimate impact of this exercise. A cost saving it will not be. It will be a penalty on all Australian students at all Australian universities, whether or not they are the sandstone universities or the newer regional universities like the Charles Darwin University in my own territory, the Northern Territory. Of course, that is a very young university and can ill afford the cuts in services which will automatically flow from the government's decision to prevent the university from raising the student association fees. The government may not see the value in student associations but, on this side of the House, their role in the universities is clear. It is worthwhile looking at some of the functions that are carried out by a small regional university like ours in the Northern Territory. University associations administer sports associations and sports facilities. I was a and is member of the student association here at ANU when I was a student and was on the sports council. We had the responsibility of administering and managing all the sports resources of the university. That included the gymnasium, the grounds and all of the things that the students were using as part of the union fees in the sports arena. All of these will now be threatened. The reduced capacity of student associations to provide comprehensive services as a result of this measure will mean that many of the clubs and societies which are currently run at universities and financed through the student associations will no longer continue. Charles Darwin University has a gymnasium and various sporting clubs: athletics, soccer, the various football codes, badminton, basketball, netball, cricket, triathlon, hockey, ju-jitsu, karate, sailing, TaeKwonDo, Ultimate Frisbee, volleyball, water polo and capoeira. In the students union they have special interest groups: the Social Workers Club, the Indigenous Students Association, the Engineers Club, the Maths Club, the Psychology Students Association, the Law Students Association, the IT Club, the Labor Club and-dare I say it-the Liberal Club, the Baha'i Society, the Fellowship of Christian University Students and the Japanese Animation Club. There is a students' rights advocate, who is funded through the students union. The function of this position includes advising of rights under the CDU student charter, helping students deal with issues with their faculty, failed grades, exclusion, disciplinary hearings and special consideration, helping international students with study visa and liaison with the department of immigration, support for mature age students, other advocacy and assistance with external bodies, including assistance with youth allowance, Austudy and Abstudy, accommodation assistance, employment assistance, participation in annual events such as Orientation Week for both VET and university students, Troppo Week at the commencement of second semester, Youth Week, Indigenous Day, International Day, Harmony Day, Darwin Pride Week, Charity Pancake Day, the National Campus Band Competition, the National Tertiary Art Prize, the Movie Club and Deck Chair Cinema, cocktail parties, ‘big barbies' and even a pub crawl, and the Litchfield Day Trip. It may sound trite, but these are all essenThe tial activities on the university campus. Yet the government seems to think that, somehow or other, these things will continue once it removes the right of universities to charge students association fees. Most of the sandstone universities will have built up significant reserves and their capital costs would have been sunk many years ago, but the smaller universities do not have those luxuries. Since 1996, when the Howard government first appeared here in the parliament, the government has removed $6 million a year in recurrent funding from Charles Darwin University alone-$60 million over 10 years. Last year, this government raised HECS charges by 25 per cent and opened the door for ‘buy your future' $200,000 university degrees. Now students pay GST on books. Universities like Charles Darwin cannot suffer long the penalties which have been imposed upon it by the Howard government. The successive charges which have been placed upon that university because of underfunding by the Commonwealth are causing that university distress in the way it is able to fund courses and provide student services. And now we have another shot. Under the process the government has put in place we will see the capacity of the university to provide for the student associations and the activities of the student union-which I have just outlined-severely undermined. The involvement of the university students in the community of Darwin will be handicapped. I do not believe this measure is something many Australians will support. It compounds, in my view, the cynical approach of the Howard government-attacking the rights of universities to raise these charges when it knows that the universities themselves oppose the measure. Professor Di Yerbury, President of the Australian ViceChancellors Committee, on 16 March stated: Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee rejects the government's underlying premise that students are forced to be members of student organisations. Students already have the option not to be members. I made this point clear just moments ago. She continues: It is a bit like council rates-not everybody uses all the services, but rates in a community are compulsory. I do not think that is a bad analogy-it is a very good analogy, in fact. That is how these charges should be seen. Professor Yerbury continues: We see this legislation as somewhat heavyhanded. John Mullarvey, the chief executive of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, said on 17 March: International students view education in Australia as a holistic experience-an education combined with an invaluable life experience underpinned by the students services offered on campus, such as general support and pastoral care, as well cial and sporting activities ... I am certain that domestic students should share this view of their time at university. It demonstrates clearly that a comprehensive involvement at the level of higher education means that you should be able to access these services. But that will be threatened and undermined if the government has its way. I mentioned earlier the role of student sports associations. We know that a number of prominent Australians placed advertisements in the major daily newspapers on 19 April this year expressing concern that the introduction of this anti-student organisation legislation would destroy sporting activities at universities, which have encouraged and developed many athletes at the elite level. Among the signatories were Charlesworth, a former member of this place who was a Sheffield Shield cricketer, an Australian representative hockey player and the coach of the great gold medal winning Australian women's hockey team; Shane Gould MBE; John Boultbee; Ric Charlton; David Clarke; John Coates; David Coe; Kim Beazley; Bruce Collins QC; Peter Crittle, a great rugby player; Phil Crowe; Roger Davis; Rob de Castella; Gary Flowers; David Gallop; Phil Harry; Richard Lee-and the list goes on. These are not people of want who just go out and pay for an advertisement of this type simply because they want the exercise or because they want to participate in this sort of activity. It shows their real concern about the impact of this legislation upon the ability of universities to provide the full range of services to their students. Importantly, these people understand, as I do from my own experience at university, the value of the sports services that are provided by university campuses and the fact that they are a very strong training ground for sportsas so- men and women who go on to earn higher honours as Australian representatives. It seems to me that we are throwing out the baby with the bathwater here. This is such a short-sighted thing the government is doing. It is penalising good, young Australians for going to university. It has penalised them already by the enormous increase of 25 per cent in HECS charges. Now it is saying to them: ‘We don't believe that these services are essential to your education.' I say they are. And I say that it is in the national interest to ensure these services are provided at universities. Of course the Commonwealth government will not tip into the till to cover the losses that will be incurred as a result of this legislation. There will be no additional finance coming from the government to help these Ric university activities-no way. But it is all about ideology. It is all about the government's abhorrence of students having a voice. I am reminded of Kent Rowe, President of the Charles Darwin University student union. In a statement he made on 16 March this year he said: The Howard government is irritated by informed organised criticism of his anti-student policies student organisations, so now he wants us to shut up. The legislation his government introduced in parliament today is designed to do just that. What kind of government bans students from making organised political comment? He gives three examples: Soeharto, Indonesia 1978. Deng Xioping, China 1989we all remember thatand John Howard, Australia 2005 By contrast, universities in virtually every country in the OECD including the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom and New Zealand charge compulsory fees to support student services at universities. Australia will be the exception if this proposed legislation is passed. Some governments just hate informed, organised opposition, and John Howard's government is one of those. I do not believe that Australians will be able to hold their heads up with any great pride as a result of this legislation. They will, like me, be very concerned about its impact upon campuses across this nation. They will, like me, be concerned about the ability of students to provide services for themselves and their colleagues. They will, like me, be concerned about the ability of student associations to actively promote and advocate students rights. They will, like me, be concerned about the impact this will have on the ability of student associations, and student bodies generally, to be actively involved politically. I am most concerned about this and believe that it will be a day of great shame if and when this legislation becomes law. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. Like the bill debated yesterday on bargaining agents' fees, it goes by to the heart of values in Australian society: freedom of choice and freedom of association. Before I go on with what I had planned to say, I want to go back to something that the member for Lingiari alerted the House to-that is, his time at the ANU. He was a member of the student union. He remembered with fondness the services that were delivered by that student union body and where the money was going. I was at the same university. In fact, if I look at the age range of both of us, I think our time may have overlapped slightly towards the end of the member for Lingiari's time and the start of mine. I remember the absolute outrage from the students on the campus about where that money was going. I remember the protests that took place when we found out that the money during those days was going to support terrorist organisations overseas. It could very well be that money was going to services within the university, but it was also going to questionable organisations overseas. If the member for Lingiari was part of the student body that made the decision to send money to those overseas terrorist organisations based in Libya, then he should hang his head in shame for the part that he played, because it certainly did not receive the support of the student organisation when I was there during the early to mid-seventies. This bill is about freedom of choice. It is about freedom of association. What makes these fundamental freedoms all the more relevant in this case is the fact that they relate to the very people we are currently training as the future leaders of our society. At present, freedom of choice and freedom of association do not apply to membership of student organisations or the payment of compulsory general service fees at universities. This situation is simply unacceptable and it keeps the higher education sector out of line with the general community. As mentioned, the Howard government has breathed much needed life into the industrial relations sector by introducing freedom of choice and association through our workplace relations reforms. This bill seeks to introduce these freedoms to students in the higher education sector. Why shouldn't students enjoy the right to choose something that now exists in most workplaces across Australia? The union movement only represents 17 per cent of the Australian private sector work force, and membership is falling. Why is it falling? Because people do not understand and do not accept the value of what the union movement purports to give them. The same applies on campuses. Workers refrain from formally contributing their voice to a union; the situanature tion is mirrored in Australia's universities, where a pitifully low voter turnout to student elections reflects a high level of apathy amongst students towards their unions. Before the pros and cons of voluntary student unionism can be effectively debated, one point needs to be made: student unions, guilds and associations are not industrial ions. I accept that. But, unlike in industry, students are not engaged in employment with the university and, hence, do not derive an income from their role at the institution. dent unions are formed to represent students at the various administrative bodies of the university and to provide student services. Additionally, student unions manage their associations and the windfall that they receive straight from the pockets of students. Higher education funding reform has been a highly topical issue in this chamber over recent years. To our universities, the Backing Australia's Future reforms are a sensible response by the government to the cause of greater financial liquidity for students. The reforms recognise that Australia's universities need greater and quicker access to funds if they are to continually develop into worldclass education centres. Prior to the reforms of December 2003, universities were limited to the terms and finances of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. The same cannot be said of our student unions across Australia. Compulsory student union fees are upfront payments collected prior to the commencement of an academic semester. In most cases, the fees are collected by the university under the guise of a general service fee or student association fee. The majority is then directed straight into the coffers of the student union. The most unfair aspects of these fees are the conditions that payment or, in some cases, non-payment entails. The compulsory of the fees ties into student access to vital university services such as libraries, computer laboratories, the internet and other online services. There is no one standard model for student unions and associations in Australian universities. Essentially, a student organisation is in place to be representative of the student and reflective of their needs. In un- some cases, the representative role and the wider student union role are clearly divided. It needs to be made clear that this bill is not designed to belittle the need for student Stubased organisations. In most cases, student unions and associations offer important student welfare services in areas such as careers and housing assistance, employment services, medical facilities, counselling and advocacy. Additionally, these associations control commercial student facilities on campus and coordinate clubs, societies and student media. However-and this is where we differstudents can choose whether to utilise most of these services during their time at university. The same cannot be said about paying quite a large sum of money to access those services. To illustrate the point, I draw the attention of the House to Deakin University, located on Burwood Highway, just outside my electorate. It is a very good university with a growing reputation for its academic standards. During recent years, Deakin University has charged a general service fee in excess of $250 for full-time undergraduates. As with most institutions, the major beneficiary of these fees was the student association-in this case, Deakin University Student Association, or DUSA. Despite the obvious financial potency of DUSA, the organisation's annual student elections generated a meagre voter turnout and a low level of interest from students for office-bearing positions. Of the 90 DUSA positions on offer across the university's three campuses, a staggering 27 remained vacant after the 2005 campus elections. This is hardly a healthy representative democracy at work. The problems evident in this are a lack of an accountable structure for the association's funding and a clear lack of incentive to increase the level of student resentation. Accurate voter turnout figures for student elections are hard to locate. ever, I have heard informally that as few as 600 students out of the tens of thousands attending Deakin actually voted in the DUSA elections. I am not using this opportunity to criticise DUSA's services or Deakin University generally; many of my constituents, staff and, notably, community volunteers within my electorate received their education at Deakin. But it has been drawn to my attention that the compulsory up-front, no-questions-asked method of fee collection can really put a strain on students. In their wisdom, many academics at Deakin University recommend that full-time students work no more than 15 hours per week when supporting their studies. For the average full-time student working 15 hours or less per week, up-front fees totalling $240 can create a real problemeven more so when they perceive they are getting no value from that fee. Abolishing the compulsory component of student union fees is one of the things that has been hotly debated in this parliament since 1999. This has had real relevance for tertiary students within my electorate as it complemented legislation passed by the Victorian Kennett government in June 1994. The Victorian legislation at that time had given the Victorian education minister power to specify which student services could require a mandatory fee. In this case state legislation created a window of accountability for student union fees. Sadly, however, this legislation was amended by the Bracks Labor government in 2000. The amendment removed the list of allowable student services, paving the way for student fees to be used for publications and often extremist political activities. The Bracks government demonstrated the time-honoured Labor tradition of placing the repconcerns of the union movement, which controls its purse strings, ahead of the interests How- of the students. Premier Bracks, himself a former student union president in the early 1980s of what is now the University of Ballarat, is part of this attempt to wind back those needed improvements in union representation and fees introduced by the Kennett government. Interestingly, the total take-up in compulsory fees at the University of Ballarat in 2005 will be approximately $1.14 million. Like many of his Labor contemporaries, the Victorian Premier's political upbringing was peppered no doubt by socialist undertones of obligatory economic distribution. Mr Burke interjecting

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I am glad you are amused by that. Many of the members opposite may argue that the intention of this legislation to increase student fee transparencies is ideologically driven. I would like to argue that the Labor Party's opposition to such moves is done in collaboration with the vested interests of the student union movement and against the interests of the students in general. Therefore, I ask the members opposite: how do you justify forcing students to pay up-front fees? This question was put before the parliament in 1999, when we debated the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill. That debate generated some memorable cynicism from the opposition. I recall at the time a cynical comment by the member for Wills, who stated: For the Liberal side of politics, voluntary student unionism is a combination of an ideological wet dream and political payback. Only the member for Wills can use that kind of expression. However, this argument is questionable when, while calling for an abandonment of the legislation, he acknowledged that a responsible government should ‘allow students to decide for themselves what they want from their student organisations'. That is exactly right. Surely it stands to reason that offering some choice in the payment to, and participation in, the student union is a key tenet in giving students such an opportunity. Abolishing student fees pulls the rug of complacency out from under student organisations-organisations that fail to effectively represent students; organisations that fail to target their efforts towards assisting students and instead promote political agendas that are out of touch with the overwhelming majority. Voluntary student unionism has generated its own sense of history in this House in recent times. Throughout Australia the pros and cons of the issue have been largely debated. A key comparison is often drawn between the Victorian model, which I previously mentioned, and the Western Australian model of the same period. Under the Victorian model, the university could prescribe a list of conditions for which a general service fee could be used. However, the changes did not include voluntary payment of fees. When VSU was introduced into Western Australia, the changes were far more pertinent. The detractors claimed that the effects of VSU reduced student services. What actually occurred was a shift towards a more targeted form of service delivery. I had an opportunity at the time to see that service delivery and the effect of the VSU legislation in Western Australia when I visited the Edith Cowan University campus in Perth. Sadly, the re-election of a Labor government in Western Australia denied the chance for the voluntary system to have a long-term effect. We have seen two attempts by state governments to introduce VSU and, on their losing office, the Labor governments reversed those attempts. Yesterday, this House debated the merits of indirect fees for employees when enterprise bargaining agreements take place-and I participated in that debate. The key ethos of that debate was the immorality of charging an indirect fee to people who choose not to be a member of a student union. While we cannot directly associate workplace relations with students, the same principle of choice should apply to student associations. Earlier in this debate, members on this side of the House highlighted the recent track record of the financial mismanagement within the University of Melbourne student union, or MUSU as it is often known. The liquidation of this once all-powerful organisation more than anything highlights the need for a greater level of accountability within these associations. It became evident towards the end of 2003 that the union had become embroiled in questionable property deals with a little-known development firm. Unbeknown to students at the time, MUSU had made arrangements to pay tens of millions of dollars to the firm to invest in apartthis ments. A very significant fact in this alleged scandal is that many involved were heavily aligned with the right of the ALP. One should not imply that the mismanagement resulted solely from political affiliation. It is very evident, however, that the alleged kingpin of this scandal is ALP figure Andrew Landeryou. He has now returned from hiding overseas to face trial. The courts have recently heard that Mr Landeryou was behind at least two controversial leasing deals struck between the union and private companies in the year before the union collapsed. He will face court and no doubt the processes of the judicial system will take place.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: A truly democratic, voluntary system will continue to permit and encourage politically active students from across the spectrum to run for office. The added accountability of having to encourage students to join will add to the role. If dent association offers good value for money services, it will attract members. It tive that student union executives work to effectively manage their finances. Under the current system, the compulsory fees do not provide an additional incentive for the University of Melbourne student union to effectively manage their estimated total take from students of $10.6 million in 2005. It is important to highlight the need for bill. Our universities are full of hard working students. Many students turn up on campus to attend classes, use the academic facilities and focus on their studies. It is simply unfair that every student should be forced to pay for many services that they choose not to use. In Victoria this year over $51.54 million in compulsory fees will feed the coffers of the various student organisations. While this is not a bad thing in itself, provided that each student utilises the pool of services, we cannot be sure that this will be the case. More importantly, there is the compulsion side of it, rather than making it voluntary. Let us run through some of the funding for the various universities in Victoria and what they will be receiving from compulsory student union fees: Deakin University-just on the outside of my electorate-$4.28 million; La Trobe University, $5.87 million; Monash University, $13.4 million; Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, $11.2 million; the University of Melbourne, $10 million; the University of Ballarat, $1.14 million; the Victoria University of Technology, $3.16 million. These are large sums of money.
