At the end of the day, this bill is about making sure that we protect students from the practices of student union bodies who have had their skill level and experience to manage the money effectively questioned. It is also about the fundamental freedoms that all of us in this place often talk about and this time have an opportunity to uphold: a stufreedom of association and freedom of choice. That is what this bill is about. I is imperacommend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Ms HOARE
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I rise this afternoon to speak against the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. The Howard government and the Liberal Party have always been opposed to student unionism and student activism. In fact, given the changes this government have brought in recently to higher education, we on this side of the House say the government are plainly against students. The bill arises from a determination by this government to thwart anything associated with the concept of unionism. They hate unionism. They hate solidarity and all that it stands for. In the case of voluntary student unionism, the Tories cannot see past the word ‘union'. We have heard many contributions today from members of the government, including the member for Deakin, that have referred to and made comparisons with workplace relations legislation. That emphasises this ideological bent. This is not the first attempt by the Liberal Party to introduce voluntary student unionism. It has been trying desperately to do so for years. The first real attempt was in Western Australia in the 1970s. Other models have been introduced but have failed to silence students. Student organisations have repeatedly voiced their opposition to Liberal Party attacks on students and universities. The Prime Minister is attempting to silence student organisations because they successfully bring to public attention the antistudent policies of the government. Students have campaigned strongly against the cutting back of billions of dollars of federal funding for universities and the doubling of HECS fees, plus the latest increases of up to 25 per cent that just about every university across this country has accepted, increases in class sizes and university fees for the dumb and the rich. There is a lot of history here. The Liberal Party has been out to quash student organisations for more than 25 years. I wonder how much of this stems from current members of the government who were so unpopular as students because they were Liberals that they could not garner any support from their fellow students in elections. When considering the background to this legislation, we should consider that some past and present members of this parliament and major party organisers came up through the ranks of student organisations, including Kim Beazley, Peter Costello, Chris Ellison, Bob Hawke, Michael Kroger, Tony Nutt, Michael Yabsley and Julia Gillard, to name just a few. Conservative politicians have identified politically orientated student organisations as ripe ground for the propagation of successful and career politicians. Despite the fact that some key and very influential people in the Liberal Party were largely introduced into politics and completed their apprenticeships in these political student bodies, more and more from the progressive side of politics emerge. This attempt and those previously to introduce voluntary student unionism have been designed with the motivation to stunt the growth and learning opportunities of non-conservative activists. The government argues that this legislation is designed to protect the right of people to choose not to belong to an organisation if they choose not to for whatever reason, be it political or otherwise. However, Mr Deputy Speaker, I think you will find that most student organisations will allow any student, on the basis of conscientious objection, to refuse to be a member of their organisation. I know that is the case with organisations at the University of Newcastle. The basis of the student's decision cannot be made on the grounds that they object to the payment of their membership fee. However, they can choose not to have that fee passed on to the student organisation. The compulsory nature of the fee structure upon enrolment does not permit a student to opt out of payment. Instead they are required to pay the fee, and in many cases organisations will allow the equivalent cost of membership to be contributed to a recognised charity of their choice. I think that if we conducted a poll of Australians as to whether they wanted the taxes that they pay to be contributing to the salary of the Minister for Education, Science and Training, many of them would choose to opt out. At this point I think it is important to cuss the precise role of student organisations in student life. Members would be aware that the vast majority of students attending university are there to get an education and do not bother with the political side of student life. However, student organisations still play a vital role in their studies. Being a student without strong financial support from parents and family is pretty tough. This government has made it harder and harder. One of the fees that is paid by students, certainly at the University of Newcastle, goes towards providing subsidised services and facilities on campus. In its attempts to close dissent among students, the Howard government is putting at risk vital services and facilities students, making things harder yet. I would like to spend a little time on the provision of services in universities. I draw my examples from the work of the University of Newcastle Union. This is not a politically active organisation. It is an organisation that provides excellent services and facilities for the students of Newcastle university and charges a fee each year to provide essential services and an environment to make life as a student enjoyable. The union's web site details the benefits of membership: - 15% discount on food within UNU - 10% discount at all UNU Shops - 12.5% discount at all UNU Bars - Internet Access - Clubs and Societies subsidies - Highly subsidised and FREE entertainment The union is not an organisation driven by profit motive. It receives concessions under the taxation laws in recognition of this fact. The organisation exists for the benefit of its members. The provision of services and activities that students want and need is a clear objective of the unions and should never be put into a position of compromise. The discounts offered to members, the clubs and dis- societies, the activities and the support of other aspects of university life are all examples of ways in which the union successfully contributes to the personal, social and cultural development of the students of the University of Newcastle. It is worth noting that, in the event of the withdrawal of a large level of membership fee income through the provisions of this legislation, many of these aspects of the organisation's activities would be jeopardised and would be likely to be severely limited. The reason for this is clear. Students are hard up for funds most of the time. The Howard government has added to these burdens and if there were an opportunity to opt out of a for membership fee then most students would take advantage of that. Under voluntary student unionism, many student organisations will become unviable. Many services and activities will dry up because they are not commercially viable, and a great aspect of student life will disappear. However, those services will still need to be provided. We will see businesses come in and replace existing services and charge market prices, which will be a major disadvantage to students. At many TAFE campuses around the country, private firms operate and provide the catering services required by students. There are large firms operating on numerous campuses. These firms are obviously profit driven. There is nothing wrong with that-they are operating a business that requires a return on their investment. However, choice is limited in order to keep costs down. Items are generally expensive and the length of time one can expect to wait to be served can be considerable. There is a captive market at many university campuses and private service providers are only too keen to take advantage of this. This draws an important distinction between the approach of student unions and that of a private provider. While many student organisations have outsourced particular catering functions, it cannot be expected that a private business which is set up to provide a return for an investment is going to consider the needs of students ahead of profits. On the face of it, the commercial operations of a student organisation may appear to be an attractive proposition for a private interest. Closer examination shows the captive market largely only exists for six months of the year and the need to establish necessary infrastructure would diminish the viability of any expected return. Only an organisation like a student union can properly maintain the services, facilities and activities that it provides for all its members. Proponents of voluntary student unionism will have you believe that the fundamental need for fees and the subsidies they provide to services and facilities that do not necessarily turn a profit cannot be justified because there are unsubsidised, off-campus alternatives to virtually all services and because there are ordinary shops within walking distance of every Australian campus. We recently heard the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, talking in this place about how much cheaper the sausage rolls are off-campus. Minister Nelson should take himself up to Newcastle university and explain to the students there where the shops are that sell these cut-price sausage rolls. The University of Newcastlelike other non-metropolitan campuses, I would think-is isolated from any shops. It is not within walking distance. The entire case of regional universities must be considered separately from metropolitan based campuses, which have different situations and concerns. Then there is the argument of competition. Proponents of voluntary student unionism will say that a student organisation having a monopoly over the provision of services is detrimental to the needs of its consumers or students, as it offers little in the way of choice. For those metropolitan based campuses, where students are able to walk from the union building to off-campus services, this must surely allow for that competitive edge that is considered so necessary. This cannot be applied to most regional campuses though. This legislation is misguided. The government may want to nip in the bud aspiring progressive student political activists, but the collateral damage is the enormous added disadvantage such a move will place on the vast majority of non-politically active students. This is a disgraceful piece of legislation. It should be opposed, and the government should be condemned for it.

Speaker: Mr HENRY
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: Hasluck) (4.44 pm)Freedom of association is one of the most fundamental freedoms enjoyed by Australians, and I am sure that there are very few within this House today that would disagree with that sentiment. It is therefore somewhat surprising, although I must admit not entirely surprising, that the Labor Party should oppose the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. It was certainly interesting to listen to the comments of the member for Charlton in her speech to the House just now regarding the Liberal Party's view of student activism and student unions. She used the emotive word ‘hate' extensively in her opening remarks, but I think it is those who sit on the opposition benches, the members of the Labor Party, who are the real haters in this House and in this parliament. Labor hates that individuals might have the freedom to choose what organisation or association they might belong to-if such individuals choose to belong to any such associations. In fact, in our communities today workers are deserting unions in droves-they are certainly voting with their feet-and I think it is the same with students: they have no great desire to belong to student unions. It is an absolute nonsense to say that the Liberal Party or the government is opposed to students. Indeed, many students are fully supportive of the initiatives of this government because they, too, stand for freedomfreedom of association and freedom of choice. This bill does not limit freedom of association. It does not seek to abolish the student union movement; nor does it in any way impact on students' rights to join and contribute to their student unions. It requires that this membership should be a conscious choice of the individual student. This is hardly an outrageous expectation. The key word here is ‘choice'. Essential to, and at the heart of, the concept of freedom of association is the right to choose to belong-or, indeed, not to belong-to a union. The government is not anti student unions. Students should be, and indeed are, free to organise and develop representative structures. Nothing in that regard will be changed by this legislation. What will change is that students will be entitled to choose to do so rather than be compelled to do so. Compulsion, by its very nature, removes choice, and the idea that students should be forced to a student union that might have little relevance to their individual beliefs, interests needs is therefore objectionable to many people, including many students that I have spoken to over the years. It is more objectionable when those students are required to hand over anything from $100 to $600 for the privilege, without having a say on how the money is spent and without taking into account the individual's ability to pay. Nor does that requirement take into consideration whether the student is in full-time or part-time education or whether they have a need for the student union services that are provided. In Western Australia many students are disaffected by the political nature of their student unions. Indeed, they are disaffected with the student union office holders that are meant to represent them. An article entitled ‘Shades of racism in campus race' that appeared on 3 November 2004 in the Inside Cover column of the West Australian newspaper helps illustrate this point. It describes the election of an African student to the office of union president and the attempt of the incumbent office holder to prevent him from taking up the role. Despite his being democratically elected, it seems that the idea that a foreigner could be the president of the student guild dismayed the acting president sufficiently for him to involve the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs in an effort to prevent the elected student taking office. Such practices bring that student union into disrepute and it is no wonder that in many cases students would prefer not to support or be associated with its activities. The government is absolutely committed to the principles of freedom of associationand to doing something about it. In that context, it is my belief that students have the right to unhindered freedom of association, join as well as to choose the services they want and the causes or organisations they wish to or support. It is absolute anathema to us that students who disagree with the current compulsory nature of student unionism should be in a position whereby they face the very real prospect of expulsion from a university or even the withholding of their examination results. The Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Upfront Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 seeks to address this issue and remove what is, in my view and the view of many in my electorate, an inequity long overdue for change. It will mean that from next year, 2006, voluntary student unionism will exist throughout Australia, and I for one warmly welcome that development. Essentially, at the core of this bill are very important provisions. Firstly, the bill requires that higher education providers should not make it compulsory for students to become members of student organisations or to pay fees for services and amenities that are not of an academic nature. Secondly, the bill provides that this prohibition on nonacademic fees should not apply to goods and services that are considered essential to the student's course of study provided the student also has the choice-there is that word again-of purchasing those goods or services from an alternative supplier. This legislation will ensure that students, as a condition of enrolment, are no longer forced to pay for goods and services that they have absolutely no use for and, at the end of the day, often can ill afford. Membership of student unions will be optional and universities will no longer be able to charge students for services they do not use or want. Optional membership of student unions would be meaningless if students were still compelled to financially support student organisations through the levying of a general services fee. If that were the case, the question would have to be asked: where would the pressure come from for student guilds to adapt and become more relevant to the people they are meant to serve? In this context, general services fees can be regarded as a form of compulsory association by another name and I therefore welcome the fact that this bill addresses this important issue. In a West Australian newspaper article entitled ‘Student groups condemn move to cut guild funding' which appeared on 17 March 2005, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Western Australia, Mr Alan Robson, made an assertion that amenity fees should not be abolished because students that were required to pay them did not have to join the student guild. Mr Robson's assertion misses two the point entirely, which is that students should not be made to pay for campus facilities they do not need. Services funded through the general services fee should be run efficiently and competitively. They should meet the actual needs of students and, this being the case, they would, in my opinion, best be provided for on a user-pays, cost-recovery basis, much as happens for services provided by commercial and voluntary organisations throughout the wider community. To ensure compliance and adherence to the two requirements imposed upon them, the bill provides for mandatory penalties for higher education providers breaching the voluntary student unionism policy. Those penalties include a reduction of the basic grant to be paid to the higher education establishment that equates to $100 for every Commonwealth supported place allocated to the provider. It is, therefore, a bill with teeth and one that higher education providers will ignore at their peril and with an eye only to the impact on their bottom line. The effect of the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 will be to achieve a number of important outcomes. It was the 17th century European philosopher and Oxford academic, John Locke, who said that the great purpose of law is not to abolish or restrain but to help preserve and enlarge freedom. This bill achieves that high ideal by establishing and enshrining a student's right to freedom of association. It embodies choice and introduces competition to an environment where none existed before. This means that student unions will have to ensure that they remain relevant to their membership and provide services that students need, want and value. Surely such a desirable outcome has to be welcomed by all parties. In essence, students will, of their own volition, join organisations that demonstrate they do a good job of representing the interests of their membership. And, of course, student unions will be able to recruit new members by offering relevant, value for money services to students that are prized by them and can be sustained in the long run. In essence, the bill encourages student unions to enter the real world, rather than continue to be closeted in a world where they exist as a fait accompli, irrespective of their performance and relevance and without any need to be seen to provide value for money. So under the bill a student body has the potential not only to survive but to thrive by being free to recruit members and offering services to students that are valued by them. Of course, those with a vested interest will oppose the idea. After all, you do not have to work particularly hard to ensure you meet the needs of your membership, if membership of the student union is compulsory. Student guilds and others will argue that valuable community facilities, particularly in regional Australia, will be lost. They will argue that the services lost as a result of untary student unionism will put an extra financial burden on universities and that the quality of their educational experience will be diminished as a result. They will argue that student unions are an essential part of university life. In my considered view, these arguments really do not stack up when examined in the cold light of day. I ask the House: is it really reasonable to force students-who most of us would agree are hardly swimming in surplus cash-to subsidise recreational and other facilities for the broader community? In my experience, few students, certainly in the electorate of Hasluck, have the resources to pay for services unconnected to their academic pursuits which, at the end of the day, are not relevant to their personal interests or to the activities they wish to pursue. As the situation stands today, many students are not even aware how their money is being used. I also contend that those regional universities in a position to share campus facilities with their local communities are well placed to spread the cost in a way that is not always available to metropolitan campuses. If facilities are valued by students and local communities, with each contributing to their operating costs, I do not believe that it will automatically follow that voluntary student unionism will have a detrimental impact on those facilities. Nor do I accept the assertions made in the media that voluntary student unionism will damage Australia's ability to win medals at the Olympics and other major sporting events. There is no basis for suggesting that services that are relevant and of interest to students will not continue to enjoy their support and to thrive. Voluntary student unionism does not mean the death knell of student unions or their contribution to university life. Far from it; as I have said, services that are valued by stuvoldents will continue to receive student support. Many sporting clubs and voluntary organisations exist throughout Australia because they offer mutually beneficial services to their membership. There is no compulsion involved and really there is no reason to suppose that university campuses should operate any differently. Individuals on campuses will band together in pursuit of common objectives just as they do everywhere else in this country. I accept that during the period from 1995 to 2002, when Western Australia embraced voluntary student unionism, as a result of the introduction by the state government of the Voluntary Membership of Student Guilds and Associations Act, some services ceased to be provided. However, the reality is that this situation reflected the change and new requirements placed upon student guilds to focus on the services most likely to be valued by their members. Students had a choice to join or not to join and many services that were initially impacted upon recovered over time as they changed and were adjusted to more closely fit with the needs of the students. I and many students in Western Australia regard it as extremely unfortunate that in 2002 the Labor controlled state government saw fit to overturn the legislation on voluntary student unionism through the introduction of a so-called amenities fee. An opinion piece in the West Australian newspaper described this practice as an egregious denial the right of choice and association, as well an inevitable infringement of students' rights. Quite rightly, in my view, the writer points out that the vast majority of students attend universities primarily to undertake academic courses and further their career prospects. So there can be no justification for hindering them from doing so by demanding payment of fees that have nothing to do with their courses. The article goes on to assert that any university that makes the payment of such amenity fees a condition of enrolment contributes to the diminishing of tertiary education. There can be no excuse for holding the future of our young people to ransom in such an unnecessary, unwarranted and unwelcome way. If student guilds are providing essential services for students, they should be able to attract members without any need for compulsion. If they cannot do so, it means that today's student union movement has, in essence, little relevance to its membership and therefore you have to ask the question: does it deserve a place on university campuses? I do not believe that this is the case and I therefore suggest to this House that there really is no need to enshrine student guilds as enclaves of unwarranted compulsion. Make no mistake about it: the move to reintroduce compulsion in Western Australia, which means that every student has no choice but to pay around $100 or more to fund the student guild, was a very definite and unwelcome step backwards for the rights of students who are once again forced to pay an up-front fee for something that is totally unrelated to their academic studies. Interestingly, though, it seems that the WA student guilds may have learnt a valuable lesson during Western Australia's period of voluntary student unionism. In an article entitled ‘Student guilds in survival bid' that appeared in the West Australian on 3 November 2004, of the then University of Western Australia as guild president was quoted as saying that strategies were being discussed to make sure better provisions were made for the onset of a return to voluntary student unionism. From my point of view such pragmatism is certainly very welcome. It is unfortunate, but fairly predictable, that the Labor Party does not seem to share that pragmatism. It seems to me that at both a state and federal level Labor is determined to oppose the right of students to exercise choice and also deny them their fundamental right to freedom of association. Opponents of this bill must surely recognise that students should not be made to pay for services they do not want. I have heard the argument put forward that by legislating for voluntary student unionism the government is in effect making an assault on academic freedom. In my view and the view of most reasonable people, the student's right to freedom of association by far overrides the right of a university or higher education provider to ride roughshod over it. The concept of academic freedom does not give the university the right or indeed the justification to interfere in the lives of their students in a way that is outside their mandate. This government is committed to the principle of freedom of association, and this bill will finally give students that right, which is already enjoyed by the wider community. On that basis I support this bill and I commend it to the House.

Speaker: Ms CORCORAN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: Isaacs) (5.02 pm)The Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 is designed to prohibit compulsory student unionism. Firstly, it will prevent higher education providers, mainly universities, from making membership of a student organisation a condition of enrolment. Secondly, the bill will prevent higher education providers from making a condition of enrolment the payment of any fee that is not directly related to a course of study. The government has a long standing commitment to prohibit compulsory student unionism in universities. One cannot help but wonder if the term ‘union' is the thing that is the real problem here. The use of the name ‘union' in association with students at university has been described as a historical accident. The earliest student organisations evolved out of the Oxford and Cambridge debating unions that were founded around 1815. These organisations grew and developed wider roles, but the name stuck and has since been adopted by other universities. Student organisations can be better likened to local councils-everyone pays for the provision of services and the services are available for everyone to use. On campus services provided by student fees go towards such things as student study spaces, free computers, free room hire, advocacy, representation, legal advice, student development opportunities, email addresses and access to sport and recreation facilities. The argument put in favour of this legislation is that current arrangements impinge on a student's right to freedom of association. That argument has been put to rest by many authorities including the full court of the Supreme Court of Victoria in Clark v the University of Melbourne and by the full court of the Supreme Court of South Australia in Harradine v the University of Adelaide. The full court of the Supreme Court of Victoria held: The essence of the University's powers is that they are powers of self-government affecting only those who choose to become members by enrolment ... they cannot touch anyone who does not voluntarily bring himself within their reach. The full court of the Supreme Court of South Australia said: The suggestion that the Universal Declaration of Human Rights is at all relevant to the issue here is not sound. In the Adelaide case it was also said that Adelaide University Union is a body providing services to members of the university. The learned trial judge noted that a student union is ‘not a union of the kind well known in the industrial and commercial world'. He went on to note that a student union is a ‘club providing facilities for eating, sport and other activities'. It is clear that a student union is not a union in the industrial relations sense at all. There is also the argument that students are forced to pay fees for services that they will not use and that their fees will be used in activities, particularly political activities, that the student disapproves of. The current Treasurer of Australia has put paid to that argument. He commented on the issue of compulsory student union fees way back in his Monash University days. He said: The funding and therefore provision of ... services would be impossible unless there was some requirement to pay a contribution ... He also said: The facilities of student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions. Those are the Treasurer's own words! In fact, the Treasurer went on to qualify his statement and illustrate it with an example. He said: The fact that some people object to the way in which some public funds are spent does not mean that they are therefore exempted from paying taxes. Treasurer, you are absolutely right. In our society we all pay taxes and share the costs of the use of services and resources, and a university is no different. The Minister for Education, Science and Training is mistaken when he says that students should enjoy the same consumer rights enjoyed by other Australians. Citizens of a democratic country generally do not have a choice about where their particular tax dollar goes. This so-called freedom of choice is an illusion. If such logic were applied to taxes, people could refuse to pay for roads they do not use and so on. The way to direct where our taxes go is through the appropriate ballot box. Simply making the tax or fee voluntary is a nonsense. We do not do it for government taxes. We do not allow doctors to opt out of paying their medical registration fees on the grounds of freedom of association. We do not allow teachers to opt out of paying registration fees. Last year many vice-chancellors were in Canberra, and MPs and senators were invited to meet with them informally. I took this opportunity to ask a number of vice-chancellors about this bill. The response was unanimous and slightly bemused: the bill is nonsense, it should never have been introduced and it certainly should not be supported. Swinburne University of Technology, my old stamping ground, has written asking me not to support this bill. I will read some of their letter: One of the main outcomes of this Bill will be to significantly reduce the range and quality of services (including academic, cultural, sporting and social services) offered to university students within Australia. It will also diminish the facilities and environments in which they are studying. This will further threaten the Higher Education export market (currently worth $8 billion), as Australia becomes less attractive to overseas students, leaving room for competitors from other countries to take market share. There are, however, further issues connected to the Bill which need to be addressed. The first is that the Bill confuses two separate issues-that of the general service fee (GSF) which is levied on students at all universities to pay for a range of amenities and services, and that of compulsory student unionism. These two matters are separate and need to be managed appropriately. Swinburne goes on: The next is that the name of the Bill is somewhat misleading. In Victoria, in accordance with the Tertiary Education Act 1993, there are no Compulsory Up-Front Student Union Fees to abolish. Victoria does not have compulsory student unionism and certainly at Swinburne, Student Union membership is an individual choice, and not linked to enrolment. Under the Bill, the general service fee (GSF) is swept away and Swinburne will effectively lose $4 million in resources per year and risks not being able to provide critical services to our students. Activities such as student advocacy, orientation, transition and mentoring programs, on-line support services and infrastructure and facility support are currently provided by GSF funds, which complement and enhance our students' studies. If this bill passes, the result will be a reduction in services offered by student organisations across our university campusesservices such as student employment services, child care, welfare services, orientation and transition to university, student loans, accommodation services, subsidised meals and access to sport and leisure activities. All these services are important to the well-being of our students. It is obvious that not all students will use all the services all the time, but that is not the point. The services are there for students to use if the need arises or if they choose to do so. Student associations have traditionally nurtured the future leaders of this country. Many members from both sides of this House were involved in their student union or association. Beyond fostering leadership, student associations hold activities and functions that allow diverse groups of people to meet and socialise. People who attend university come from regional areas, interstate and overseas. The transition from high school to university leaves many students feeling vulnerable and isolated. The university or post high school years are very important to a young person's future. It is where they begin to shed their adolescent skin and shape and mould themselves into well balanced, knowledgeable adults prepared and able to contribute to our society. Student associations allow individuality to develop, and foster an appreciation of differences. They cultivate an atmosphere of tolerance and allow students a chance to excel in their academic and social lives. I will read a letter I received from a constituent who is determined to see this bill fail: I am writing to you to voice my opposition to the Federal Governments proposal to prohibit universities from collecting a compulsory general service fee (GSF) from universities for services supporting students. As a former student of La Trobe University (Bundoora campus) I have been through the tertiary education process where GSFs are compulsory. I believe I speak on behalf of the majority of students when I say that I would not have experienced many of the benefits I did without the subsidies the university has provided through the GSF system. I continued my sporting career throughout university as it was made affordable to me. In fact I still play soccer for La Trobe University (now unsubsidised of course) despite not being a student for the past nine years. The life time friends which are made by being part of a social club plus the social and business skills learnt along the way are invaluable. None of this would have happened had GSF been voluntary as I strongly believe that the funds would not have been available to continue to run these clubs and activities. Please ensure the general service fees remain compulsory so that the quality and diversity of the tertiary experience continues. This bill is all about silencing student organisations. It is about retribution, plain and simple, because student associations dare to speak out against funding cuts to universities-funding cuts which have led to increased class sizes and to 20,000 qualified students per year being turned away from our universities. Turning away qualified students is a waste of our most precious resourceour own abilities and talents. This bill is about retribution because student associations do not want students paying an extra 25 per cent for HECS and they say so. This bill is about retribution because student associations do not want to pay full fees for undergraduate courses and they say so. Student associations understand the importance of access to education for all those who are interested and qualified, not just for those with deep pockets. The government knows all too well that university students can see straight through the recent changes in university financial arrangements and can understand very clearly the destructive nature of them. Students know that this government is intent on wrecking the future of many of our young people by denying them access to a university education. In destroying the future of many young people the government is also putting at risk the future of our society. We need all the skills and resources we can muster to thrive into the future. To deny a tertiary education to those students with the capacity and the desire for further education is to waste our resources both on an individual basis and on a community basis. The Minister for Education, Science and Training has said that if this legislation is passed students will be better able to manage their own financial affairs. That is an absolutely outrageous claim to make, given that he and the federal government are not really concerned about the welfare of our students, considering the havoc they have wreaked upon our higher education system. This bill does not enjoy the support of those at the coalface. Every university and peak university body in the country has given this bill the thumbs down. This bill is all about the government annoyed at a body speaking out against government actions. The government cannot control the voices of our students so it is intent on silencing them. It is trying to do this by removing student unions. It is worth noting in passing that the government is so afraid of collective student action that it has produced a very second-rate piece of legislation. A consequence of this bill-and it is probably unintended-will be that universities will no longer be able to issue fees for things such as parking and library services. To summarise: supporters of this bill are trying to get rid of student unions for ideological reasons. I make the point that student unions are not the same as industrial unions and that the government's obsession with unions is blinding it to the reality of what student unions really do. The government argues that compulsory student fees force some students to pay for services they do not use. Once again, I cannot do any better than to quote the current Treasurer when he was wearing another hat and explained that provision of services would be impossible without a requirement on all students to contribute. Every part of this bill is awful-not merely from an ideological perspective but from a functional and practical one. I will not be supporting this legislation.

Speaker: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: It is turning into a long day of debate on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Upfront Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. Many speakers have preceded me and, looking at the speakers list, I see there are many yet to come. I do not want to sound snobby about this but there is a lot of interest in this bill from both sides of the chamber. I rise to strongly support this bill. I am proud to support this bill. I believe in freedom of association; anyone in this place who opposes the bill clearly does not. For all the rhetoric we have heard, this bill is not based on a narrow political ideology; it is not wedge politics; it is not returning favours to any sections of the community. This government does not do that-unlike our opponents when they have had the opportunity to be in government. This legislation is based on a simple mainstream belief that is held by the peoples of every free nation around the globe, and that is that everybody should have the freedom to associate with people or organisations of their own choice and nobody should be forced to associate with people or organisations against their will. So this issue is really about quite a simple principle, and one which I am somewhat surprised we are contesting and debating here today. I cannot see how people can stand up and proudly oppose a bill that contains a measure that simply seeks to enact this belief. My party, the Liberal Party, is guided by firm principles. Some 60 years ago the organisation's founders set down ideals which today would cause us to stop higher education providers-that is, universities-from forcing their students to become members of student organisations or at least from forcing them to pay fees for services and amenities that are not of an academic nature. We are talking about paying for things that do not necessarily relate to the purpose of attending a university. We are talking about fees and charges for services that are not essential to obtaining a higher education. Today I have been respectfully listening to some of the comments from members of the opposition who strongly oppose this bill. Some of the arguments being used-I think, to defend the indefensible-are very difficult to accept for anybody around Australia who is able to listen to the broadcast of this debate or read it later in Hansard. How can you describe child care as an essential service? Child care is an important service for a lot of people. It has been important in the past for my family. But, in the context of a university education, you simply cannot say with very much credibility that it is essential. Of course it is important for many; but, like the sporting examples we have heard of, such as the rugby club at Sydney University, it is not an essential service. It is important for those who need and want to enjoy campus life in that way but there is no defensible reason for the entire body of students to be forced against their will to subsidise and pay for those services for other people. I think the previous speaker is one of the Labor Party's better advocates, because she argues in such a respectful and dignified way. But I still think it is difficult to defend her opposition to the bill. She said that this bill is retribution against students who have protested against this government in the past. It is true that student organisations around Australia have very loudly protested against many of the important reform measures that this government has introduced over nine years, including the GST, industrial relations and issues that have nothing to do with campus life. However, the Howard government, and I as an individual, have no problem with people protesting and expressing their opinion on any issue. In fact, this legislation will do nothing to water down students' ability to collectively organise, if that is their wish, and protest on any issue they like, providing that it is done in a law-abiding way. Forcing people to pay is a breach of basic human rights. The previous speaker compared university fees to taxes. Federal and state taxes are applied to everybody in the Australian community. We all pay taxes in accordance with the same rules and we may often think to ourselves that we are paying for services and government spending that we do not use or want. The argument being applied by the previous speaker was that university fees that would go to student organisations could be viewed in the same way and therefore there is a good reason why they should be compulsory. With respect, this argument is totally unsustainable. You are comparing an educational institution with a sovereign, elected government-so there the comparison ends. No university should be ascribed the status and the ability to make decisions on behalf of other people that belong to a government. Every person should have the right to choose the goods and services they want and the causes they are prepared to support. I would like to make it clear again that I am not opposed to student organisations. They can be an exciting form of democracy in which students are able to represent their members, the students, and to undertake advocacy-and even, if they are able to do so using the resources they do have, to provide services which will benefit their members. The passing of this bill will not stop or impede that sort of voluntary activity. In fact, I would argue today that this bill actually reinforces it and encourages a form of student engagement which is far more dynamic and meaningful-voluntary and loyal membership. If I were the head of an organisation and I had the choice between having a membership of people who were paying toward the costs of that organisation and a membership of people who perhaps had no choice as to whether or not they contributed to the running costs of the organisation, I would feel very much as though I were leading an organisation that had a very reluctant membership in the latter case. There is not a status in that; there is certainly not much pride; and there is zero dignity in it. I would rather lead an organisation that had a membership of people who were committed to the central causes that made that organisation exist in the first place. I would rather have a membership of people who believed in the need and the legitimacy of that organisation. It is almost like an arranged marriage as things are-two reluctant partners stuck with each other and forced to make it work out as best they can. As we should all know as mature adults, a good, healthy marriage-a healthy relationship-is where there is mutual affection and mutual loyalty. Student organisations will always be free to recruit members and offer services to students. If the students want them, they will buy them. If they want those services but perhaps can find a better deal elsewhere, they should be able to choose them and buy those without being told where to purchase. Conversely, if they do not want those services, if they do not need them, if they are not a part of their academic program at the university or higher education provider, they should be excused from paying for them. I say here today that the National Union of Students is totally out of touch with this nation's student population. I represented the University of Tasmania's Launceston campus as a delegate to the NUS in the early 1990s. I was in a distinct minority by choosing to be an independent. Most others were disturbingly close to-or active members of-the Australian Labor Party and some others were close to that ragtag group of Democrats and, when that disintegrated, really became followers of the Greens. While the odd protest against the government of the day was quite normal, to be expected, it was really an annual event. The union tried to rally its members to always put the Liberals last at elections. It was in reality a Trojan horse for the lot of Labor Party. The arrangement between the Labor Party, unions like the NUS and campus guilds, unions and associations is one of the best examples we have today of mutual obligation-even before the advent of the Howard government and our social compact. Labor needed the union-and, let us face it, the union needed Labor. Both consequently totally lost touch with the real world. They have lost touch with real students and they have totally lost touch with the real needs of students. I can see again today evidence of how true that still is today. I again say to my Labor colleagues that you are defending the indefensible so long as you stand in the way of freedom of association, whether it be in schools, clubs, churches, businesses, trade unions or university campuses. To stop a student or an individual person from having that innate right to choose whom they will associate with is indefensible and to be condemned. I would also say that the National Union of Students is far too closely aligned to the ALP and the Greens-parties that say they fight for the people's best interests. I do not believe that this is the case. They want to force people to pay student union fees-with or without their support, permission, involvement or loyalty. As most tertiary education students in this country will tell you, money is very tight and every purchase is a very considered and careful decision. Cashstrapped students need to have the flexibility to spend their money on what they want to spend it on. Let us face it: if students really believe that services that university unions, guilds and associations have on offer to their members are worthwhile, they should be free to purchase them, not forced to do so. If students actually believe that university union services are worthwhile, they will willingly pay for them. Equally, if they are worthwhile, the student unions should have the courage to market them and to take the same business decisions that every other commercial entity around Australia has to take: to market their product, to run a proper business plan, to not run and offer services and spending that are wasteful and to try to meet their market-in the case of universities, to try to meet the needs of the students in relation to whom they have an excellent marketing opportunity, a captive audience, to whom they can advertise their various wares and services. Student union presidents who claim that they will be shut down with legislation obviously have no confidence in the services they provide. Without naming the person, I want to mention that quite recently I received an email from an advocate for stopping voluntary student unionism. I had to be quite honest and blunt and say: If services provided by student unions such as yours are valuable services for students, then dents will naturally be willing to choose them and they will pay whatever chargeable fees are set by your union. I then asked: Are you firm in your opinion that providing this choice to students will cause you to shut down? If so, perhaps you may agree that it is unreasonable to force students to pay for a service or organisation that is, in your own words, unsustainable. Good on him for writing to me. At least he had the courage to make his claim. That email was the only opinion that I received in my office-by email, post or fax-that actually came from a student who resides in my electorate. And I have two higher education institutions, with some thousands of students, in my electorate. So I am not opposed to student organisations. I have been in one. I just want to see value for money. Figures compiled in 2003 looking at compulsory student union fees around the country showed the national average for 39 institutions was $280, which are substantial funds for a young person or a mature age student to have to find at the beginning of the university year when there are also various other expenses such as accommodation, textbooks and levies payable for the courses they have chosen. I am very amused also with some of the claims that we heard from the member for Melbourne Ports earlier today, which somehow said that the Howard government, in wanting to introduce this bill and see it carried forward, was attacking freedom of speech. So we see that member doing something which I think is unreasonable in an argument-that is, playing off these two important principles of freedom speech and freedom of association. But the two can validly be upheld: we are not choosing freedom of association over freedom of speech, because this government believes that we can have both and that we should have both and stuthat a student, irrespective of what their political or life views might be, ought to have the right to join a union if they want to and the right to not join a union if they do not want to. Also, whether or not they are a member of a union or an organisation that represents students, they should have the right to freedom of speech. Nothing I do in this chamber will diminish that freedom that I believe in. I want to draw the House's attention to some material from the National Union of Students. Again, that is an organisation that I used to be a member of. On 22 April a posting on their web site claimed: As with all regressive changes to the Higher Education sector, the impact of Voluntary Student Unionism legislation will not fall equally on students. The person who wrote the article concerned has not put their name to it, but it is an official document from NUS. It further states: Student organisations are of specific and direct benefit to women students in a myriad of ways, therefore attempts to destroy them hit women particularly hard. Viva la revolution! This will liberate women on campus and give women more choices because they will be able to choose to pay for union membership if that is their wont, and if that is in their best interests they can do that. This government will be doing something for those women students by providing them with a choice that they do not have today, but which they will have as soon as this bill, which we have presented so often in this parliament, gets passed in the Senate. The NUS web site also said that around 350 students attended the activities held on the University of New England National Day of Action and found out more about the implications of the VSU legislation currently before federal parliament. The NUS web site has a picture of a poster which advertised the event and told everybody to come. In two photographs associated with this story you can perhaps see the number of people who were there, which looks like a couple of dozen, not 350. This is further evidence of that union's inability to engage in this debate in a cognisant and sensible manner. The NUS also supplied protesters with suggested chants that they could use on the National Day of Action on 28 April: ‘VSU no way, we are going to fight it all the way.' That is a good one. ‘VSU is not a choice. It destroys the student voice.' ‘VSU is not a choice. Give the students back their voice.' And the ripper, which I think really goes to explain the purpose of the National Day of Action and, indeed, the purpose of this unall ion: ‘Unions yes, Liberals no. VSU has got to go.' My time is about to expire, so I thank the House. I commend this bill to the House and I call on Labor and members opposite to withdraw their fanatical opposition to this bill and to support the rights of the people they were put here to represent.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: The government's official spin on the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 is that it is somehow related to civil liberties, human rights and freedom of choice. In fact, the bill has little to do with any of those things. Every now and then government members let slip what is indeed the real motivation behind this bill when they launch into their typical tirade about student guilds, student unions, student councilshowever they are named-on university campuses daring to be involved in public debate and public comment, usually taking a position contrary to that of the Liberal Party of Australia. For that they have been condemned and for that they are being punished now. I want to refer to a very interesting letter I received which outlined some concerns about this bill. I challenge members opposite to listen to me read the letter and to identify where it came from. The letter said that the: ... proposal to reduce already inadequate Commonwealth support for the University is an unwarranted interference in the affairs of the University. If promulgated in its present form, the legislation could do irreparable damage to the University and particularly to its international competitiveness. That was a letter from the Chancellor and the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Queensland. Who is the Chancellor of the University of Queensland? It is Sir Llewellyn Edwards, former leader of the Liberal Party in the state of Queensland, former Deputy Premier to former Premier Bjelke-Petersen. It was also signed by the Vice-Chancellor, Professor John Hay, a well respected academic. Llew Edwards, one of the high priests of the Liberal Party in Queensland, understands clearly the implications of the madness of this government's legislation if it is enacted. He understands the impact on the university and on the services available for the staff and the wider community at the university and he thinks that is more important than the blind Liberal dogma that we have witnessed here in this debate and seen evidenced in the contribution of a number of members. The letter from the University of Queensland's Senate is illustrative in a number of respects and I want to refer to a couple of other passages in it: The Senate of the University of Queensland is very strongly opposed to the Commonwealth Government's alarming proposals in relation to voluntary student unionism and compulsory student service charges. That is the first sentence. Let there be no mistake where Llew Edwards and the Senate of the University of Queensland stand. They are strongly opposed to these proposals. Later on the letter sets out some of the important services and functions that the various student bodies perform. Many of those things have been covered during the debate today. The letter also refers to the important role that those student bodies play in the educational development of the students as part of their university life. If time permits, I may return to quote some of that letter. They also note quite correctly that student clubs and societies are a part of the great tradition of Western universities. I have seen in other material the comment that, if this legislation goes through, Australia will be the only country in the Western world to have outlawed these compulsory student fee payments. I have endeavoured to get that checked on a number of occasions. I have not been able to determine absolutely that it is accurate, but it does appear to be the case. Certainly, as Llew Edwards and Professor John Hay point out, it is the tradition in Western universities for there to be compulsory student organisations that the students participate in, not just for the delivery of important services but as part of the development of those people at universities, not all but many of whom are transiting through life from youth to adulthood and will be leaders of our community in years to come. That is important. If Llew Edwards, one of the high priests of the Liberal Party in Queensland, can understand that, it beggars belief that few on the government side either cannot comprehend it or, if they do comprehend it, fail to have the intestinal fortitude to stand up and do something about it. The letter that I received from Llew Edwards that I was quoting from has in fact been sent to every member of the federal parliament from Queensland and to the minister. The parliamentary secretary at the table, the member for Petrie, no doubt has a copy. I am sure she has read it and I look forward to her contribution to this debate, answering the letter from Llew Edwards and explaining why he, as one of the senior, respected political figures in Queensland-and a senior Liberal figure to boot-has got it wrong. I suspect the parliamentary secretary is not about to give up her job and cross the floor to vote with us on this, so she may like to enter the debate and explain to us why the people of Petrie should find themselves lost in this debate. It is not just the Liberal Party in Queensland that is led by people who understand the importance of student services on campus. Not that long ago, on 29 April, I was interested to note a statement from the leader of the opposition in the Queensland parliament, the leader of the Queensland National Party, Lawrence Springborg. The Courier Mail reported on that day: Queensland Nationals leader Lawrence Springborg has broken from conservative ranks to call for major changes to the Federal Government's voluntary student unionism legislation. The article quoted him saying: I think there is a strong case for a compulsory levy otherwise genuine student services will fer, particularly in regional areas ... That is Lawrence Springborg, the leader of the National Party in the Queensland parliament and the leader of the opposition in the Queensland parliament. So we have here two prominent Queenslanders, leaders in their own right of conservative parties, the Liberal Party in the case of Llew Edwards and the National Party in the case of Lawrence Springborg, both coming out publicly and saying that this government's approach with respect to compulsory fees at university is wrong and, worse than that, is damaging to the life of the university. Indeed, the University of Queensland, in the letter from Llew Edwards, went on to point out that it is going to create problems for them as they endeavour to market themselves to students overseas because the services provided by these student guilds and bodies are often regarded as essential by overseas students and those who pay for the overseas students to come here. They are concerned that the University of Queensland will be placed at a disadvantage when those students look around the world because, unlike the rest of the universities in the Western world, they will find that these services are not available to students here in Australia if this legislation goes through. Why is that the case? We need look no further than the comments of some opposite when they were in a different life. Treasurer Peter Costello no less, when he was at university, was not only an activist in his student association but also the president of it. He was the president of the Monash Association of Students. He wrote an article about the threat to universities should compulsory charges be removed. This is what Peter Costello wrote in that article: The funding and therefore provision of the various student services would be impossible unless sufthere was some requirements to pay a contribution towards them. … … … ... the facilities of the student unions are only practical on the basis of compulsory contributions ... That was no less a person than Peter Costello, the Treasurer of Australia today, when he was president of the Monash association-when he was actually at university, involved in an association and understanding on a day-today basis the services they provide and the way those services are funded and operate. That is the view he had then. He is quite silent about it these days. He has his mind set on other activities at the momenthe is trying to topple the Prime Minister and have a bit of generational change within the Liberal cabinet room. But when he was the president of the student guild at Monash University, he made no bones about this issue. He made it clear that, without the compulsory payment, these services would not exist. That reinforces the concern that people like Llew Edwards and Lawrence Springborg have raised. These are not people whom government members can characterise as left wing radicals or unionists trying to bring down the world as we know it. If you listen to some of the nonsense from people on the other side, they would have us believe that university student guilds were hotbeds of anarchy. It is a fairly amusing thing for those of us who were involved in student politics, and I have to confess that I was very active in student politics as well. There are people on both sides of this chamber who were. Unlike Peter Costello, I hold the views about the importance of those organisations that I held then. Like Llew Edwards and Lawrence Springborg, I appreciate the importance that they provide on campus for a whole range of reasons. This is not the first time John Howard and his government have sought to introduce legislation such as this. A similar-probably identical, in fact-piece of legislation was introduced into this parliament in 1999 which evoked the same negative response from all of those involved with universities, and by that I do not mean the student guilds and unions that those opposite want to lambast. One university union went bankruptyes, that happened. We can talk about companies that go bankrupt. Does that mean we should close down the operations of boards of directors around the country? We can talk about company directors that are behind bars because of their improper behaviour. Does that mean we should be taking drastic action to close down corporate Australia? The simple fact is that there are going to be some people who want to bend rules and cut corners. That happens everywhere, but please do not pretend in this debate that they are representative of the student guilds and unions around Australia. That is such a fallacious argument-it does no credit to those in the Liberal and National parties who have raised it. Let me go back to when this issue was raised in 1999. Who came out then to oppose the legislation? There were people like Sir Gerard Brennan, the former Chief Justice of the High Court, and Steve Monaghetti, the well-known Australian Olympian and marathon runner. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee opposed it, and I believe they are opposed to it on this occasion. Not only were people outside the parliament on the record as opposing it; in 1999, at least, there were a few Tories in this parliament who were willing to stand up and publicly criticise itpeople who today are silent. Mr Murphy-Name them.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I am invited by my friend the member for Lowe to name them, and I think I should. In 1999 those people on the government benches for the Liberal and National parties who thought that this was a bad thing and said so publicly were: Ian Macfarlane, the member for Groom, now a minister; Kay Hull, the member for Riverina; Joanna Gash, the member for Gilmore; and a member who is now an Independent, Bob Katter, the member for Kennedy. So members of the Liberal and National parties were saying publicly that this was the wrong tack to take, it would damage the role of universities, it would damage the services available and it would diminish the experience of students as they progressed through tertiary education. I wonder what has happened to people like Ian Macfarlane, Kay Hull and Joanna Gash these days-not a peep out of them. At least people like Llew Edwards have the intestinal fortitude and integrity to stand up and publicly say this is the wrong thing to do. There is even Lawrence Springborg from the National Party. You do not hear me saying too many positive things about the Queensland National Party, but at least the Queensland National Party are led by someone who understands that his constituents are going to be hurt by this. A couple of weeks ago I spoke at a rally against this proposition on the campus of the Queensland University of Technology. I made the point then that it is really bewildering to see the National Party jumping off the cliff like lemmings on this issue. They have done it on other things; there is no reason why they should not do it on this. It is not passing amusement that they are referred to these days as ‘Liberals in gumboots', but their constituents are actually seriously affected. One of the critical services most student guilds and unions provide is accommodation and other support for people who are moving into the area of the university. They might be moving from, say, the outskirts of Brisbane into the city and need assistance with accommodation or job placement. They might need to know where there are doctors who bulk-bill, because most university students do not have a lot of cash. They may need other counselling support and services. Because they are away from their home base, they may need some advice on the operation of their university and, from time to time, advocacy support if things go wrong. One of the groups that use those services more than others are, in fact, the people from the bush who come to the city for their tertiary education. Lawrence Springborg is smart enough to understand that. You would hope that cocky corner on the other side of the House could wake up before the vote occurs and realise that their constituents are going be adversely affected if they mutely sit on their hands. But I would have to say that, given their performance on a number of issues-not least of all the sale of Telstra-we will see the National Party trot along with the Liberal Party and support this bill. During this debate, members on this side of the House have referred to the idea of mutual obligation and the fact that it is not uncommon in our society for people to be obliged to make a contribution if, indeed, they receive a benefit from an organisation. We would not be here as a parliament and a government if we did not subscribe to that principle, because it is on that basis that we tax people whether they like it or not. It is on that basis that state and local governments for tax people whether they like it or not. I have listened to comments from government members who are critical of that. There are a few lawyers on the other side of this parliament. I just wonder what they say about the compulsory fees they have to pay to their law societies. Should that be the next bill we introduce? If this is about freedom of choice, civil liberties and human rights, why is it that we tolerate a situation where lawyers have to make a contribution to an organisation whether they want to or not? Because there is a good reason for that: it ensures a standard; there is a collective benefit. As a society we accept the view that, if you get the benefit, you should make a contribution. There was another very good comparison made, I think by one of the student union activists in an article recently, which perhaps was better than those already made in this debate. It is the situation that applies in Queensland, and perhaps elsewhere, of the ambulance levy. I think people would agree that the ambulance service is an essential service. Our society could not really function in a civilised manner without it. In Queento sland, until quite recently ambulance contributions were voluntary. As a consequence, the ambulance service was dramatically underfunded. So you would go to your shopping centre on Saturday and there would be a chook ruffle or a chocolate wheel, and the ambulance guys would be out there trying to raise a few bob to make sure they had equipment for their ambulances that, frankly, are an essential service. The Beattie government, quite properly, put an end to voluntary contributions. They said: ‘This is an essential service and we are going to place a levy on people to cover it. Everyone will make a contribution, which will guarantee an appropriate level of resourcing for the ambulance service.' We heard some of the same arguments then from people in the community. Frankly, I supported that decision by the Queensland government. Everybody should be making a contribution to the operation of the ambulance service. None of us particularly want to be in a situation where we need it, but it is proper that we all make a contribution to it. Today I do not hear anyone in Queensland arguing the reverse of that. I do not hear anybody hopping up to say, ‘We should abolish that because really it is a question of freedom of choice, human rights and civil liberty.' The argument before the parliament today is about something far broader. It is not about the things that the government have put forward in the debate. It is in fact this: John Howard and this government will not tolerate dissent; they will not tolerate alternative voices in our community. We have seen it in the rhetoric of those opposite when the emotions start to run high The student unions happen to be the latest group in the firing line for that; they are not the first people encounter it. It has happened to the environmental groups. It has happened to social groups who have had their funding cut or threatened. It has happened to church groups who dare to complain that the welfare system in this country has got worse. It has happened to the ABC-they were being bludgeoned to death by this government. Now the government are directing their weaponry at the student unions, because they erate voices of dissent and alternative thought. That is fundamentally wrong and is one of the most insidious things this government have done since they came to office. I oppose this bill wholeheartedly. It may well be that the bill will go through after 1 July, but it will be at great cost to universities throughout Australia. If people opposite do not want to listen to Labor members, they should listen to the wise heads in their own Liberal and National parties on this issue. Debate (on motion by Mr Keenan) adjourned.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: Sitting suspended from 5.54 pm to 7.30 pm APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 2005-2006 Second Reading Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Costello: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: Our great country is about to enter the second decade of conservative rule. History will mark 1996 to 2006 as the Liberal-National government's decade of deception: year after year of lowering the ‘truth' bar, then deliberately crawling under it, with one common theme-the government deceive and Australians pay. But this year we have learned why the government to have been so deceitful. We uncover their motive with each new economic indicatorwith one of the highest foreign debt levels in the world, with a record current account deficit, with household debt rising and rising-and with the tragedy of a government that turns away tens of thousands of Australians from TAFE colleges whilst the Treasurer makes a virtue in his budget speech of importing skills from overseas to make up will not tol- for the difference. Sadly, we are learning the truth. They have squandered this chance to make Australia secure for our children and grandchildren. They have surfed a wave of prosperity but left the tough decisions to future generations. When we hoped they would get better, they got worse. Tuesday's budget centrepiece is an injustice of the highest order. Instead of leading Australia through reforms the OECD and Reserve Bank, among others, tell us we ought to have, instead of preparing Australia for the next phase of growth by investing in training Australians and in infrastructure like roads, rail, water and ports-and in tax reform which encourages people into the Australian work force-the budget savaged the weakest in our society and contemptuously dismissed those nurses, teachers, tradesmen, labourers-the people raising our families, 80 per cent of our taxpayers, seven million Australians, the engine room of Australia. They received no tax cuts last year or this year and in the next three they get a derisory $6 a week-nothing to encourage those out of the work force into it but for a minority a tax cut which, for the first time in my memory, takes those of us in this parliament out of the top tax bracket with 10 times the reward of our fellow Australians. If you think anyone here of Labor principle would vote ourselves a $65 weekly tax cut when the people who put us here get $6, you have got another think coming. It is not leadership to cheer this through. What leadership means is that when you are confronted with something like this you stand up and fight. That is what we will do. I will do so in the context of a budget of lost opportunity. It comes at a time when Australia is enjoying its highest export prices since Don Bradman retired from captaining Australia half a century ago. The minerals boom that underpins our economy has nothing to do with the policies of this government. Good fortune has added $40 billion per year to our national income. That is the equivalent of a $7,000 bonus for every Australian family, every year. But a responsible leader looks out to the horizon, sizes up the future threats to the nation and prepares it for risks. Before the budget, the question for Australia was: what would we do with this singular opportunity? Would we invest it in something that lasts? Would we take this extraordinary opportunity to repair what is broken in our nation? This is a question of our values: what and who would come first in our Australia? This budget has failed the Australian people because it fails to act upon urgent challenges facing the nation. It does nothing new to ease our chronic skill shortage. It does nothing new to fix our ports and roads. It does nothing new to support research and development. It does nothing new to support our universities. It does nothing new to solve the water crisis. It does nothing new to lift our exports. Fairer tax reforms But before I get on to those matters, I want to deal with the first order of business: taxation. Tonight I am drawing a line in the sand with John Howard on Australian values and the sort of country we want to be, a line between us and this government, which says someone earning $500,000 a year deserves 10 times the tax cut of an Australian earning $50,000 a year. A lot of Australians think that John Howard's tax plan is terribly unfair. I will expose it for what it is and oppose it for what it is. I will not accept criticism from a greedy government for standing up for the seven million Australian taxpayers who were tossed the tax cut scraps from the tax cut feast enjoyed by so few Australians. The Labor Party will be the last line of defence between John Howard and his desire to divide the Australian community-reward some and punish the many.
